PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed works be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Laboratory complex for CSIRO Division of Minerals, Clayton, Vic.

SPEECH.PARA: The development at Clayton will be designed to accommodate the 130 staff from Port Melbourne, including a number of visitors and students. The staff will include 70 research personnel; 54 personnel in management, administration and research support; and six visiting scientists and students. Completion of the project is expected by late 1997. The proposed complex will be consistent with the long-term CSIRO strategy to integrate and consolidate compatible research resources and facilities on a small number of major regional sites.

PARA.TAB: The Port Melbourne site is a converted paint factory on a state government lease. It has been the subject of an adverse OH&S investigation and is inadequate due to its old buildings, lack of space and high infrastructure cost. The proposed complex will amalgamate two research groups of the newly formed Division of Minerals who are currently dispersed—one being at Clayton and the other at Port Melbourne. The amalgamation will allow improved communications between the two groups in synergy with other CSIRO divisions already on the Clayton site and at Monash University.

The existing Port Melbourne site lease will be terminated. The construction project has a budget of $15.5 million, which has been approved by the CSIRO board, and will be funded from within the CSIRO 1994-2000 capital investment plan. All construction will take place within the existing CSIRO site at Clayton in accordance with the current site master plan, and construction is proposed to commence in early 1996 and be completed in late 1997. I table the attached drawing and commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this referral of works to the Joint Committee on Public Works. Clayton, Springvale and Oakleigh are areas that have been very badly hit by unemployment, particularly in the ethnic community. Unemployment in that part of Melbourne is about 50 per cent higher than the national average, and ethnic unemployment is up to three times greater than the national average. In that area, the unemployment rate of the Vietnamese in the community is about 30 per cent and the unemployment ratee of those of Greek extraction is about 15 per cent.

PARA.TAB: For that reason, I hope the public works committee will make an early analysis and give approval to this project so that, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mrs Crosio) has said, we can look forward to construction commencing there in early 1996 and to ongoing employment in that very difficult part of Melbourne.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed works be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Joint venture development with Delfin Property Group of The Willows, Townsville, for defence housing.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a need to provide adequate housing for service families posted to Townsville, for which the Defence Housing Authority—referred to as the DHA—is responsible. Originally, DHA formed a joint venture with Delfin Property Group to tender for an attractive parcel of land at Douglas in Townsville. Unfortunately, the tender was unsuccessful. But soon after DHA, on behalf of the joint venture, successfully negotiated the acquisition of 107 hectares of land at Kirwan known as the Willows, which was available for sale by the receivers of Kern Corporation.

PARA.TAB: The DHA acquired the land on behalf of the joint venture, subject to the approval of the public works committee and the minister. The joint venture has proceeded with the development of a portion of the land on the eastern side of the main stormwater drain with the approval of the public works committee and wishes to proceed with the development of the balance of the land. It is intended that the DHA acquire approximately 25 per cent of the lots from the joint venture at a reasonable discount and thereon provide new housing for service families which has been specifically designed for the local climate. The total development cost for the joint venture is estimated to be $37 million. However, the maximum exposure for DHA is approximately $3.8 million in mid-1995. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 29 June 1994.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill amends the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992 to give effect to initiatives announced in the context of the 1994-95 budget. This bill proposes to provide grants to foster literacy development for children in the early years of schooling. Under the new provisions, $8.7 million will be made available to assist children from kindergarten to year 3, with special emphasis on those disadvantaged by low socioeconomic backgrounds.

PARA.TAB: Additionally, $4 million will be made available to provide grants to school authorities to support the study of 10 priority languages. This program will replace an existing program which supports eight languages in each state and territory.
The bill provides for a number of other changes:

SPEECH.PARA: strengthening the Commonwealth's new schools policy for funding new and changing non-government schools;
simplifying administrative arrangements for approving block grant authorities under the capital grants program for schools; and

funding schedules for capital grants for government and non-government schools for 1995, funding schedules for grants for community languages for 1995 and a revised funding schedule for grants for rural student hostel projects for 1994 to 1996.

With this bill and the government amendments I propose to introduce, total grant levels for schools for the 1995 program year are estimated to be $3.086 billion. Funds appropriated for the 1995 program year are estimated to be some $2.459 billion for general recurrent grants to government and non-government schools, $316.7 million for capital grants to government and non-government schools, $289.1 million for national equity programs, $14.7 million for the school language program and $6.3 million for other programs. I commend the bill to the House and present the supplementary explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for the opportunity to eventually speak to the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994. This bill amends the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992 to give effect to the following budget initiatives: $8.7 million is to be provided in 1995 to foster literacy development for children in the early years of schooling; $4 million is to be allocated in 1995 to provide grants to school authorities to support the study of 10 priority languages. This program will replace an existing program which supports eight languages in each state and territory.

PARA.TAB: The bill will also give effect to changes to the Commonwealth new schools policy. It will give effect to changes to administrative arrangements for approving block grant authorities under the capital grants program for schools as well as funding schedules for capital grants for government and non-government schools for 1995 and funding schedules for grants for community languages for 1995. I believe further amendments will be moved later this morning in relation to supplementation.

After much consideration and consultation, my position will be consistent with that of the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), who, when the bill was introduced last year, gave an undertaking not to oppose the bill. That is not to say that we fully support all initiatives provided in this bill. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1)expresses its grave concern at the direction of the Federal Government's new schools policy, and calls on the Government to abandon this policy;

(2)despite the widespread cynicism as to the Government's motives in commissioning a review of arrangements in this area, calls on the Government to have this review completed as soon as possible, and no later than September 1995".

TALK.START.PARA: —Any particular date in September?
—Well, I personally might decide on 1 September. What do you reckon? That might be a good start. I would even be prepared to extend that to 30 September if it would make it any easier for you.

PARA.TAB: To fully understand many of this bill's implications, it is important to have a background understanding of what these measures involve. With regard to the new schools policy, in order to gain provisional approval and eventually final approval for general recurrent funding, schools must meet certain eligibility criteria, including an advanced notification requirement and a sufficiently high funding priority. Under the 1992 act, a school wishing to operate at a new location, amalgamate, provide an additional level of education or separate into two or more schools must give notice two years before 1 March in the year in which the change is proposed. The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 extends this notice period to three years before 31 October for changes proposed on or after 1 January 1997.

Clause 23 of this bill introduces a further notification requirement for changes or proposals intended to occur on or after 1 January 1998 so that notification of a change or proposal to be funded in 1998 will be required by 31 October 1995. Keep in mind, Mr Speaker, that we are already a quarter of the way into 1995 and not only has this bill not been passed but one must question the ability of schools which have not acted pending the outcome of this bill to give adequate notification by the end of October this year.

The coalition maintains its policy position of the last election, which is to abandon the new schools policy. Make no mistake about it: Labor has always been philosophically opposed to non-government school education, and this policy is just one example of this outdated philosophical position. The principal objective of this policy is to make it as difficult as possible for new schools to start. It is that simple. The policy is opposed to real parental choice in schooling, with the post-1992 funding policy effectively pricing non-government schools out of the reach of many parents. The coalition is committed to parental choice in schooling and we believe that this should be an affordable choice.

Turning to the block grants authority proposal, under the general element grant administered by DEET, funds are provided in the form of block grants to state education authorities for the government sector and to block grant authorities—BGAs—for the non-government sector. There are two BGAs in each state—one Catholic and one independent—and there is a joint Catholic-independent BGA in both the Northern Territory and the ACT. This bill amends the principal act by removing the requirement to re-approve a block grant authority every time a school or hostel joins or leaves a BGA. I am sure the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) will be pleased to hear that this proposal is supported by the coalition, as it will clearly not only simplify the existing arrangements but also will do away with unnecessary administrative burdens.

The priority language incentive element—PLIE—has been aimed at promoting a collaborative effort with the states to improve national proficiency in languages other than English. The objective of the element has been to provide financial incentives to increase the number of students studying priority languages other than English at the year 12 level.

The bill also has the effect of curtailing the operations of the priority languages element to the program years 1993 and 1994, and to give effect to a new program to replace the PLIE from the beginning of program year 1995. The new program will provide grants to government and non-government education authorities to support the study of 10 priority languages.

The coalition believes that the serious decline in skills in languages other than English needs to be addressed. We believe that skills in languages other than English are also important for Australia's international competitiveness. It is clear that successful exporters tend to be companies that have staff skilled in the language of their non-English speaking customers or potential customers.

I will now return to the new schools policy amendment of the bill. The coalition has long been opposed to the government's draconian new schools policy. The policy is restrictive, intrusive and designed to restrict true parental choice. The coalition has been vehemently opposed to this policy since its introduction. It is an issue on which we believe very strongly and it is an issue on which we have consistently campaigned in successive elections. Unlike the government, the coalition still listens to those who work in the field of non-government schools. They have said to us that the policy should be renamed the `no new schools policy' as it significantly retards new schools growth.

Labor is philosophically opposed to non-government schooling and private education. It has been for a long time, and the new schools policy is a manifestation of its disdain for this sector. The government in its arrogance is proud of this policy. We on this side remember all too well being continually chastised for our policy to abolish the new schools policy, a policy position, I am proud to say, we will implement on our return to government.

The former Minister for Employment, Education and Training, now Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley), declared in a press release prior to the last election that to abandon the new schools policy would be to `abandon the government's stable, needs-based system school funding'. In a speech to the National Press Club on 19 October 1992, the former minister emphatically stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition promised to scrub the New Schools Policy which places some sensible restraints on the growth of the non-government school sector.
He went on to say:

The Government has an understandable pride of ownership in major achievements . . . The strength of that pride is reflected in the strength of our concern when such achievements are so obviously threatened.

According to the former minister, the coalition's policies would threaten the school system, `facing a threat to its quality and equitable funding base'. Let all members of this chamber be very clear on the government's position on the new schools policy. To abolish this policy would be to adopt—and I again quote from a press release by the former minister—`out of date and unworkable education policies'. So wedded is the government to its policy, so proud is the government of its stranglehold over non-government sector that in this very chamber on 7 October 1992 the minister stated:
We will not—
and I repeat `not'—
abandon the propositions that we have in place under the new schools policy proposal.

How things have changed. The government has now buckled under the pressure of the opposition and the non-government sector, especially the Christian schools, with the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) announcing on the first of this month a review of the shameful policy.

PARA.TAB: I read with great interest his press release on this issue, which will go down in the non-government school sector as one of the great opportunistic policy reversals in living memory. The press release announced the view, and in doing so, gave the most spurious of reasons for the policy backflip and that is, `that the environment in which schools operate has changed'. And the evidence for this? According to the minister, it is the expanded use of computers and increased retention rates. How this in any way can be used as justification for the review will be lost on the non-government sector.It is a proposition that totally lacks any credibility. What the press release should have stated was:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government has decided to review the way new, non-government schools are assessed for Commonwealth funding.
I will give the minister a copy of this so that he can put it out this afternoon. It goes on:
Since the new schools policy was introduced in 1986 the Government has been attacked by the Opposition and the non-government sector—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you checked the spelling?

—I will have a chat to you about some of your press releases in that regard too. I can tell you that you now have a system on your computer where you can run it through, and I am sure that we will not see mistakes like those that I picked up the other day, using that new system. We might both be better off as a result of it. I suspect that there may well be other members of this House who will get great benefit from the grammar check on that system. This is the minister's press release that he is going to put out this afternoon. It further states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . for continuing to have a policy setting which is anti the establishment of new non-government schools. In his explanation for the reason for the backflip, the minister said, "Well, in all honesty I've been getting so much pressure from the Opposition and non-government sector, especially those in the Christian education sector, that I thought it unwise to go to the next election without having said something that might try to placate them.
The last paragraph of that press release should read:
The minister went on to say that he had asked for the review to be finalised in March 1996, which in all likelihood, meant that he would not be required to make a decision before the next election.

Put in its simplest terms, the terms of reference of the review make a mockery of the bill. The bill and the direction it takes in relation to the new schools policy only seek to re-enforce the wide-held belief that the latest review smacks of no more than political expediency.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—You agree with that. This review should be seen in the context of the bigger picture and that is the utter hypocrisy of the government that is trying to curry favour with a group whose opposition to the government is mounting while at the same time instructing the various government departments to look at ways to slash funding to the non-government sector.

PARA.TAB: I am sure the minister saw press comments some months ago about proposed cuts to the education sector and would be aware that if they were to come into place it would totally decimate Australia's non-government sector. I must admit that I really am very surprised that the minister did not move to in any way cut short the debate on this. There was no denial from him. Nothing at all came out which would indicate that he either supported or denied those mooted cost cuttings.

The question that must be asked, given his silence, is whether he is indicating support for the proposed measures. Equally importantly, may they become a budget reality as opposed to a departmental review? The other matter of great concern to the school sector is the government's constant about face and buck passing in relation to various matters of great concern to the school sector. I vividly remember holding the government to account for the drastic decline in retention rates, only to be told by the minister in a press release of 30 January 1995:

SPEECH.PARA: The Member for Ballarat criticises the Federal Government because retention rates were down in the past year. But it is the states which have responsibility for running schools.
The minister seems to forget that on 30 May 1993 in this chamber, when talking about retention rates, Minister Beazley stated :
. . . is a reflection of the extraordinary extent to which this government has been prepared to invest in the development of our higher education system.

On 4 June 1994, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) boasted to this House, `Of course we have now increased retention rates in schools to nearly 80 per cent.' However, the most glaring statement to this House which makes crystal clear the extent of the minister's duplicity was made on 8 November 1994. He said:
Everybody knows that this government's policies have achieved an absolute revolution in school retention rates.

It appears that everyone knows who is responsible for the retention rates except you or, should I say, only when it is convenient for you to know. The minister is trying to emulate the feats of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) whose selective memory is legend not only in this House but also in the state of Western Australia. Let us be in no doubt that through the review of the new schools policy, and the possible slashing of funds to the non-government sector, we are seeing the government establish a framework to avoid taking responsibility for the non-government sector. This is Labor's true commitment to the non-government school sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk to them about the $10 million cuts in Fightback.

—If that is the best contribution you have to make to this House, I suggest to you that you go away and get another job. That is old hat; and if that is your only contribution you will be judged accordingly. Make a sensible contribution to this debate or pull your head in.
—I think the parliamentary secretary might let it go.

—I note with interest that this bill also proposes $8.7 million to be provided in 1995 to foster literacy development for children in the early years of schooling. The coalition supports this measure and we believe it is long overdue. However, Australian parents have every cause to be doubtful as to how well this initiative will work once implemented. After all, the government's record on literacy is one of distortion of the truth, and a never-ending stream of go nowhere funding with no result.

PARA.TAB: I would like to place on record the initiatives we have had to date from Labor over 12 years in office. We have had the International Literacy Year 1990; the literacy challenge, strategies for early intervention for literacy and learning for Australian children, December 1992; International Literacy Day on 8 September 1990; early literacy programs; adult literacy programs; the 1991 Australian language and literacy policy; the `Book it' program of 1990; and the literacy awards in 1992—and the government is currently administering a national literacy survey. Not only is the minister, in his own words, not sure of the end result of these past efforts on the state of our literacy, but up to 25 per cent of Australian school children are battling literacy problems. What is needed is accountability and testing of basic skills. States such as Victoria and New South Wales are showing much needed leadership in this area. If the government were serious about improving these figures, it would tell its left wing union teacher mates to back off and allow such testing to continue.

I mentioned the minister's position on the issue of accountability, especially given the fact that the Commonwealth invested over $3 billion into this sector. I wonder whether the minister agrees with the editorial in the Age this week. I am sure the minister is acutely aware of the fact that the Age is not necessarily a great supporter of the state government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does Kennett call it?
—I suspect he would probably call it not a bad rag if he read this Age editorial.

SPEECH.PARA: It is hard to see why teachers oppose the formal testing of the basic competence of eight and 10-year-old children in Victorian schools. If the tests reveal problems, surely that will be valuable information for teachers, parents and schools as they work to enable all children to reach their full potential. Surely this should be the aim of education; not to treat every child as if they have the same potential or can achieve the same outcome.

PARA.TAB: Every child should have the opportunity to become fully literate and numerate and those who do not reach acceptable standards should have the right to assistance. Some studies indicate that educational standards are declining and that as many as 25 per cent of children now leave primary school with inadequate literacy and numeracy skills.

SPEECH.PARA: The article goes on to talk about who should be receiving this information. I support the view of the Age that indeed it is something that should be between the school and parents. I would not like to see any system where children themselves are put at risk through being handed documentation about their basic literacy skills.

PARA.TAB: But surely the question of testing is not something that this minister or this government should be opposed to. I would have thought it was basic to ascertain whether there are problems and, if there are problems, then you can address them. The only way they can be addressed, if you do not avoid the problems, I suspect will come out in the truancy inquiry. The minister knows that I am a member of that committee, and I suspect that he and I will be fairly horrified at its outcomes.

I support the move to find out the levels of truancy because, until we find out what they are and ascertain some of the reasons, we will not be able to address what is a continuing and growing community problem. I think we will probably find, and indeed there seems to be plenty of evidence to support this, that basic literacy problems lead to truancy problems. So I draw the attention of the minister to that Age editorial as I think it really sums up the position we have.

The concern is that the lowest common denominator has become the benchmark in Australia's education system as a direct result of the lack of testing. Labor is now torn between its union mates and the figures which show that little has been achieved by listening to them in the past. The time has come for some accountability in the education system, but this will not happen under the present government.

I have been informed that one of the reasons for the delay with this bill is the issue of supplementation. I have been informed that, although supplementation of recurrent grants is usually paid at the end of the schooling year, this was not the case in 1994. The reason, it would appear, was that the unexpectedly high amount of supplementation caused the minister to give long consideration to whether he would fulfil the government's commitment to supplementation in line with movements in the AGSRC. However, the government will now be paying supplementation.

I would like to quote from the February edition of the Australian Parents Council Review. I am sure when the seconder to the motion arrives he will be extremely anxious to support the comments that I will make in relation to this matter. I am sure the imminent arrival of the seconder will make that task considerably easier. It is good to see the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) here; I know he has great concerns about education in his electorate as well. I can now go on to quote from the Australian Parents Council Review with renewed vigour:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it says that it will be doing so on the basis that "it would be inappropriate to provide any further funding for schooling in 1995 beyond the existing programs".

The supplementation amount, the Government says, will serve to meet the Commonwealth Government's share of any additional costs to school and system authorities to cover the Australian Vocational Training System and will also offset demands for any extra funding the non-government schooling sector makes for superannuation, special education and capital needs.

The Commonwealth Government says that the 5.1% supplementation outcome is particularly high when compared with, for example, a Consumer Price Index . . . In the light of this, the Commonwealth Government states that it will be revising the components of the AGSRC.

In a letter dated 25th January 1995 to the Australian Parents Council (APC) in response to APC requests that the Commonwealth Government honour its supplementation policy. Special Minister of State, Gary Johns says with regard to the review of the AGSRC:

"In particular the Government believes that those components such as teacher redundancy payments should be excluded from the index in future to more accurately reflect the normal annual costs of running government schools. A revised index is under consideration. In the meantime supplementary payments for schools for 1994 will be paid as soon as possible."
What is the council's response to this attempt by the government to push them into a corner? I again quote from the A.P.C. Review:
No doubt non-government school authorities and organisations will be vitally concerned with this and any other proposed outcome of revision of the AGSRC.

Given past assurances to these organisations by various government ministers, especially prior to the last election, the non-government sector has every reason to be concerned at the broken promises which this government is notorious for.

PARA.TAB: The concerns we have with this bill have been shown to be legitimate to the extent that, even the minister acknowledges the new schools policy—which this bill serves to further restrict—needs further review. Had the government the courage to listen to the opposition in the first place and abandon this obnoxious policy, the sector would not be in the chaos it is in today.

What we have witnessed in this House would almost be comical if it were not so serious. We have a piece of legislation which is virtually unravelling as we speak. We have a minister who is at odds with his predecessor and with his party's policies. In all this, we also have the non-government school sector looking for nothing more than security and a commitment to honour past promises. This is not how it should be and this is not how it will be under a coalition government.

Before I finish, when the minister stands up today I would like him to give this House and, indeed, the non-government schools—especially those with a vital interest in the new schools area—an undertaking that this review will be completed by September. There is no reason why that cannot be done. A discussion paper is due to be released in July. We are now getting to a time frame of March 1996. I think the minister can see that this is an extremely serious matter concerning not only the coalition but also the non-government sector.

There is an extraordinary amount of cynicism, especially in the Christian schools, as to why a discussion paper can be released by July but the review can be put off until March 1996. There can be only two reasons for this: it is either a political stunt during the election campaign or the fervent hope of the minister that the matter will go well past the next election and he will go into the next election saying, `Well, I can't do anything until the review of the new schools policy is released.'

When we go into the next election campaign, the coalition will give a very firm commitment that this policy will be abolished. That has been our firm policy position for some time. It has been constantly reiterated. Our policy will satisfy growing community concern, especially amongst the Christian schools sector, about the total inappropriateness of this government's policy, which has been an unmitigated disaster since it was introduced.

This review is no more than the minister trying to placate a rapidly growing sector; a sector that has been urging him personally for some time to address what it sees as gross inequity in the non-government schools sector. That is his challenge. I would like to hear whether he is going to take it up.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment, and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening closely to the member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson), and I say to him at the outset that I, along with other government members, refute totally the suggestion that the ALP is in any way philosophically opposed to non-government school education. I think the member for Ballarat, along with many of his colleagues, has lapsed in time back to the lacklustre days of Menzies when the state aid debate raged through this parliament.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the history of government funding for non-government schools brings enormous credit to the Australian Labor Party. Funding of non-government schools in this country was first proposed by a Labor government in New South Wales in the early 1960s—a Labor government in the early sixties wanting to fund, for the first time, non-government schools. To this proposition Menzies responded, typically as a political opportunist, with a limited proposal for the federal funding of non-government schools and their science blocks. The truth of the matter is that substantial federal funding of those schools did not come into place until the election of the Whitlam Labor government in 1972 and establishment of the Australian Schools Commission in 1973.

I provide the member for Ballarat with some of the background. The national government has been providing funding for specific purposes for schools in Australia since 1964—that limited Menzies proposition. Since that time, both the scope and size of Commonwealth outlays for schooling have increased substantially. Expenditure on school education through the various states grants acts has grown from $9.9 million in 1964-65—that is, less than $10 million after 15 years of Menzies Liberal government. The member for Ballarat should note that. He talked about truancy. He must have been playing truant when it came to Australian political history lessons during his time at school.

The grants and aid grew from less than $10 million during the period of Menzies to outlays in 1994 of over $1 billion for government schools and $1,563 million for non-government schools—$1.5 billion of Commonwealth assistance for non-government schools established and confirmed by this Labor government. For the member for Ballarat to suggest that there is any philosophical opposition to non-government school education on the part of the Keating government is an absurdity. I am sure that the member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott), a strong supporter of non-government and government schools throughout the country and his own electorate, would agree that the schools would all say, `If that is the philosophical opposition of the Australian Labor Party in 1994-95—$1.5 billion of funding for non-government schools—let's have more of it.'

It is an absurdity for the member for Ballarat to base his whole argument on a question of philosophical opposition by the ALP to non-government schools. He has lapsed comfortably back from his perspective to the lacklustre era of Menzies and that redundant state aid debate.

On the substance of this legislation, its purpose is essentially threefold: to require greater notice of proposals to establish new non-government schools which seek government funding or alter the status of non-government schools receiving government funding; to introduce procedures for situations where additional levels of education are introduced progressively at a particular school; and to establish a list of priority languages for which Commonwealth grants shall be paid. I support these purposes entirely, but I also wish to make some broader observations about the effectiveness of the nation's school education system. I do so against a background of rapid change in teaching and the learning environment in Australia's schools.

During my lifetime, and it is an experience which I am sure has been shared by the member for Parramatta, there have been two great changes in the school education system. The first is, as I have mentioned, Commonwealth involvement—substantial Commonwealth funding of both the government and non-government school sectors. Unfortunately, this has not led to the creation of a national system. We have had enormous growth in national funding, but we are yet to establish a national school education system in Australia. We are still relying on eight state and territory based systems. There are obvious problems such as a lack of coordination, a lack of efficiency, a lack of integration and the tremendous difficulties that arise with students who, because of their parents moving across territorial and state boundaries, move into new education systems with different standards, different curricula and different requirements.

The second change in school education during my lifetime has been the convergence of general and vocational education. Schools have become much more concerned, particularly in the past decade, with the question of employability and the provision of broad vocational education. This represents a convergence not only of general and vocational education in schools but also a convergence between the concept of work and the concept of education.

It is now recognised that the most successful forms of work organisation are those which encourage people to be multiskilled, creative and adaptable. In this sense, the quality of Australia's school education system has become a key determinant of competitive advantages and disadvantages for the national economy.

With the proliferation and pace of international capital movements, human resources and skills have become the primary means by which national economies compete against each other. All other factor markets—resources, capital formation and technological progress—have jumped over and well beyond national boundaries, particularly with the development of knowledge-based industries.

In the 1950s and 1960s in Australia young people looked forward to employment once they, through the school education system, had acquired relatively simple and repetitious skills. This was because our economy was organised around systems of high-volume, standardised production. Whether in agriculture, manufacturing or office work, each employee took a simple but interconnected part in the production process through which productivity was guaranteed by high volumes and low unit costs.

Skill requirements for adaptability and innovation were restricted to a small group of managers who planned and designed the production process. Most workers simply followed orders within the limits of rigid work roles and job classifications. If they did this with due discipline and tolerance, then their working life would most likely require just one set of simple trade based skills.

In the 1970s and 1980s, however, this mechanistic production process was transformed by the advent of knowledge-based technology. This has flattened the old production hierarchy and given workers a much better chance to contribute innovations and ideas to the production process. A successful working life in the 1990s requires a range of adaptable skills, with a lifetime commitment to training and retraining, multiskilling and reskilling.

These changes have also been a function of Australia's new trading position. Following the elimination of old protectionist policies and tariff walls, it would have been much harder for Australia to compete against cheap labour nations if the competitive environment still relied on high volume-low cost, standardised methods of production.

Our only feasible option has been to compete not on the basis of the cost of labour but through the value of labour—the capacity of Australian workers to add value, quality, flexibility and ideas to the production process. By this strategy we produce not only more interesting work in Australia, not only more cooperative and successful workplaces but, most importantly, we preserve the integrity of our national values and aspirations for a high wage-high employment economy.

I take inspiration and guidance from the policies outlined by the US Labour Secretary, Robert Reich, in his 1989 book, The resurgent liberal. Of course, he is talking about small `l' liberals. There is nothing resurgent about the big `L' Liberals in this place. Reich, nonetheless, states in his book from 1989:

SPEECH.PARA: for managers this path means continuously retraining employees for more complex tasks, automating in ways that cut routine tasks and enhance worker flexibility and creativity, diffusing responsibility for innovation, taking seriously labour's concern for job security and giving the workers a stake in improved productivity via profit-linked bonuses and stock plans. For workers this means accepting flexible job classifications and work rules, agreeing to wage rates linked to productivity improvements, and generally taking greater responsibility for the soundness and efficiency of the enterprise.

Reich goes on to outline how such an economy relies, above all, on a work force capable of rapid learning. The key transformation is how policy makers in this area, including the member for Ballarat, should be linking changes in the nature of work to changes in the school education system. Reich has this to say:

Because the future economy will depend to an even greater extent on thinking, rather than repeating learned information, future reforms must motivate teachers and students alike to engage in the process of learning. Rather than prescribe exactly what should be learned and how and when the information should be doled out, reformers should aim at improving students' capacity to learn . . . . rather than teach students to assume that problems and solutions are generated by others (as they were under high-volume standardised production), students should be led to understand that problems and questions are created . . . . the emphasis should be on allowing students to experiment for themselves with solving the problems they help define.

One could not find a better statement of the challenge for educators and education policy makers in the 1990s—to have teachers who engage students in the process of learning. I think that matches the experience that members of parliament would have had in their own school years.

PARA.TAB: Studies have found that few people remember any amount of the content they were taught at school. The lasting significance of the school education system is to pick up a certain way of learning, a certain way of thinking. That is a very important point to understand. It is not so much the content that people take away from school, not so much the rote learning and knowledge; it is a process of learning, a way of thinking. If we use this commonsense proposition—something that happens in any case in the school education system—we can certainly produce schooling in Australia in the 1990s better suited to the new nature of work and changes in employment.

The link between school education and employment is still, by my assessment, underestimated in the public debate. Our emphasis in this parliament and through government policy in recent years has been on post-school training and retraining—such as the Working Nation program implemented by DEET. This, unfortunately, by my assessment has left the school education system and its contribution to training and work force skills as a second order consideration. It should not be so. It should be a first order consideration.

In Australia, the comprehensive system has focused on minimum standards across the nation without linkages to regional economic development. Even so, fast growing regions have been under-resourced in education through the recent period of spending restraint. Yet these are the areas that require the greatest boost to human skills. As Gregory and Hunter concluded from their study of the spatial structure of the labour market:

SPEECH.PARA: The structural change of Australian employment into less manual work in the service sector has favoured those workers in the good regions with more education. The workers in the low status areas have largely failed to secure employment in the growth industries and appear to move into the unemployment pool once they lose their jobs in manufacturing.

This highlights a failure to match the school education system to the economic restructuring process still under way in Australia. The process of restructuring has changed the nature and the definitions we apply to work force skills. In the 1950s and 1960s it was assumed that white-collar work was relatively high skilled and that blue-collar work would be relatively low skilled. Now, with an internationalised economy in the 1990s, there is an entirely different definition of skills and their requirements in employment.

PARA.TAB: It is the traded sector, the sector exposed to international competition, that requires the highest level of skills, be that in white- or blue-collar work. Close to my electorate, I recall an inspection of the Alcatel factory where the workers were producing telephone switching equipment for a large market in China. They were not wearing blue overalls but white lab coats. This reflects how the manufacturing work environment now requires an intensely capable level of education and skill development.

It is the non-traded sector that is more likely to have the relatively low skill base. This refers to those sectors of the economy, such as community services and the retail sector, that are not exposed to international competition and not part of any internationalised production process. This demonstrates some of the problems that have occurred in making the transformation, the adjustment, in skills and job opportunities.

Unhappily, there has been a concentration of unemployment in a group of regional economies. Poverty rates have become a problem. Welfare dependency has become a problem. In fact, the correlation between public housing, poverty rates and unemployment is strong, based on location. My colleague the member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) has said that you can predict someone's employment and lifetime aspirations based on their postcode. Unfortunately, with unemployment and rates of poverty, that has become a reality on a regional scale.

It is important to rethink the training agenda and understand that the school education system can potentially play a strong role in making young people job ready. While the government is justly proud of the huge rise in school retention rates since 1983, these figures say nothing about the quality and suitability of education for students who would otherwise have left school after years 9 or 10.

There is a strong correlation between students who respond poorly to an academic style school curriculum and long-term unemployment. Education policies need to address the needs of young people who disconnect themselves from the academic learning environment. The limited data available to the green paper on long-term unemployment in 1993 year suggested that between 10 and 20 per cent of students require special assistance to enhance basic literacy skills. This problem is particularly acute in disadvantaged regions, reflected ultimately in higher rates of long-term unemployment.

The government's substantial investment in DEET training programs for the young long-term unemployed—especially those dealing with personal development skills—is in many ways correcting problems which arose at a much younger age in the school education system. The cost effectiveness of government outlays—federal and state—would be substantially improved by addressing the needs of these students at years 9 and 10.

I welcome the initiative in Working Nation to progress vocational based education, a vocational based curriculum and work experience for years 11 and 12 through the Australian student traineeship system. Along with the honourable member for Bourke (Mr O'Keefe), who has written a discussion paper on this subject, I urge the government to extend the Australian student traineeships into years 9 and 10.

Compared with other OECD nations, Australia has a low participation rate of its 15- to 18-year-olds in vocational education. We need to turn that around. We turn it around by applying work experience and vocation based training not only in years 11 and 12, but also years 9 and 10. The education system in this country has traditionally been seen as a source of meritocracy; the great equality of opportunity and great liberator of the disadvantaged. This was true during the period of full employment in Australia, but it is a more difficult proposition to sustain when the country has less than full employment; especially when, with the greater emphasis on labour force skills, access to employment depends, firstly, on how well someone performs within the school education system and, secondly, where someone lives—his or her post code.

We need to reassess the role school education can play in the internationalised economic environment, and particularly how to best improve the regional economic opportunities. I briefly outline four reforms worthy of consideration by policy makers.

The first proposition is to end the dominance of universities in setting the school curriculum. Unlike other OECD nations, industry and vocational considerations have little input in Australia. The tertiary entrance score and rank is designed for entry into university, not for work force entrance. There needs to be a shift from this 1960s model where the smarter kids go on to university and the rest get a job in the full employment labour market. That is no longer the environment in the 1990s. There needs to be greater input from business people, industry leaders and those interested in vocational training to ensure the entrance score and rank in year 12 is based as much around vocational work force needs as for tertiary education.

My second proposition is to end the dichotomy between general and vocational education. I refer honourable members to the outstanding report in December last year by the Schools Council entitled The role of schools in the vocational preparation of Australia's senior secondary students. That report outlines the way in which an integrated system can be developed in Australia to ensure that not only our academic standards—literacy and numeracy—are sound, but also that schools provide the best opportunity for vocational training.

My third proposition is to rethink the way in which the disadvantaged schools program is run, to try to adapt to new opportunities for parental training and parental involvement in the education system, particularly in disadvantaged areas, and to use the new technology on the so-called information superhighway. My fourth proposition is to change the nature of teacher training so that it adapts to the new economic environment. Again I refer members to page 78 of the Schools Council report. They are the four propositions. I look forward to elaborating on each of these propositions in greater depth on another occasion as the government continues its outstanding record on school education. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 today I think some overview should be taken of the situation in education today. If we had suggested 50 or 100 years ago that from now on half of our lifetime—20 or 30 years—should be taken up with training in the work force and that people of 26 years of age would still be in a training mode and be unable to move out into the real world, people would think that there was something wrong with us intellectually or psychologically.

PARA.TAB: Today we have reached not only that place in our development but, with very deep regret, a worse aspect of the education system where, if we had suggested 100 years ago to people that from now on the only way they can become a doctor is if they are born to be a doctor, you are put through a series of tests—some would argue that they are aptitude tests, but whatever the case may be; they change the grading system in Queensland every three years on some sort of mythical basis that it is not going to remove the competitiveness, but in my experience it only makes the competitiveness greater—and if you are not able to achieve a score of 995 then you will not become a doctor.

There are a lot of caring and intelligent people who would be absolutely wonderful doctors. It was rather intriguing that the college at the University of Queensland, which I had the great honour of being president of when I was there, introduced a system where we elected a resident doctor, a resident lawyer and a resident expert in each field so that anyone in the college who had a legal problem could go along to the resident lawyer and get advice, and similarly with the resident doctor. The resident experts were people in their last year or two years of their course or who may have been tutoring in their profession.

The bloke who was elected from our college as the resident doctor was not the brightest fellow. I think he stumbled and fell about three or four times, but he predated the system whereby you had to be amongst the top 100 or 200 achievers in the matriculation examinations and managed to get into medical college.

He was elected two years in a row, despite having failed three years of the course, to my memory, because the people did not want an Albert Einstein looking after them. They wanted someone who cared about them and someone who, if he did not have the knowledge, would have the humility to go to someone who did have the knowledge to find out what needed to be done to fix them up. When the students were given the choice of whom they wanted, even people that had come out of the apex, if you like, of the academic system of the colleges at Queensland University—you had to have a very high mark to get in there in the first place—they did not opt for the academic achiever; they opted for the carer. But no longer in the state of Queensland—and I am quite confident in every other state in Australia—is that available to society.

When I had a number of high school students over in their final year for lunch I asked, `Are you happy with the system?' One student—one of this kid's forebears was of Aboriginal descent and his parents were not wealthy; they had very humble, low income jobs—said, `No, I am not happy with the system at all because I would like to be an engineer and I have no hope of ever becoming an engineer.' I asked him, `Why? Explain that to me.' He said, `Because, under subjective assessment, I have got a teacher who does not like me.' I asked if he could prove that, and he said, `Yes, as a matter of fact, I can. I have been scoring 3 1/2 out of seven in my essays in English. I put the same essay I scored 3 1/2 on to the new teacher who came three weeks ago and she gave me a six. Other teachers who looked at this have said, "Yes, you should be getting a six." Unfortunately, I had a blue with her and she has taken it out on me, and that's my fate. But I am prepared to do whatever work is necessary to achieve the results I need to become an engineer.'

The end of the story is that the kid did not get the marks to become an engineer—he was too low in English—so he went off and got an apprenticeship. He topped the apprenticeships in the state two years in a row. He was given a pass conceded at James Cook University, went through his university course with distinctions and is now holding a very prominent job as an engineer in Sydney.

I tell that story to indicate that not only are we put through an objective assessment which grades us in some Brave New World or Nineteen Eighty-four reality that has come upon society—and no matter how much you want to go into a particular field that is cut off to you—but also our children are cast to the tender mercies of some enormously petty-minded school teachers who, for some personal vendetta reasons, may completely, or do their best to, destroy their entire future.

In days past, we had on-the-job training. People were not sent off to an elite institution. Having gone through the University of Queensland, I know it is very hard to go to a university, particularly that type of university, and not come out thinking that you are a great gift to humanity. In his book, Trevor Sykes delineates the terrible occurrences of the 1980s, with the loss of $28,000 million in this country.

I spoke with a very successful businessman in North Queensland who told me that he was the youngest ever credit manager for the Bank of New South Wales in Queensland—Westpac, as it is now called. I asked him why he got out of banking and he told me it was because he could see the disasters coming. I thought he meant those in the 1980s and he said, `No, that wasn't quite what I meant. That was a manifestation of the disasters.' So I asked him what he was referring to and he said, `As a kid, you started working in a bank as a clerk. Typically, you were sent out to a western town where you were forced to play football with the local yokels. Rich, poor, black or white—you were all cast into the same football team. You perhaps belonged to the local Apex club, and you knew everybody in your community. You also knew their bank accounts: who was paying up, who was reliable and who wasn't.'

He continued by saying, `Then you rose to be a teller and probably joined Lions, Rotary or something like that. You had a very intimate knowledge of and a responsibility to oversight their accounts. When you became manager your toes were cut off with a rusty razor blade if you failed to make the right decisions about people. But you learnt and understood people, which was by far the most important thing in banking.' I then asked him what the disaster was that befell banking in Australia and he said, `All of those positions that I occupied were cut of completely.'

TALK.START.PARA: —It's got nothing to do with bill.

—We have only one debate in this place—unlike the two we used to have in the state House in Queensland—because it is a wide ranging debate in the first place. We also do not have the opportunities to speak very often on issues that are very relevant to, for example, the field of education, but I will move on.

PARA.TAB: The businessman then told me that in Queensland through the 1980s all of those positions were made available only to the bright young MBAs coming out of the universities—interestingly enough, a lot of them foreign universities. He said that a Harvard MBA almost guaranteed you a senior position in the Bank of New South Wales or the National Bank. He said, `Can you imagine one of those bright young elitist "gifts to the world" being taken to dinner in a Rolls Royce by the likes of tough, rough nuts like Alan Bond? Do you really think he would have had the temerity to raise the issue of security value at the lunch? Not likely! It would have been naive for a person of his stature to talk of such a petty matter. He would have had no understanding of human nature to go with it. That led to what happened in the 1980s.' I think he made a very interesting statement.

Another very important issue needs to be canvassed. I sat down on one occasion and went through what I thought were the 23 major technological breakthroughs in the last hundred years. With one exception, which was radio, the other 22 major breakthroughs—whether they were television, the electric light, the telephone, the motor car, the internal combustion engine, refrigeration, the polarisation of light or photography—were achieved by people who had no tertiary qualifications. Isn't that interesting? A lot of people in argument to that would say that in the old days a lot of people did not have tertiary qualifications. I expect that argument, but the instamatic camera and the polarisation of light were pretty recent inventions of Edwin Land. The jet engine, which was effectively invented in the last year or two of the Second World War, was another invention by a person without tertiary qualifications.

A lot of commentators on these issues say, `What you have here is an assessment on the basis of your ability to memorise and regurgitate the conventional wisdom. A person that is very good at absorbing the conventional wisdom and accepting it without questioning is a person that will be very good at the examination system.' Edward De Bono would say that he is an absolutely hopeless ass when it comes to formulating something new. As one person put to me recently, `The last thing in the world we want is someone on steel rails. We want a four-wheel drive operator.' He was talking about a mental four-wheel drive operator; a person able to see the opportunities and move in any particular direction.

I think there is a very important part to be played by universities with regard to these matters—that is, as libraries, sets of living encyclopedias and marketplaces for information. They should be right there with the runners—the Edisons, Ottos, Alexander Bells and all of their modern equivalents—understanding those breakthroughs, stepping side by side with those breakthroughs and being able to provide that information to the wider community upon request. I do not want to denigrate steel rail thinkers. We need steel rail thinkers, technocrats and people to man the magnificent achievements of some of the people responsible for the great breakthroughs.

It impossible not to go sideways for a second and reflect upon that most incredible person, Henry Ford. Every single year for the 22 years that Henry Ford produced his famous motor car, the model T Ford, the price went down, not up. For 22 years, every single year, that car got cheaper and cheaper. As many model T Fords were sold as all the cars sold in the rest of the world put together. Here was a person who had built the motor car. I think other people could claim to have built the motor car but, if we had to look to someone who was the most successful inventor of the motor car, we would look no further than him. Again, he was a man with no tertiary qualifications.

The Ford group decided that the Europeans were well ahead of them. They were winning all the motor car races and Ford had to find out why. They found out that the metal alloys being used were vastly superior. So the Ford group, which at the time was probably the biggest and most successful company in the world, monetary wise, searched the world for the best metallurgist they could find. They found him, after searching the world, in the Ford factory: it was a kid who had been paid to sweep. He was shoved over to be a worker in metallurgy and rose to be the head of the metallurgy section. He was the person that knew most about metallurgy in the whole world. They had the money to buy the best. They had the money to search the world for the best and the best was already there. He was self-taught, self-trained and he had all of the knowledge of anyone else in the world.

That great raconteur, Malcolm Muggeridge, said that modern education is very much like the giant armadillo of prehistoric times. With every successive wave of evolution, the giant armadillo clothed itself in more and more armour plating until, eventually, it was invulnerable from attack from any other animal that walked the earth. It was a great evolutionary achievement. However, there was one problem. The armour was so heavy the armadillo could not forage for food and it very rapidly became extinct. There are no giant armadillos today.

The most important thing I have to say today is that, sadly, without an education almost every door is closed. In society today, with the crushing of the agricultural sector in Australia by this government and other governments—I do not hesitate to say that—and the crushing of small business, all doors are now closed. The corporations own everything. The corporations will own everything so, if you cannot get a job with a corporation or the government—you most certainly cannot get jobs with them without degrees or tertiary qualifications—every door of opportunity is closed.

Nowadays, not only do people living outside the cities and very large towns not have a right to tertiary education but also they do not have a right to secondary education. Areas I represent in North Queensland, such as Feluga, Normanton, Georgetown, Burketown, Richmond and Julia Creek—and, sadly, soon probably towns like Winton—will be left without secondary education. Recently, the Julia Creek school lost all of its secondary department. The only way people in these areas can secure an education is to go away to boarding school. There is no other way it can be done. It is ludicrous to say that people can gain a secondary education by correspondence. There is too much competitiveness out there, and figures clearly indicate that that is the case. Very few even try. There is no secondary education in those sorts of areas unless you can go away to boarding school.

When I was a young person, unless you were rich you could not go to boarding school. By Cloncurry standards, I was lucky enough to belong to a rich family and was able to go away to school. Later on, if you were of Aboriginal descent, you could go to boarding school. I can remember being embarrassed that I had this great advantage over 80 per cent of the kids in Cloncurry. I could go as far as I wanted to because I had a secondary education and they did not. Kids from boarding schools walked with pride. They had been out in the bigger world and tried themselves against bigger people. They had this thing called education, which they could intimidate everybody else with for the rest of their days. It was very sad. I can remember the embarrassment I felt during those years.

I was lucky enough to be in a government which pioneered in Australia equality of education, so education in Queensland was provided on an equal basis for every single person. Through the 1970s and 1980s, the entire cost of going away to boarding school was picked up by the state and federal governments. Because of the inaction of this House, and because of the inaction of the Queensland government, now only half the cost of sending children away to boarding school is covered. I am not talking about elitist GPS schools, as we call them in Queensland; I am talking about ordinary garden variety service schools, which are the sorts of schools I boarded at in Charters Towers. They believe they have a duty to provide something the kids must have, which is a secondary education at the cheapest possible cost.

But, even with those schools, you are still looking at a shortfall of about $6,000. If you have two or three kids and come from a town such as Hughenden, where the cost of living is 26 per cent higher than Brisbane—I am quoting specifically from two separate reports—there is no way in the world you can afford to send your kids away to school. It is impossible. We are now back to the bad old days where education is available only—I am not talking about tertiary education; I am talking about secondary education—to the rich or those of Aboriginal descent, whose numbers are much smaller. This is a dreadful indictment upon this government and other governments of Australia, and must be fixed up. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always entertaining to listen to the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter). He gives us the opportunity to have a wide-ranging debate, and some of the points he raised were rather interesting from a Queenslander's point of view. We can see why the people of Queensland woke up to themselves back in 1989 and replaced the National Party government with the Goss Labor government, which has a very strong commitment to social justice and education for our young people. The member for Kennedy was a minister in the Bjelke-Petersen government, and we should remind this place of that bad era in Queensland.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The speaker is casting personal aspersions upon me and I request that he withdraw those remarks which are offensive to me.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will move on and talk about the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994, but I could not help but take the opportunity presented to me to make those comments. I am pleased to have the opportunity to support this bill, which amends the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992. The changes this bill will introduce will enable the government to provide additional funding to enhance early literacy development, and the important task of providing education in 10 priority languages. I will come to that area later, particularly in relation to Aboriginal languages. I was a member of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs in 1992, which looked into Aboriginal languages, and I will refer to that report later. A lot of things are pertinent to what we are speaking about today.

PARA.TAB: I should begin by saying that there are few more important tasks than the one Australia's 220,000 teachers carry out every day of their working lives—it is important to acknowledge the work of the educators of our children—namely, educating our children and helping them become responsible citizens not only in this country but in the whole world. There are few jobs that would be more challenging and ultimately more rewarding. I understand that the Australian Teaching Council is attempting to have International Teachers Day acknowledged and celebrated every year. I wish them well in that pursuit.

This bill will give effect to the initiatives announced in the 1994-95 budget, including the provision of $8.7 million in 1995 to foster literacy development for children in the early years of schooling, and the provision of $4 million in 1995 to provide grants to school authorities to support the study of 10 priority languages. This program will replace an existing one which supports eight languages in each state and territory. The bill also gives effect to changes to strengthen the Commonwealth's new schools policy from the new and changing non-government schools, changes to simplify administrative arrangements for improving block grant authorities under the capital grants program for schools, and funding schedules for capital grants for government and non-government schools for 1995 and funding schedules for grants for community language for 1995.

This bill is an example of this government's commitment to education for young Australians, the country's future. It is an outstanding commitment that this government has shown over the many years it has been in office. I think we would all agree that the key to a successful future, both as individuals and as a nation, is a good education. The member for Kennedy was probably right in highlighting the need for a good education, which is available to many young people today. Australia can be justifiably proud of its record in providing a good education to our children, and the high rate of school retention to year 12—currently near the 80 per cent mark—shows that the policies of the past have been winners with young Australians. They are the policies of this government.

Young people recognise—as have several governments of the past, and as this one certainly does—that their future lies in gaining a good education, particularly one with a solid grounding in the technology that is already playing such a large part in their lives. It is also best if students can get an early start in quality education. That is one of the things that this bill proposes to do. It continues the Labor government's strong commitment both ideologically and materially to an effective schooling system.

A brief analysis of Commonwealth funding and the level of enrolments over 1988-92 clearly illustrates this commitment. In each year of that period, the percentage increase in funding actually exceeded the percentage increase in enrolments. So we could say that the federal government has had funding levels that have exceeded the growth in demand for student numbers. This is enhanced further when we consider the current figures for Commonwealth grants. For government schools in 1994 it is estimated to be $1,073 million, and non-government schools receive approximately $1,563 million.

Commonwealth grants represent approximately 12 per cent of the total spending on government schools with the rest being met by state governments while for non-government schools the Commonwealth provides approximately 37 per cent of total revenue with the remainder coming from other governments and other sources. Funding for government schools is based on yearly agreements with the states. Similar agreements are in place with non-government schools. The agreements require states and non-government schools to report annually to the Commonwealth.

Since 1985, applications for government funding for new non-government schools and existing non-government schools that wish to change their operations have been determined according to the new schools policy. Under the new schools policy, applicants are to apply for funding to a new schools committee or a joint planning and coordination committee, depending on the state or territory, two years before funding is to commence. Late applications may be accepted in special circumstances.

The committee is to determine the category in which the proposed school falls on the basis of a number of criteria such as the demographics of the school's catchment area, the planned provision of other schools in the area and the level of use of existing facilities. If the proposed school satisfies the relevant criteria it is to be given provisional approval for funding. Existing non-government schools in receipt of Commonwealth funds were required prior to 1993 to notify the relevant committee of all proposals to vary their operations. Notification was required two years before the proposed change, which had to be approved by the committee.

The rules were changed in 1993 so that some verification is allowed without assessment by a committee, although it must be notified of such changes six months before they come into effect. Variations covered by the new rules include changing from a single sex school to a co-educational school, or from a co-educational school to a single sex school; a change in status regarding whether the school is a day school, a boarding school or a combination of both; amalgamation with another funded school which does not involve a new level of education; or a relocation or separation of a school into two or more schools that do not involve a relocation. These points highlight the government's commitment to education. I am certainly very pleased to have the opportunity to reflect on them.

It is worth mentioning this when we see the number of people going on to year 12. The member for Kennedy mentioned before that, when he was growing up as a young fellow, because he came from a more affluent family he was able to get a secondary education. I come from a similar sort of background—but it was not affluent, it was on the other side of things. We did not have the opportunity to get a good secondary education. I have been very proud to see this government encourage many young people to go on to year 12. I remember how my parents struggled so I could get at least half a secondary education. That was something my parents had a very strong commitment to.

Just before Christmas two of my sons received their degrees from university. We went to the graduation ceremony in Brisbane at the University of Queensland. We looked around the room to see the number of people there and thought about the backgrounds of those people. I saw a chap there with whom I use to work in the Bank of New South Wales. He was an English migrant to this country. He had struggled for most of his life and had come to this country to make a better life. His daughter and my son received their degrees, as did the grandson of a council truck driver. There were many people like that. I looked across and saw another elderly gentleman I knew, a retired coalminer from Ipswich, in my electorate. His granddaughter was receiving her degree, too.

When we look around and see young people receiving their degrees we can be really proud of the efforts of this government. It is something we should look very seriously at. We should commend the various Labor government ministers for education we have had since 1983; they have shown a very strong commitment to education. When we see, for instance, those people receiving their degrees in the crowded hall at the University of Queensland, as I highlighted, we can really see that a lot of this government's policies are working. I commend the ministers, and I take the opportunity in this place to put on record that their efforts are really paying off.

People from all sorts of backgrounds are now receiving a good tertiary education. No longer is tertiary education available only to the rich. It is something we can all be very proud of because, at the end of the day, Australians will be much better off. Australia as a nation will be much better off through having a better educated work force. With changing technologies we must, if we are to employ our people, take advantage of every educational opportunity that is there, and I certainly encourage young people to do that.

Earlier the honourable member for Kennedy mentioned the banking sector and that he had a friend working for the Bank of New South Wales. I worked for the Bank of New South Wales, but he was not talking about me. In a sector such as banking we must have ongoing education. People need to get a better education as time goes on. As things changed in that sector, bank employees had to change as well; they had to take the opportunities to extend their own career options. I know from my own experience of that industry that when bank employees actually took the initiative and studied at night and were dedicated to improving their opportunities they did particularly well. I say, `Good on them'. They were prepared to give up their leisure time and lots of their weekends and evenings to spend studying so they could improve their lot in life, so good on them. Managing to obtain a better education has made them better people. That is progress; things move on. We have had to improve our education as we go.
