If we just sit there and say, `She'll be right, mate', adopting the old attitude of those opposite that we all saw through the 1950s and 1960s when Australians sat back and said, `She'll be right; Mother England will look after us', then we know it won't happen that way. We have to help ourselves. As the honourable member for Kennedy mentioned, people in careers such as those in the banking industry have to get out and improve their qualifications if they want to achieve. Many of them have done it: good on them. I think we should acknowledge their contributions as well because the industry will only improve in that way.

I wish to turn to some aspects of the bill regarding the priority of languages. The priority of language incentive commenced in 1992. It provides funds to increase the number of students learning a priority language other than English. This too is an important area. For those of us who have the opportunity to travel from time to time—it is one of the things that we as members of parliament get the opportunity to do—it has really brought home to us that Australians, as isolated as we are, need to have at least a second language to communicate with people in other parts of the world. If we are to be a much more forward-looking nation we have to ensure that our people can speak other languages.

Last Friday morning when I returned home to my electorate I attended a school at Redbank to hand out school badges to the young people there. I was speaking to a grade seven teacher there who came from Holland and was able to speak seven languages. Certainly when he was living in Holland he had a greater advantage as he was only a couple of kilometres away from another country which had another language, but by being able to speak seven languages he has been able to move around. He actually taught in Italy at one stage. The benefits of that sort of an education are second to none.

Just speaking to someone like that in a little school in my own electorate emphasised to me the need for another language. I could see what great benefit it was to this particular teacher. When people have much greater opportunities to travel these days, it is important for them to learn a second language. Many of those points are highlighted in this bill.

The priority languages incentive element provides funds to increase the number of students actually learning a priority language other than English. In 1992, $5.4 million was paid under the program in respect of 18,149 students, a per capita rate of $300. The principal act allows the minister to determine a list of priority languages, currently 10, and allows the relevant state minister to determine that a maximum of eight of these languages is a priority language for grants to the state. If a state minister does not determine that a language is a priority language for the state, assistance is not available in respect of students of that language.A number of languages are covered under the priority languages incentive element scheme. The languages that will be supported include Aboriginal languages, Arabic, French, German, Italian, modern Greek, Russian, Spanish, Thai and Vietnamese. That is a very important initiative.

Back in 1992 the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs tabled a report entitled Language and culture—a matter of survival, which was a report of the inquiry into Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander language maintenance. I had the privilege of chairing the subcommittee which delivered that report. Of course, the chairman of the full committee was the honourable member for Denison and now Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr). It was quite an interesting experience for all those who were involved on the inquiry. The sad state of Aboriginal languages in Australia was highlighted during the inquiry.

This bill addresses some of those issues. I welcome that initiative. I am not sure whether the minister has actually picked up any of the committee's recommendations, but certainly some of the problems that we canvassed in the report are addressed in this bill. The executive summary of that report states:
Only about one tenth of the original languages—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, Aboriginal languages—
survive today in a relatively healthy state. About a third of the original languages continue to be spoken but are under considerable threat, often being spoken by only a handful of elderly speakers.

That is pretty sad. Two hundred years ago there were probably 250 Aboriginal languages in this country; today there are only about 25. If we are going to maintain the language and culture of the Aboriginal people, we must make a greater effort to address this issue. However, I think that can be picked up in this particular bill.

PARA.TAB: The states also have a very important role to play in this process. Before coming in to speak on this bill this morning, I went through this report. We highlighted some of the problems. The report states:

The committee finds it intolerable that while most migrant children with a first language other than English have been able to study that language up to matriculation level, most Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children cannot study their language at high school. As states and territories move to make LOTE compulsory the situation is exacerbated even further. Dr Schmidt cites as an example the NSW Education Department spending $3000 in 1989 for just one student to sit a Higher School Certificate exam in Estonian.

SPEECH.PARA: I have got nothing against the Estonians. In fact, a great friend, who has since passed on, was Estonian. The report highlights:

PARA.TAB: The NSW Government advised the committee that Aboriginal language courses were not currently provided nor included in their strategic plan for Aboriginal education.

SPEECH.PARA: That is an indictment of the largest state in the Commonwealth of Australia. It actually admitted that to us. It is probably consistent with the policies of many other states—I am sure it is. The report continues:

PARA.TAB: The committee formed the view that the New South Wales Education Department, while articulating its desire to support Aboriginal languages, had no serious intention of undertaking any specific program within the next decade.

SPEECH.PARA: That is atrocious. This was in 1992, so we are looking at beyond 2000. Those sorts of problems are highlighted in that report. The minister has not picked up this report, though I am sure the department has, at the minister's guidance. I would recommend that they come back to that report and look at some of the things we had to say about the need to preserve Aboriginal languages. It will help break down a lot of those barriers between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians if we can come to understand more about the quality of their languages. That is very important, and I just wanted to take the opportunity today to highlight that. I am pleased to have had the opportunity to rise to support the bill before the House today and commend, again, the government and the relevant ministers of education for their efforts over many years.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Mr Haviland) adjourned.
Consideration resumed from 9 November 1994.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill contains amendments to the funding and disclosure provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, arising out of the government's response to the interim report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters entitled Financial reporting by political parties and out of further submissions made by the major political parties. The bill deals with changes to four aspects of the electoral funding provisions of our electoral laws. These are simplification of paper work, the method of payment of public funding entitlement to parties and candidates, an increase in that entitlement and provisions seeking to close loopholes in the disclosure provisions.

PARA.TAB: The bill provides for simplification of what the committee rightly saw as unnecessarily onerous reporting requirements for registered political parties. Parties will no longer have to report particulars of their financial transactions in the minute detail the legislation required. The recitation of this minutiae served no useful purpose in achieving the policy objectives underpinning the legislation. Those objectives are, of course, to force disclosure of donations to candidates or their parties that might appear to influence a parliamentarian or a political party's position in the parliament.

Obviously, the tens of thousands of small individual donations that are made at the time of elections do not fall into this category. The committee, in its wisdom, recommended higher thresholds before individual donations had to be included or highlighted in returns. The bill raises the threshold figure from $100 to $500 and nominates $1,500 as the sum at which donors must report and be reported. As the annual returns which political parties will be required to furnish under the proposed amendments will contain less detail than previously, the due date for furnishing them has been brought forward from 20 weeks to 16 weeks after the end of the financial year.

Consistent with the approach of simplifying procedures and avoiding unnecessary paperwork, parties will no longer be obliged to file a detailed election claim in the election year regurgitating financial information that will also be in their annual return. They will, however, have to lodge a return itemising major expenditure in respect of the election campaign. For some time now, parties have been complaining that payment of public funding has arrived long after the election. This was unavoidable in a system that required the parties to prepare highly detailed claims and lodge them and then have the AEC attend to the time consuming processing of hundreds of claims.

Neither the political parties nor the AEC are overendowed with staff and the system placed great strain on their resources. The long gap between political parties and candidates running up campaign debts and receipt of funding has led to campaign directors seeking bank overdraft accommodation against the future payment of their entitlement.

The service charges on such overdrafts could be very heavy, particularly if there were problems in processing the return. That burden will now be substantially alleviated with the AEC making an interim payment of at least 95 per cent of the entitlement on the basis of the parties known vote by the third Friday after polling day.

At that point the House of Representatives count will be complete and the Senate close to completion. If certain proposals involving the provision of a computerised counting system for the Senate are implemented it is conceivable that the Senate count will also be completed by the last day that overseas postal votes enter the count. Otherwise the final payment could be slightly delayed.

The government holds the view that the public is entitled to know what is spent on election campaigns and the bill will reinstate the arrangement prior to 1992 when parties and candidates filed a return disclosing all significant expenditure such as broadcasting, publishing, printing, display advertising and opinion polls.

SPEECH.PARA: Payments to national offices

PARA.TAB: The bill also raises the possibility of payment to national offices. Until now, payment has been made to either state branches of parties, regional parties or individual candidates. This did not take into consideration the reality that some parties were structured on a national basis and may want to fund an Australia-wide election out of their national office.

Registered parties will now be able to direct the AEC to pay their entitlement to the national office of a party. This can only be done by mutual agreement. Some state branches of parties may of course not wish to take this step.

SPEECH.PARA: Amount of funding

PARA.TAB: The bill brings the funding rate for Senate elections into line with that for the House of Representatives and increases the election funding rate to $1.50 for each formal first preference vote, indexed each six months to rises in the CPI.These changes will provide an estimated additional $14.656 million of public funding for registered political parties and entitled candidates, based on the payments made for the 1993 general election. The joint standing committee noted that it takes as much effort to win a Senate vote as one for the House of Representatives and this illogical distinction will be abolished.

The increasing emphasis on disclosure has meant that donors are far more reluctant to contribute, given that the Australian public will now be aware of their commitment. The government and the committee take the view that the increase in funding is reasonable in the circumstances and a fair price to pay for a more transparent political process.

SPEECH.PARA: Donors' returns

PARA.TAB: Donors to political parties were previously required to furnish returns following each election. This bill amends the reporting requirements of these donors to bring them into line with the reporting requirements of political parties by requiring annual returns to be furnished within 20 weeks after the end of the financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: Closing loopholes

PARA.TAB: A loophole in the existing legislation which is addressed by this bill relates to the operation of trust funds and similar organisations—including companies—which function wholly or mainly for the benefit of a registered political party or a number of political parties. To appreciate the extent to which the disclosure provisions are being flouted one need only examine the latest returns of the opposition parties. The Liberal Party, for example, has revealed that it has received income of $7.2 million laundered through a trust called the Free Enterprise Foundation.

The donations to this foundation have not been disclosed to the AEC. One does not know whether all the income from this trust has gone to the Liberal Party but current yields on funds would suggest that the undisclosed donations could exceed $80 million.

To evade the disclosure provisions the National Party of Australia launders its donations through John McEwen House Pty Ltd, a corporation that provides income to the Nationals amounting to half a million dollars.

Recently we heard of the South Australian Liberal receiving a $100,000 donation through an unregistered Hong Kong company. It has been suggested that the real source of these funds could be parties interested in bidding for a casino licence.

To my mind, the AEC's inability to police overseas donors represents a weakness in the legislation. I propose to give the joint standing committee a reference to advise how these provisions might be strengthened. Closing these loopholes has a lot of similarities to tackling tax evasion schemes. As one gate is shut, smart lawyers invent another. Nevertheless something has to be done to restore the spirit of our disclosure laws.

The bill provides that trusts and related entities must provide annual returns to the Electoral Commission containing substantially the same information as parties are required to report. However, where an amount was paid to or for the benefit of one or more registered political parties from funds generated by capital of that entity, each person who contributed to the capital must be identified in the return. Following on from this is a provision which makes these entities subject to compliance investigations by officers authorised by the Australian Electoral Commission.

Another loophole has been addressed by providing that donations made to a person or body with the intention of benefiting a particular registered political party will be deemed to be donations directly to that party. The bill also addresses a concern expressed by some party agents about compliance investigations of local party units by providing that the registered party agent may attend such investigations or may nominate another person to attend.

An anomaly in the act has been addressed by providing that the current registered agent of a political party may request that amendment be made to a claim or return. Previously, only the person who furnished the claim or return could make a request to the Electoral Commission that the claim or return be amended. For all those reasons, I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 amends the Commonwealth Electoral Act to give effect to recommendations made by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. The main elements in the bill include: making annual disclosure less complex, increasing the election funding rate, and bringing the Senate rate to the same level as the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: In June 1994, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters presented its interim report, titled Financial reporting by political parties. It was a very important report because it was the first time since 1984, when the present government first introduced electoral funding into federal legislation, that the processes had been reviewed in some detail by an appropriate committee of the parliament.

The report flowed from the committee's resolution in May 1994 to take further evidence on the funding and disclosure provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act of 1918. The proposals in the bill have been discussed between the parties and general agreement has been reached on most of the provisions contained therein. The coalition parties, of course, are opposed, as we have always been, to any retrospective elements in relation to contributions to the capital of trust funds which may generate income paid to a political party.

As I said, this legislation amends the Commonwealth Electoral Act, and the amendments which it contains will have the effect of registered political parties not having to report minute details of financial transactions and annual returns. It might sound absurd but there was evidence before the committee to the effect that branches of the respective political parties literally had to keep an account of the number of Iced Vo Vos they bought for meetings over a year.

The level of intricate detail being sought was quite absurd for what is, essentially, a voluntary organisational structure used by various parties and administered by ordinary men and women in suburbs and country towns across Australia. To ask them to involve themselves in that level of detail, and to carry the onerous political and legal risks contained therein should an audit be conducted and the number of Iced Vo Vos registered be found to be incorrect, they were up for very serious fines under the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be lamingtons for the Liberal Party.
—As I recall, there was an august Prime Minister from the Labor Party who had a great penchant for eating lamingtons—Mr Gough Whitlam.

PARA.TAB: In addition to that, other amendments contained in this legislation include that donors to registered political parties will report annually to the Australian Electoral Commission, to bring them in line with party reporting requirements. That is useful because it means that they can interrelate the need to report to the commission side by side with annual reporting processes necessary under the law and in compliance with the regulations.

The amendments further provide that the agent of a registered political party will have a right to attend compliance investigations into local party units. Again, this was not previously required under the legislation. Consequently, an audit could be conducted of a branch's affairs but no-one was necessarily present to explain why there were more lamingtons or fewer lamingtons than were originally referred to in the costs of that particular branch.

The amendments further provide that organisations, such as trust funds, which are closely related to registered political parties will be required to furnish annual returns to the Australian Electoral Commission and will be required to detail the source of capital where income derived has been used wholly or mainly for the benefit of a political party. An anomaly which prevents any person other than the person who furnished a claim or return from having that claim or return amended, will be removed to enable the current party agent to make the request for amendment.

Another two amendments which are worthy of note are that the rate for election funding reimbursement will be amended so that a Senate vote will be funded at the same rate as a House of Representatives vote and the rate will be increased to $1.50 per vote, indexed; and payments of election funding entitlements will also be able to be made to the national secretariat of a registered political party. That is with the agreement of the state body.

I should point out that this amendment is one which was amenable to the Labor Party because it has a centralised administrative system. This is not so for other parties—especially the Greens. I understand that the Australian Democrats argued quite persuasively that it had a state based organisational structure and, provided that there was agreement with the state bodies, the funding arrangements are as requested.

This legislation and its amendments will facilitate the completion of annual disclosure returns of income and expenditure by registered political parties by making them less complex. The point I made earlier is quite clear from the point of view of voluntary based organisations. Annual returns will no longer be required in great detail, as was the case under the original legislation.

Details of donors of individual amounts of less than $500 need not now be disclosed. There are corresponding requirements in relation to payments. Again, that is a very significant amendment which will be of considerable help at the branch level. Donors of gifts of $500 or more, totalling more than $1,500, must be disclosed in an annual return of a political party. However, donors of gifts to a political party which total $1,500 or more during a financial year will be required to furnish an annual return. This will ensure that there is a cross-check of donations by having donors' returns cover the same time frame as party returns.

As we see it, there is a retrospective element in the provision relating to annual returns of trust funds which will require details on the source of capital, even though that capital was contributed when there was no question of disclosure—in other words, under the old legislation. I understand that that matter will be further examined when the legislation is before the Senate.

Finally, the amendments will enable a party agent to request that an amendment be made to a claim or return. That is the matter to which I earlier referred. The coalition does not intend to oppose this legislation, although I emphasise that we are strongly opposed to retrospective elements in relation to declaring the source of capital for trust funds.

I must say that I took some exception to the comments made by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker) when he was trying to put forward the view that the coalition spent an inordinate amount of time trying to find loopholes in the old legislation, and suggesting, of course, that the Labor Party was absolutely above board and would never conceivably even think along such lines. The simple realities are that the Western Australian government was thrown out—and rightly so—over an interesting exercise called WA Inc. That was the case involving the activities of the Labor Party. A former premier is—or was—a guest in Her Majesty's gaol. A number of people have been before the courts, and possibly others will follow them. For the Labor Party to claim that it is somehow or other free of such activities—

TALK.START.PARA: —That million they collected at Hawke's lunch disappeared at the border with Canberra.
—Precisely. Absolutely right. Another one worth mentioning is John Curtin House Ltd. Last year, John Curtin House, as I understand it, made a donation to the Labor Party of around $1.6 million.
—How much?

—It was $1.6 million. John Curtin House is a very interesting little mechanism by which the Labor Party has been able to access property purchasers and use the rent gained therefrom as a means of supplementing its income. There is nothing illegal about that; I am not suggesting that there is. I am simply making the point that there are mechanisms which Labor has been only too happy to use over many years, certainly since 1984 when federal funding was first introduced, and which make it rather rich for the minister to seriously suggest that they are lilywhite and that everybody else is besmirched by allegations of this nature. Then you have the famous Centenary House inquiry, in which I had a small role to play.
—Infamous.
—The infamous Centenary House, if I recall rightly, had gross sums as high as $80 million floating in and out of the system.
—But mainly in.

—Mainly in. Again this was a case where there were considerable questions raised by me and others as to whether the activities of the Commonwealth were being protected by the government in the context of its decision to rent out its accommodation, namely Centenary House, to the Commonwealth Auditor-General. I say here, as I have said in other places, we as a government would not have considered an arrangement such as that because it left open to considerable question whether the level of probity had been adequately met and whether the Auditor-General, of all people, was in a position to protect his integrity under those circumstances.There is no way this government can claim that it is lilywhite in these very complex issues of federal funding, or indirect federal funding, of political parties and it is a matter which is worth noting.

PARA.TAB: The minister also referred to the Free Enterprise Foundation. For the record may I make it absolutely clear that the Free Enterprise Foundation was established, as I understand it, in the early 1980s. It is not part of the Liberal Party, as the minister suggested.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives you $7 million a year.

—Nevertheless, it is not part of the Liberal Party, unlike John Curtin House Ltd or the Centenary House arrangement where your ministerial colleagues have been, and some possibly still are, directors of these companies which have been directly involved in funding the Labor Party, which is in government and which has had not the slightest compunction about leasing out at exorbitant rent its property to Commonwealth departments, including the Auditor-General. That is the issue. That is the question of probity which I am prepared to raise and debate in this House at any time with the minister or with anybody else.

PARA.TAB: Do not come in here and try to put over an act that you are lilywhite because, frankly, a lot of people in the Australian community are highly suspicious of the activities of the Labor Party over recent years and the way in which you have used your power as the government of the day to enter into agreements which are clearly and unequivocally to the advantage of the Labor Party and certainly not to the advantage of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —In any electoral funding legislation in Australia today we must balance the need to disclose properly where donations have come from to ensure that, wherever possible, benefits and assistance are not being given to people in exchange for contributions to political parties against, on the other hand, the very important need to ensure that the reporting conditions are not so onerous as to make it extremely difficult, if not impossible, to comply with the requirements.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that the legislation was first brought in by this government a number of years ago. As has been said by previous speakers, there has been a review of the procedures which have been in place until now and there has been a general consensus amongst the political parties in Australia that the way things were operating was simply not adequate.

Consequently, the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 has been brought into this place as a result of a report brought down by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, and it amends the Commonwealth Electoral Act in a number of ways. On our side of politics we would have liked to have seen a number of other amendments made to the Commonwealth Electoral Act in ways that would ensure that the result of an election in fact accurately represented the decision of the Australian people.

In addition to financial matters, there are other matters which the government must address, and sooner rather than later. For instance, at the present time there is no need to prove identity to be able to enrol to vote. The Electoral Commission should trial a system of voter cards, there should be a continuous review of the electoral roll, subdivisional voting should be reintroduced and compulsory voting should be abolished. These are matters the government may well consider in the future but, unfortunately, they have not been included in the legislation currently before the House.

This particular legislation will make a number of changes and, as a result, registered political parties will not have to report minute details of financial transactions in annual returns. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) outlined a number of the very minute transactions that he experienced had to be carried out within Liberal Party branches. I have even heard that, on occasions, a Liberal Party branch had been required to count the number of tea bags it held in stock—no doubt these rules also apply to the Labor Party. Clearly, the minute requirements for accounting, which have been in place until now, were an unintended consequence of the legislation. It is important, when one realises the system is not working the way it was intended to work, that amendments be brought in and, indeed, we are debating those amendments today.

The legislation will also provide for donors to registered political parties to report annually to the Australian Electoral Commission so they can be brought into line with party reporting requirements. The provisions also include that an agent of a registered political party will have a right to attend compliance investigations into local party units, which is very important because these days the public image of a political party can quite often be determined by actions carried out at the local and branch level.

Let us face it: the ALP has branch stacking. We have heard how the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) rorted his first preselection. All that impacts on the Australian public's overall impression of the ALP. Similarly, if a local party organisation did not dot its i's and cross its t's as far as electoral financial matters were concerned, it could impact on the overall public impression of that political party. Therefore, it is eminently appropriate that the agent of a political party have the right to attend compliance investigations into local party units. When that is done, state office will have an idea of what is actually happening and will be able to rectify things that are not right.

The legislation also provides that organisations, such as trust funds, which are closely related to registered political parties will be required to furnish annual returns to the Australian Electoral Commission and will be required to detail the source of capital where income derived has been used wholly or mainly for the benefit of a political party. The legislation also seeks to remove an anomaly which prevents any person from having a claim or return amended other than the person who furnished it. That will be removed to enable the current party agent to make the request for amendment.

The rate of electoral funding and reimbursement will be amended so that a Senate vote will be funded at the same rate as a House of Representatives vote. The rate will be increased to $1.50 per vote and will be indexed. The coalition will not be opposing this. Payments of election funding entitlements will also be able to be made to the national secretariat of a registered political party with the consent of the state organisations.

These are the principal changes occurring through the bill before the House. There has been a substantial public debate following the release by the joint committee of its recommendations, and thus we find ourselves today discussing legislation which will not be opposed by the coalition.

The position of the Liberal and National parties was outlined by my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield when he addressed the parliament a short while ago. The coalition parties, however, are opposed to the retrospective element in relation to contributors to the capital of trust funds which generate income paid to a political party. As a general rule, our side of politics is certainly opposed to retrospective legislation which acts to the detriment of the citizen.

This legislation, which has been some time in coming before the House of Representatives, is not being opposed by our side of politics. It is interesting to note that the government brought in this legislation for debate this morning without its appearing on the Notice Paper. I really wonder why we are discussing this piece of legislation when it has not appeared on the Notice Paper. Someone suggested to me that it could well be that the government has political motives in bringing it forward at this time. We all know how hard the government has tried to obtain a double dissolution trigger, but it has been denied such a trigger. Clearly, the government is keeping its options as open as possible so that it can go to the people at a time when it feels it could be successful.

If we look at the current opinion polls, we see that the government is clearly on track to lose a vast number of seats. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has every chance, with the support of the Australian people, of becoming Prime Minister. In my view, he will be one of the greatest prime ministers that this nation has ever seen. I see that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker) is smiling. Given the current opinion polls, I think the minister would consider his tenure as certainly limited.

I turn to the key points of this legislation. One provision will facilitate the completion of annual disclosure returns of income and expenditure by registered political parties by making them less complex. Annual returns will no longer require categorisation of amounts received and paid. Details of donors of individual amounts less than $500 need not now be disclosed. There are corresponding requirements in relation to payments. Donors of gifts of $500 or more totalling more than $1,500 must be disclosed in an annual return of a political party. However, donors of gifts to a political party which total $1,500 or more during a financial year must furnish an annual return, thereby ensuring that there is a cross-check of donations by having donors' returns cover the same time frame as party returns.

There is a retrospective element in the provisions relating to annual returns of trust funds which require details on the source of capital even though that capital was contributed when there was no question of disclosure. The legislation also enables a party agent to request that an amendment be made to a claim or a return.

The fact that both sides of politics are supporting this particular piece of legislation is an example of cooperation in the political area. When we find that legislation is not working the way that it was intended and that legislation has become onerous, unwieldy and unreasonable, I think it is eminently appropriate that amendments should be made. There have been discussions between the government and the opposition, and the bill currently before the House is the product of those discussions. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Messages from the Governor-General recommending appropriations announced.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.
Amendments (by Mr Walker)—by leave—proposed:

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is not opposing the amendments moved by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker). They are integral to the legislative changes which are the subject of this debate and which have been agreed to prior to this. They are quite consistent with the amendments contained in the committee report, which is the basis of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I should make one point in relation to amendment Nos 1 to 3 of clause 5, which relates to gifts to political parties. The minister is no doubt aware that this proposal will commence only on the date of agreement by the Governor-General. There is a real probability that that is going to be remarkably close to 30 June 1995, which is when the act is said to commence. Consequently, there could be an overlap problem, and that is worth serious consideration. There is no doubt the Electoral Commission will have to make sure all political parties are aware of the timing components in that particular matter.

I also refer to item 12, new division 5A, which removes the relevance of the time for claims to be made and lodged. The 20th day after polling day is the deadline for lodging an agreement dividing the election funding payment in respect of a Senate group jointly endorsed by two registered parties. That, of course, is relevant to the coalition for obvious reasons. In many states, we have a joint ticket shared by both the Liberal Party and the National Party. Consequently, we will need to be fully involved in that process.

But, overall, the amendments have the agreement of the opposition. As I said in my speech during the second reading debate, we are concerned about the retrospective elements contained in the legislation, and that will be subject to further discussion as the legislation proceeds into the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to table the supplementary explanatory memorandum and make one comment on this alleged retrospectivity argument.
