DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haviland Mr C.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take great pleasure in speaking on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994. This bill amends the State Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992 to give effect to initiatives announced in last year's budget. Under this bill, $8.7 million will be provided by the Commonwealth in 1995 to foster literacy development for children in the early years of schooling, and $4 million will be provided in 1995 in grants to school authorities to support the study of 10 priority languages. This program will replace an existing program which supports eight languages in each state and territory.

PARA.TAB: The bill gives effect to changes to strengthen the Commonwealth's new schools policy for funding new and changing non-government schools and to simplify administrative arrangements for approving block grant authorities under the capital grants program for schools. It will also give effect to funding schedules for capital grants for government and non-government schools for 1995, funding schedules for grants for community languages for 1995 and a revised funding schedule for grants for rural student hostel projects from 1994 to 1996.

The bill proposes to provide grants to foster literacy development for children in the early years of schooling. As I have already said, under the new provisions $8.7 million will be made available to assist children from kindergarten to year 3, with special emphasis on those disadvantaged by low socio-economic backgrounds. That is entirely consistent with the government's social justice focus and the importance of access and equity to the most disadvantaged in the community for whom this government believes so strongly. Additionally, $4 million will be made available to provide grants to school authorities to support the study of the 10 priority languages that I mentioned before.

The bill provides for a number of other changes, such as, strengthening the Commonwealth's new schools policy for funding new and changing non-government schools, simplifying administrative arrangements for approving block grant authorities and funding schedules for capital grants for government and non-government schools, which I have already mentioned.

Education is one of the many important areas of social policy. It is about social justice and access and equity to Australia's young people, which is the reason the government places a high priority in getting the balance right and in social justice in education. Education is one of a number of policy areas which suffer from an unfortunate circumstance: under the constitution it is primarily a state government responsibility. Because the federal government provides a large amount of money to education, the funding of schools and vocational education is subject to Commonwealth-state agreements and relies on cooperation between the Commonwealth and the states, which is not always forthcoming.

As the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) pointed out in his speech, the federal government provides over $3 billion each year to Australia's schools. Yesterday in question time I asked a question of the minister relating to the Grants Commission report.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good question too.
—It was a good question. The answer he gave the House was certainly enlightening. I will elaborate on some of the current circumstances facing the school education system in New South Wales. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Victorian per capita funding on government education was $511 which, for the first time this decade, was below New South Wales per capita funding, which was $512. However, on a per student basis, New South Wales is still last.
I will come back to the comments the minister made yesterday because they are enlightening and fairly revealing about the New South Wales government's commitment to education.

PARA.TAB: As the minister has outlined, 33 new government schools were opened in New South Wales last year. Only 10 schools were opened before 30 June. Obviously, in the second half of the year, the New South Wales government decided that an election was coming up and it had better get on with the opening of a few schools. These projects, funded either wholly or partially by the Commonwealth, totalled $47,098,000 in 1994. Of that, $27,255,000 was funded by the Commonwealth, or 57.87 per cent of the total cost of these projects.

There has been a bit of a history in all states of state governments being pretty opportunistic in the way they take the electoral credit by taking every opportunity to open these schools with a lot of fanfare so guidelines have been put in place whereby, depending on the ratio of funding between the Commonwealth and the state, the Commonwealth government or the state government has opening rights or, in some cases, there are joint opening rights. As part of the guidelines for Commonwealth funding for these schools and TAFEs there is certainly a requirement for the federal minister or his representative to be able to address these functions.

The system used by the New South Wales government to notify the Commonwealth of the dates of these openings technically breaches the guidelines. In 1994, it technically breached the guidelines in 100 per cent of cases. So, last year, every time a school was opened in New South Wales the New South Wales government breached the agreement with the Commonwealth on the protocol for these openings.

The procedure used is that the New South Wales government notifies the minister's office of a date and will rarely change that date, even if it is unsuitable—for example, if federal parliament is sitting and the minister cannot get there. If federal members cannot get there, the New South Wales government still refuses to change the date even though in most cases there is more Commonwealth funding than New South Wales government funding.

Sometimes the regional officers of the Department of Education in New South Wales set the date but the New South Wales government will still not change the date if it is unsuitable for the Commonwealth minister or federal members. In at least one instance this date has been unsuitable but an alternative date was not negotiated by the region or by the office of the state minister. Some examples are Gosford High School, Sydney Boys High School and Birchgrove Primary School, where the openings clashed with sitting dates of federal parliament. For some reason, the New South Wales government and its education department were not prepared to cooperate to enable the Commonwealth to be represented by an elected person. Four of these openings out of the 33 in New South Wales last year did clash with federal parliamentary sitting days.

Let us look at what has happened in 1995. I mentioned that only 33 schools were opened in New South Wales for the whole of 1994, 23 of which were in the second half of the year. But this year by 25 March 1995, 45 government schools will have been opened in New South Wales. This compares with only one government school being opened in February or March in 1994. These 45 schools, as was the case with last year's schools, were funded wholly or in part by the Commonwealth government.

The total cost of these school projects was $116,931,106. The Commonwealth government contributed $73,302,432 or approximately 63 per cent of the total cost of those 45 schools. Funding for TAFE colleges was a total of $61,835,710, to which the Commonwealth contributed $55,859,710. The total is $129 million-odd of Commonwealth funding out of a total of $178.7 million for schools and TAFEs in New South Wales that have been opened or will be opened in February and March. That is a total of about 72 per cent of Commonwealth funding for these projects.

Once again, the system used by the New South Wales government to notify the Commonwealth of these openings has breached the guidelines in every single case. The New South Wales government notified our minister's office of the date, giving in most cases less than the required two months notice that is required under the Commonwealth-state agreement. Despite an approach by the minister to the New South Wales minister, Virginia Chadwick, in early January this year, the minister has refused to change any of the unsuitable dates. In fact, she did not even bother to answer the letter.

The minister gave some examples yesterday of schools around New South Wales. I will mention some of them. The Lucas Heights Community School was officially opened on 2 February after having operated for more than two years. A school called the Portland Central School had some new classrooms and an administration block opened yesterday, even though the work on it will not finish until May. Nevertheless, it was opened yesterday, just in time for the state election, of course.

There is to be an opening staged shortly at Lidcombe TAFE, obviously in the next two weeks. The buildings have not yet been finished, not even to the extent that a plaque can be put up. As the building could not be opened, it was decided to have a tree planting instead.

There are three other very interesting cases, all of which are in the state electorate of the South Coast and the federal electorate of Gilmore—Sanctuary Point, Vincentia High and St Georges Basin Public School. I understand that the state member for the South Coast, John Hatton, the Independent, who recently announced he would not be contesting the state election, was originally invited. Lo and behold, as soon as he announced he would not be standing for the forthcoming state election he was suddenly disinvited and Premier John Fahey decided he would do the opening instead.

The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott) discovered by talking to some state education officials that he was not going to be invited or he was not going to be allowed to speak at these openings. Naturally he took umbrage at that, given that he had sought special permission and was fortunate enough to be granted leave from this place to attend. There was a fairly major bike race he had been instrumental in organising taking place last Monday, and he found—in the case of the three schools and the bike race he had organised—that Premier John Fahey did not want him anywhere near these events, let alone speaking at them. So he contacted the Premier's office and left a fairly concise and forthright message about the fact that he had not been invited. The Premier denied that there was any attempt to remove him from the speaking list at these three schools and the bike race. The Premier obviously had been caught out. He did not want to be seen as the petty Premier of New South Wales that he indeed is. When the honourable member turned up at these events he found that his name had been removed from the speaking list; nevertheless, he was able to speak anyway as commonsense prevailed. This is a classic example of politics in New South Wales.

I was asked to represent the federal minister at the opening of some buildings at the Campbelltown Performing Arts High School yesterday. Unfortunately, because of the business of this place, I and the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) were unable to obtain leave to attend. The school is in the seat of Werriwa, but the catchment area for this school—a very important performing arts high school in Campbelltown—takes in both the seats of Macarthur and Werriwa.

Because there has been a deliberate policy on the part of the New South Wales minister to open as many of these schools as she can get away with during federal parliamentary sitting weeks, despite the fact that there is so much Commonwealth money involved, unfortunately there was no elected federal government representative able to be present. The state member for Campbelltown, who happens to be a member of the Labor Party, Mr Michael Knight, was there but he was not afforded the opportunity to speak. My wife attended in my place but was not able to speak. Funnily enough, the minister for education, Virginia Chadwick, could not be bothered attending either. She was off around the countryside in some other marginal seat opening another school—probably the one at Lithgow in the electorate of the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons)—with federal government money.

In the case of the Campbelltown Performing Arts High School the Commonwealth contribution was 100 per cent. It was funded 100 per cent by Commonwealth funding—$446,000. The New South Wales government contributed not one cent to that education facility—not one cent to the future of young children interested in the performing arts who attend that particular first-rate high school. Nevertheless, the New South Wales government trotted out not the minister, as I said, but a parliamentary secretary from the upper house who nobody had heard of—Richard Bull—the same person the New South Wales government trotted out to open the schools in Gilmore on Tuesday.

From what I understand, the parliamentary secretary, Richard Bull, spoke a lot of bull when he opened the school yesterday. He did not even mention the Commonwealth government's contribution to the school. Despite the fact that it was 100 per cent Commonwealth money, he did not even mention that. He, of course, talked about the New South Wales government's supposed great commitment to education. We heard about that yesterday. The New South Wales government is coming last in terms of funding per student. It is $250 per student behind the national average, I think that is right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Short-changing the kids of New South Wales.

—Yes, short-changing the kids. Of course, if it were not for the Commonwealth government, which has a commitment to social justice and which has a commitment to access and equity in education—as with all other areas of social policy—the New South Wales school system surely would collapse, just as the heath system is collapsing in New South Wales because of the neglect and totally inequitable management of it by the New South Wales government.

PARA.TAB: As I have said, unfortunately the state governments do have the constitutional responsibility for service delivery in areas like health and education and so, for the time being, we are stuck with that. The kids of New South Wales—particularly in the fast growing areas such as my electorate, where there are many children under five and where people under 20 make up more than half of the population—would surely miss out if it were not for the role of the Commonwealth government. I think this issue was covered fairly well by the minister in his answer yesterday.

Next week I will get the opportunity, hopefully, to speak at the opening of a school in my electorate. It is the Elizabeth Macarthur High School at Narellan, the suburb in which I live. It is a reasonably new school. While it is only being officially opened next week, like the school mentioned yesterday, the one at—

TALK.START.PARA: —Lucas Heights.

—It has been there for more than two years. I happen to know this very well because there was a polling booth at the Elizabeth Macarthur High School for the 1993 federal election. It was a fairly small polling booth because it was a new school in a growing part of the suburb of Narellan. I certainly visited that school on the day of the election because it was a polling booth. Of course, the Labor vote was substantial at that polling booth, as it was in most of those growing areas around Narellan, Mount Annan and Currans Hill, which is the area that the Elizabeth Macarthur High School serves.

PARA.TAB: Just looking at the information I have got here on the Elizabeth Macarthur High School: it is being opened by the state minister for education, Virginia Chadwick, who will actually turn up at Narellan because it is in a marginal state seat. This particular school is costing a total of $8,360,000 and I understand that a substantial proportion of that is funded by the Commonwealth.

I will have great pleasure in making sure that the students and the parents at the Elizabeth Macarthur High School in Narellan are well aware of that fact. When they arrive at the school for the opening—like the people who turned up for the Campbelltown Performing Arts High School opening yesterday—they will see all these signs which say `New South Wales government building better schools'. I had a close look at one of these signs. I can assure the House it says nothing about the Commonwealth government's contribution to New South Wales schools on these signs at all, even though they are paid for by the taxpayer.

Next week when I attend this official opening I will have to point out that the Commonwealth government supplies a substantial amount of the funding. In fact, it has supplied 72 per cent of the funding for the schools and TAFEs that have already been opened in New South Wales this year and also those that will be opened before 25 March. Indeed, it supplied 100 per cent of the funding for the buildings that were opened yesterday at the Campbelltown Performing Arts High School. I will be pointing this out to the good people of Narellan next week.

I commend the bill to the House. It is yet another necessary part of the legislative process that the federal government is committed to; that is, making sure that students in our schools do get access and equity in education, just as they do in all other areas of social justice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I obviously support very strongly the allocation of additional funds to education in Australia, particularly in the primary and secondary areas. Also, I would like to commend the shadow minister, the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson), for his contribution to this debate and his concern, as reflected in his amendment, that the funding policies of federal government should take account of all of the real and relevant issues that contemporary Australians want to see addressed. I also give recognition to the role of both state and non-government schools in the education system.

PARA.TAB: Today I want to provide a perspective from the point of view of a country member of parliament. I am a member from regional Australia. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, my seat is in north-east Victoria. We have many dynamic and interesting school communities in north-east Victoria. Some of them are in the large cities such as Wodonga, Wangaratta, Benalla and Yarrawonga and others are in very small communities. We also have populations, in both the non-government and the government education areas, that extend into catchments where people have to travel fairly long distances to and from school.

In some cases, there are interstate arrangements. For example, in Corryong in the upper Murray near Mount Kosciusko, the schools have traditionally provided educational opportunities in primary and secondary schools, and now in TAFE, for students from New South Wales travelling each day across the state border. That is also the case along the Murray River. You will find many examples of school communities actually serving catchments in both states. That is as it should be. I, for one, believe that education knows no state borders, nor should it.

Education is a national asset and resource. We require and must demand of all of our people in charge of education in the political arena both in state and federal governments, and also in the management area, that there be the maximum of cooperation and assistance. At the same time, I think competition is a very healthy thing. I believe the opportunity for school communities to be innovative and to provide their own subjects in a general sense is a very good thing and should be encouraged, as it enriches the education framework that is needed for our young Australians.

I would like to also thank the minister at the table, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free), for his courtesy to me and to schools in my electorate in the many ways that he has helped the schools develop. In the near future, I will have the honour of representing the minister as a federal member of parliament in the opening of some extensions at the Mitchell secondary college in Wodonga, which used to be a technical school.

I was on the school council many years ago, and one of my children attended the Mitchell college to do what was then called TOP, which was a version of VCE. If you are trying to keep up with all of these titles, I am sure that you would be as dismayed as I am in trying to keep up with the various changes in education. I am very pleased that the minister has been gracious enough to ask me to represent him. I will do my best to make sure that the contribution of both state and federal governments, on behalf of taxpayers, is acknowledged fairly and in an even-handed way.

However, I want to make some comments that I hope will be regarded as constructive comments, but they are serious ones that need to be addressed, in relation to planning the allocation of the valuable and scarce dollars that we have for education in Australia. In country areas particularly, parents who have children with disabilities have a special burden to bear. They do not, in every case, have access to the larger facilities that are available for children needing special teaching and assistance because they live in smaller communities separated from the larger cities.

I have one example which I will give in a general sense without identifying the family so as not to embarrass it. In a Catholic school in Myrtleford there is a marvellous sister who, with her staff and the parents of a child with a profound hearing problem, has been able to make a remarkable contribution to the educational development of a particular little girl. As a result of the efforts and assistance of both Commonwealth and state education departments, the little girl's educational progress has been quite remarkable. She is, in fact, able to attend a normal, ordinary school in Myrtleford and, despite her profound hearing disability, is making good progress.

This has only been made possible because an interpreter is available on a one-to-one basis for quite a lot of the school week to assist this child and the teachers to relate and for the child to participate in education. Honourable members should remember that, by reason of this sort of arrangement, the benefits are, firstly, that the child is able to stay in a normal family environment, living with mother and father in the country community and not having to go away to some distant part, separated from her parents. That is a bonus, and I do not have to explain the reason why.

Secondly, it helps the school community understand and assist in the assimilation of children with disabilities. One of the greatest examples you can ever find of how successful it is to have children with disabilities in school communities is to see how children who do not have disabilities, who are going through school with these children—their mates—do not find any difference at all in their colleagues' position, even though in many cases they are profoundly disabled. It is great to see that manifestation, that development of understanding. The eventual erosion of discrimination against people with disabilities will come about because of the example being set in these circumstances and the way in which young Australians accept children in their school environment with disabilities as being just the same as they are. We should do all we can to encourage the continuation and development of these sorts of services.

In the case that I am mentioning, the small amount of money that is required to pay for the interpreter services will not be available to the same extent for this child's continuing education in secondary schooling in Myrtleford. The reason is somewhat complicated. It is partly because the Catholic Education Office has to allocate its scarce resources amongst all these schools that need assistance in this area and the inability of the state and federal governments to provide additional funds to cope with all of the requests from the Catholic Education Office and other government schools in Victoria and the rest of Australia.

I am not attacking or criticising anyone in this system. As a former minister, I know the burden of trying to prioritise and do the right thing when there is not enough money to go round. It is a very difficult circumstance. I am raising this case because I was struck by the fact that, if the one-to-one interpreter is not available to help continue with this child's educational development, it will have a dramatic adverse effect on this child's future and disrupt the child and her family.

Looking at the allocation of money in this bill that will occur in language development in improving literacy development, perhaps it would be appropriate for us to be a bit more flexible and to look again at the way the programs are funded to see whether we can squeeze a few more dollars into helping children of the type that I have just described to go on, develop and achieve their full potential.

As is often the case, education is the bridge to understanding, success and happiness. I believe—I am sure the minister will agree with me—that children with disabilities should be given that special leg-up, if possible, through education. The education process can be a marvellous way of helping disabled people make their way in life and succeed. We have many friends with serious disabilities who are outstanding in their contribution to society and to business and government.

I mention that to members because I think it is worth reflecting on. I am going to write to the minister and give him more information about this case to see whether we could do a case study and do something to assist.

The other measure I would like to welcome is the increased effort to improve literacy standards in schooling. It is easy to criticise and to pass on stories that members of parliament collect as they travel around their electorates, but we all know that many people—in business, commerce and industry—complain and express alarm about the lack of skill in the basics of many of those who have left secondary school.

Frankly, I am alarmed that this is the case. It is a difficult problem because often it implies an adverse criticism that is not fair on many fine teachers who have done their best. However, I think there is ample evidence, as the funding in this bill obviously recognises, that a lot more needs to be done to improve the basic skills in education.

I have a brother who is a primary school teacher. I believe, notwithstanding his constant brainwashing of me constantly over many years, that it is at the primary school level that we should be putting in a lot more resources and effort to increase the skills of and teaching opportunities for children in those basic areas.

Also, is it not a remarkable thing that Australia is suddenly waking up to itself about the need to skill our young children in other languages? I was told recently that parents in Japan are no longer seeking to have their children taught English as a second language. They are very pragmatic and their preference now is for the Cantonese language. We can well understand why, with a market of more than 1,000 million people right on their doorstep. With the knowledge that in future the world will very much involve China in the activities of every other country, especially those in Asia, it is understandable that parents in Japan would like their children to be able to converse in a skilled way in a language that the Chinese use.

In Australia, despite the fact that we are very close to Indonesia and other Asian countries, recognition of the need for our students to be given the opportunity to learn a second language—in my view, preferably an Asian language—has been a very slow and painful process. I for one would advocate that there be a compulsory second language introduced into the curriculum at primary school level and that that compulsory language be one of the Asian languages.

I know that might offend some of my friends who have a closer affinity to the classical languages of Europe. But I say quite pragmatically that we should require our children to have a compulsory Asian language included in their curriculum. Just as reading, writing and 'rithmetic training is supposed to be carried out at primary level, so should an Asian language be included. I will be watching with great interest the development of the new 10 priority languages program to be funded in this bill.

I represent many people in Albury-Wodonga area who are in the defence forces. There is a very large defence establishment there. I would like to mention how frustrating it has been for parents involved in the defence industry, having to move around the country and around the world in the course of their careers.

I know persons in the army who have had as many as 18 transfers in their careers. There are not as many transfers now because there have been changes, but there are still quite a few. It is a great burden for parents and teachers to have to put up with some of the idiosyncrasies in the basic curriculum between states. I know that the state and federal ministers have been working on this and have made a lot of progress in reaching recognition and uniformity in some of these basic areas. However, a lot more work has to be done.

Parents who are employed in the defence area would like the federal and state education ministers to give absolute priority to resolving this matter in a way that reflects the needs of contemporary defence force families in Australia. This applies to other people who have to move around the country because of their jobs in this economy which is becoming more dynamic. Nowadays, people do not have just one job when they leave school; they sometimes have three or four or five careers. We have to get used to the idea that there will be a lot more mobility in Australia as people move from place to place.

I hope that the funds will soon be flowing. I hope that the openings will be many. I hope that there will be no arguments about who opens what, but that we will all rejoice when the openings occur because of the benefits in education that children in Australia will receive.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank the honourable members who have participated in the debate. I managed to hear most of the contributions. I thank the honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) for his contribution. I will have somebody contact him to talk about the circumstances of the little deaf girl in Myrtleford. The Commonwealth provides considerable funding for special education. I will see what has occurred that is preventing her getting the assistance she previously received. I thank him also for his support for national initiatives in curriculum. I hope that he is able to communicate his enthusiasm to the Victorian Minister for Education, Mr Hayward, because I would certainly welcome his cooperation on these matters.

PARA.TAB: I also enjoyed the contributions from the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) and the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson). It is the contribution of the honourable member for Ballarat on which I would like to concentrate. It will come as no surprise to the honourable member for Ballarat to learn that the government rejects his amendment.

During his remarks he raised three matters that deserve some attention: the first concerns retention rates; the second concerns supplementation; and the third concerns the review of the new schools policy. I turn first of all to retention rates. It is true that retention rates grew steadily from the early 1980s. They were around 36 per cent when the honourable member for Ballarat's party left office and they reached their peak of 77.1 per cent in 1992. There was a slight decline in 1993 to 76.6 per cent and a sharper decline last year to 74.6 per cent.

With the large number of alternative routes to employment now available to young people, year 12 retention rates do not provide a complete picture of where our young people are gaining relevant education and training. Certainly there is an improvement in the labour market. I imagine that the figures for February, which will be released at about this time, will show continuing growth in opportunities for young people—as they have in recent months. That is resulting in more young people taking up apprenticeships and other employment options. That trend is confirmed in figures showing apprenticeship commencements increasing from 26,800 in 1993 to 33,000 last year and a corresponding drop in the 15- to 19-year old unemployment rate.

It is also true that fewer young people appear to be repeating year 12, responding to advice from the government, repeated by me on a number of occasions, that repeating year 12 is unlikely to produce the kind of improvement in results that some year 12 repeaters seem to be expecting. Fewer young people are repeating year 12; instead, they are taking up opportunities in TAFE and employment, as the government has been encouraging them to do. This has also had an effect on school retention.

A technical factor which would be of interest to the honourable member for Ballarat is that more young people these days are choosing to study year 12 on a part-time rather than a full-time basis and those students are not counted by the ABS for retention purposes if they are studying part time. The patterns are interesting on a state by state basis. In Victoria, for example, between 1992 and 1994 retention fell by 3.8 per cent as opposed to a national fall of 2.5 per cent. As I mentioned yesterday, New South Wales has the lowest retention rate of any mainland state.

This is a reasonable illustration of Liberal policy in action. This is a reasonable illustration of what would happen were the policies advanced by the honourable member for Ballarat put in action. As a result, in those two Liberal states you see that very poor performance. In his own state, his colleagues in state government having closed 271 government schools and sacked over 8,000 teachers, it is not surprising that one should see falls of the kind I have mentioned in school retention. It is reasonably difficult to expect young people to continue on at school if at the same time you are closing their schools.

On the matter of supplementation, which the honourable member raised, it is true that the government considered this matter very carefully, as it well might, given that the index of average government school recurrent cost rose by 5.1 per cent in the most recent period. That required a considerable amount of money to supplement school funding, some $133 million this year. The government did consider its position very carefully because the original intention of the policy to index schools funding by average government school recurrent cost was intended to link quality improvements from the government sector to the flow of funds to schools in general and to the non-government sector in particular.

A figure of 5.1 per cent at a time when inflation was very low at 1.7 per cent obviously provided food for thought for the government, particularly given that the most significant contributing factor to the 5.1 per cent increase in costs was a blow-out in Victoria. That was the year in which the Victorian government sacked those teachers and paid out around $180 million in redundancy payments. The Commonwealth found it fairly difficult to accept that an increase in expenditure that involved sacking teachers could be linked to a quality index, which was the point of the original policy. The Commonwealth took time to consider its position and it decided that the original undertaking would stand and, as a result, many schools in all sectors will this year get the benefit of that additional $133 million in supplementation.

The honourable member for Ballarat spent some time on the government's decision to undertake a review of the new schools policy in the non-government sector. This review signals, first of all, a continuing commitment by this government to the orderly development of viable non-government schools. It also provides us with the opportunity for a comprehensive review of a policy which is almost 10 years old.

It is very rare—the honourable member for Ballarat may not be aware of this—for a policy to be in place for that long and not be subject to a review, particularly a program of this size that has been operating for almost 10 years and involving expenditure of well over $1 1/2 billion in the non-government sector. While the policy has undergone some changes over that period, it has certainly not been subject to any in-depth examination of its operation.

The review is certainly timely because the last 10 years have seen major changes in the school education environment. I have mentioned that year 12 retention rates have more than doubled, so the school population in the post-compulsory years is very different in 1995 from the position a decade ago. Schools these days are increasingly becoming providers of vocational education, information technology is also having its impact, and other interesting structural developments are appearing. For example, there are developments which promote links between the various sectors.

In Coffs Harbour an education precinct was recently opened which involves the co-location of a campus of the Southern Cross University, a TAFE college and a government high school, sharing facilities and promoting movement between the sectors. A similar kind of development is planned for the site of the former HMAS Nirimba in Sydney, which again will involve a campus of a university, a large TAFE presence, a government secondary school and a Catholic secondary school, to allow for the opportunity to share resources and generally an enriched educational environment. As well, there are examples around the country of links between the systems. For example, at Golden Grove in South Australia we have co-located a government high school, a Catholic high school and a Uniting Church high school, which are sharing some specialist facilities.

It is not unreasonable to say that we ought to look at the new schools policy and see whether it promotes these kinds of developments as well as it might and see whether changes are needed. There certainly has been a high level of interest in the review amongst stakeholders from a variety of quarters. It will provide stakeholders with an opportunity to discuss issues concerning new schools which they have raised from time to time—for example, whether the minimum enrolment requirement ought to take into account where a school is located and whether the same minimum enrolment requirements should apply in rural and remote areas as apply in the capital cities.

The review could provide a view on whether the policy is flexible enough to take into account the benefits that can flow from a whole range of developments that people really were not thinking about 10 years ago. It is in that spirit—and, frankly, underpinned by my basic belief that the new schools policy has served the country well but that now is the time to look at ways in which we might be able to make it work better—that the review will proceed.

I notice from his press release of Tuesday that the opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Ballarat, wants to scrap the new schools policy altogether. The opposition believes in providing funding for every new non-government school which opens, regardless of its prospects for future viability and regardless of its impact on existing schools in the region. One really has to question whether the position adopted by the opposition is a sensible use of education dollars, given that they are the same people who have accused this government from time to time of waste and duplication.

I can say to the honourable member for Ballarat that I have found no significant stakeholders in the education area who agree with the position he has adopted. Why should they? They would be faced with a position where non-government schools would come and go in the free market world of coalition education policy.

One could then reasonably ask, `What happens to the students attending a school which does not offer a sufficient range of subjects, becomes non-viable and then closes?' It is an interesting approach by the opposition. The opposition has frequently been accused of lacking policy—that side being a policy free zone. On a number of occasions I have criticised the honourable member for Ballarat and his predecessors for their lack of policy. On this occasion, I have to admit that I am wrong. They have a policy in this area. Their policy is that they will not have a policy. They want to abolish the new schools policy altogether. I hope the honourable member for Ballarat will make a submission to the inquiry if he feels so moved. Perhaps opposition members are finding it a little too hard. Perhaps they are finding that the challenges presented by the changing educational environment which I have described are too demanding to be able to frame a coherent approach aimed at providing quality education for all Australian students.

The honourable member for Ballarat accused the government of strangling growth in the non-government sector. I think he ought to be aware that in this year, in 1995, there are around 2,500 non-government schools in this country and that over the decade the share of total enrolments in the non-government sector has increased from 25.8 per cent in 1985 to 28.5 per cent in 1994. This growth in enrolments is hardly indicative of a policy which is strangling growth.

The honourable member for Ballarat is terribly interested about the timing of the review. I can tell him that the review will have sufficient time to do its job properly and to ensure that all interested parties have the opportunity to make submissions and be consulted in the progress of the review. I will certainly not be instructing the review to hasten its work. It is an important review of a policy which has been in place for almost 10 years. If the member for Ballarat thinks that he can dictate the review timetable and rush its work, he will be sadly mistaken.

In closing I should say something about literacy, because the honourable member for Ballarat did. It is true that the government through this bill is devoting additional resources to early literacy and that it has been very pro-active in the field over the years with a great deal of success. I would be the first to admit that the work we have done in literacy has not been completely successful. It is impossible to ever say that. Certainly in the case of the honourable member for Ballarat it has been less than a complete success. I note that his press release of Tuesday still has punctuation errors, although there are fewer than in early releases. He should be very careful of where he puts the apostrophe in the word `its'.

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments relate to grants to the states. I need to bring the attention of the House to a matter that occurred yesterday and which should be of enormous concern to this House. It is in relation to a response from the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) to a question by the member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland). I will be interested to hear the minister's comments on what I am about to say. I assume he will follow with an apology to this House and to the Victorian government.

PARA.TAB: In answer to the member for Macarthur's question yesterday about state funding in Victoria, the minister stated that Victoria's spending was well below the per student Australian average. The minister is obviously unaware of the difference between per capita and per student. To malign the Victorian government in the way he has done in relation to its spending was a total misrepresentation of the facts. The $538 that the minister referred to was indeed the standardised average, the per capita average, for Australia. It bore no relation to per student spending and therefore the minister's allegation that the Victorian government had reduced its per student funding to schools and was now at the bottom of the pile is totally incorrect and a gross misrepresentation of the true position.

Let us look at the true situation in relation to per capita funding and use the minister's figure of $538. He was using it per student but it is a per capita figure. If we look at the true standardised figures we will see that Victoria is spending well above its standardised per capita amount, according to the Grants Commission. This matter was raised in the Victorian state parliament yesterday. I will read briefly from the speech, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially what the commission does is to establish a standardised expenditure for education for the various states. In doing that the commission takes into consideration a number of factors. So far as Victoria is concerned it takes into consideration, for example, that it is geographically smaller and more densely populated than other states and has fewer problems with remoteness and isolation, its established infrastructure and the age distribution of its population. On that basis the commission's report shows that Victoria's actual spending per capita is $511.18 and the commission's standardised expenditure for Victoria is $476.86.

That is a clear indication that, according to the Grants Commission, the Victorian government is spending more on education than the commission believes it should be. The minister misrepresented the position in this House yesterday. I hope he will apologise.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the voluntary fees?

—It is unrelated to this. You should listen because you were nodding your head in agreement and you are basically wrong. Do not show your ignorance by agreeing with what was said. It is per capita standardised expenditure which is unrelated to per student expenditure. Either the minister was unaware of the difference between per capita and per student—in that case he has been badly advised—or he did it deliberately. I will not say he did it deliberately, because I am sure that is not the situation, but there is an apology due. The graph representing these figures shows that Victoria spends 7.3 per cent more on education, according to the Grants Commission, than it should be spending on education. I seek leave to table the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister. This oversight yesterday—I will put it at its best—was used as a deliberate ploy to denigrate the education system in Victoria. PARA.TAB: I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that per student spending in Victoria, and I quote the minister's words, `is still significantly ahead and is above the Australian average on expenditure per pupil.' TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—This occasion marks the closure of the second reading debate on the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1994, and it follows the referral of the bill to the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities on 8 February of this year. The government thanks the members of the committee for producing a report on the bill in such a timely fashion. Together with the committee, the government acknowledges the efforts of all those who provided submissions to the committee or appeared before it. The committee report deals with a number of concerns about specific provisions which have been raised in the parliamentary debate on the bill or in submissions to the committee. I now table the government's response to the committee report.

PARA.TAB: In these brief remarks, I will just mention two of the main issues arising from the report: the distinction between small and large proprietary companies, and the question of access to debenture registers. One of the key reforms in the bill is to reduce the financial reporting requirements of small proprietary companies. The bill makes the distinction between small and large companies for this purpose by using a three-part objective test which looks at assets, revenue and employees. The committee concluded that, on balance, it preferred the small and large test, as a basis for distinguishing between proprietary companies, to the reporting entity concept advanced by the accounting bodies.

The committee recommended that serious consideration be given to two options: namely, that the employees criteria remain, or that the employees test be deleted from the bill and the test for a small or large proprietary company be on the proposed assets and turnover criteria alone. The current test in the bill is designed to achieve an approximate measure of the company's economic significance. It provides a measure of flexibility which enables the test to be targeted in a manner which seems to the government to be appropriate.

If the bill were to be amended to rely on two criteria alone, it would become a less appropriate test of a company's economic significance and, accordingly, a less appropriate touchstone for the application of corporate financial reporting requirements. Having said that, I advise that the government has noted carefully the committee's comments on these criteria and will keep them under review. If the employees criteria proves to be inappropriate in practice, the government will certainly be prepared to re-examine the issue.

The bill contains important new safeguards to protect the privacy of debenture holders and of other securities holders whose details are shown in registers. The committee provided a full opportunity for both the representatives of the Australian Finance Conference and members of the simplification task force to discuss the rules in the bill on debenture registers.

The committee has not proposed any change to the new protections included in the bill. However, it has recommended that an additional provision should be inserted to give the ASC the same power of exemption as it presently has. The government acknowledges that there are points to be made—both for and against—providing additional restrictions on access to debenture registers, but it has decided to accept the committee's view that the ASC should be able to provide such restrictions as it might consider necessary.

I thank all members who contributed to this debate. The debate was actually conducted some weeks ago in the House, and the matter was then referred to the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. The committee report was a useful addition to the debate. I thank everyone involved. The First Corporate Law Simplification Bill is important legislation. The government will be moving some amendments during the consideration in detail stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we are considering all the amendments together, let me say that, in relation to the work that was undertaken by the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities on the Corporate Law Simplification Bill, the opposition believes that the work that has been done and the amendments that have resulted demonstrate the virtue of having the opportunity to examine important bills of this character. Matters of very real concern were raised by a number of members on this side of the House who have spoken on the bill. As I have said on a number of occasions, it is important to recognise that it is the Senate that has undoubtedly pioneered work in relation to deliberating on legislation.

PARA.TAB: I think that there are more occasions on which the committees of the House ought to be used for such purposes. The government ought to facilitate and accommodate the reference of matters to committees of this House. It not only enhances the outcome but also ensures that there does not develop a view that the only people around this place who are able to add useful comments to and improve bills are senators. I think it is in the interests of members of the House of Representatives to be able to make those contributions.

In this case, of course, it is the work of a joint committee, involving both senators and members of the House of Representatives. I think the value of it can be seen in the fact that the government has accepted a number of the amendments suggested by that committee, in addition to a number of its technical amendments.

To go to the matter that we are discussing—the matter of the reporting entity test versus the test proposed in the bill—the distinction between small and large proprietary companies which will replace the current distinction between exempt and non-exempt companies was the subject of some public comment while the bill was being considered. The Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Australian Society of CPAs came out strongly in favour of the reporting entity test. On balance, the committee concluded that the test proposed in the bill should be adopted, as the reporting entity test does not provide a test of sufficient certainty. The committee was further advised that the distinction made by the bill reflects overseas practice and experience.

There was a question as to whether the criteria proposed in the bill for distinguishing between small and large companies should be adopted in whole or in part. The test proposes that a company move from a small company to large company when it meets two of the following three criteria: more than 50 employees; gross operating revenue of more than $10 million; or assets of more than $5 million. The committee considered that tests of assets and turnover were more important than tests in relation to number of employees.

While the committee was not able to reach an unqualified view on the test, and believes the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) should give serious consideration to whether the 50 employees criteria should be kept or should be deleted, leaving only the tests on assets and turnover, the government, in its response, indicated that it saw the present proposal as being sufficiently flexible to ensure that the test was targeted in a manner which, to the government, seemed to be appropriate. But the government made it quite clear, in the Attorney-General's report:

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, the Government has noted carefully the committee's comments on these criteria and will keep them under review. If the employees criteria proves to be inappropriate in practice, the Government will certainly be prepared to re-examine the issue.
We welcome that commitment. I have mentioned it because we see it as a genuine commitment on the government's part and, if that further examination were required, we would expect that to occur.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the other matters, the only important issue that I would like to advert to is the issue of having the register of debenture holders made public. It was a matter that caused some controversy and debate. Privacy is important. Various companies argued that the provisions could give an unfair advantage to banks, in particular, as such information, in their hands, is not publicly available. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments before the House, as I support the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill. I support the bill because this bill is good for users of the Corporations Law, is good for small business and is good for women. I speak as the chair of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, to which the bill was referred. I believe that the response by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) to the committee's report and the amendment that he has presented today constitute an eminently sensible response to an eminently sensible committee report. The Attorney-General is to be commended for that.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity to briefly go through the formal response the Attorney-General has made and also the amendments. The committee looked at the distinction between small and large proprietary companies and came to the view that on balance the small-large test was a more appropriate and certain test than the reporting entity test, and resolved on balance that two of the three criteria in the bill ought to be adopted as a test. The Attorney-General has indicated that he proposes to stick with that provision which was the on-balance view of the committee. I think that is right for the reason he points out: that test goes to a company's economic significance.

I am pleased to see that the Attorney-General has indicated that he has undertaken to keep those criteria under review and has acknowledged the government's preparedness to re-examine the issue if such reconsideration should become necessary. As far as the debenture registers amendment is concerned, the Attorney-General has picked up the recommendation of the committee, and the committee would certainly welcome that.

One of the other issues which the committee dealt with was the question of the number of shareholders and directors in a proprietary company. The committee's recommendation is that the law should enable proprietary companies to be formed with one director. I say that is good for small business and good for women because it will get over the age-old problem of the difficulty caused by active and passive directors and the issue of sexually transmitted debt, as it has become known, where more often than not the passive director is a spouse or a woman who takes no active involvement in the running of a company, simply signs the accounts, and if all goes wrong—as occasionally it does—is left saddled with the debts of the company. So this bill should avoid that occurring in the future and cut that problem off at source. The Attorney-General has indicated that he believes that change will be widely applauded by the small business community, as it should be.

As far as the auditors of proprietary companies are concerned, another issue raised by the committee, the Attorney-General has indicated that he is pleased to ensure that the working party on simplification and audit gives this issue careful consideration. As far as the incorporation of the proposed small business guide into the bill is concerned, again the committee resolved on balance that that ought to remain part of the law as proposed by the bill. There were some reservations, but in this respect I am in the Attorney-General's camp. I think he is right in stating that legislators ought to be innovative from time to time, but I am also pleased to see that he has picked up the recommendation of the committee that because it is innovative it is an issue that ought to be reviewed, and he has certainly given that undertaking.

The committee also dealt with the question of the ASC's power to require the preparation of financial reports by small companies. The Attorney-General has picked up this particular recommendation and indicated that he is raising it with the chairman of the ASC for a formal response. As chairman of the committee, I know that my personal attitude will not necessarily be shared by all members of the committee. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) has made clear his view on whether proprietary companies ought to be able to be formed with one director, so I am sure the Attorney-General's response will not satisfy him, but as chairman of the committee it certainly satisfies me. I conclude where I started: I support the amendment; it is an eminently sensible response to an eminently sensible committee report and an eminently sensible bill, which will be good for the users of Corporations Law, good for small business and good for women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan Mrs J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share some concerns that my colleague the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) expressed when he spoke on the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1994. My concerns relate to schedule 4, division 5A, subsection (2). This is one of the aspects of this bill that has received only general support. In fact, the committee's report says on page 17 at 2.37:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee has been unable to reach an unqualified view on the test—
this is to do with the test for large and small companies—

and believes that the Attorney-General should give serious consideration to two options, namely that the 50 employees criteria remain, or that the test of more than 50 employees be deleted from the bill and the test for a small/large proprietary company be on the proposed assets and turnover criteria.

I am disappointed and concerned that this section has not had greater consideration. The committee was advised by the corporate law simplification task force that, on the basis of statistics provided by the ASC, 98 per cent of proprietary companies would fall within the small category and that it would be only two per cent of Australian companies that might get caught out having to report when it is not necessary and having to do a full audit report at a high cost of somewhere between $10,000 to $30,000, according to the accounting profession.

PARA.TAB: So this subclause which addresses the distinction between small and large proprietary companies callously disregards the one to two per cent of small and medium sized enterprises which will be disadvantaged by the introduction of this bill in the House today. I am disappointed about that. It is very easy for us to throw figures around like one and two per cent, but when we consider that there are almost 800,000 small businesses in this country that means that 10,000 to 15,000 businesses stand to be disadvantaged by the measure in this bill. That is not good enough. As far as I am concerned, it is a fairly cavalier approach. There is no reason for this to become a problem. There are other ways to deal with this issue. I think it does away with the whole spirit of what this bill is all about—that is, simplifying the Corporations Law. The reason we want to see simplification of corporation law and other laws in relation to small business is to reduce the cost for small business of doing business and improve the profitability of small business, and this simply does not address that issue.

The committee stated in its findings, conclusions and recommendations, on page 33, paragraph 4.3, that the committee has been unable to reach an unqualified view. The members were not able to totally agree. I do not think that the committee fully appreciated or understood the impact that this might have and the fact that that one to two per cent translates into a very large number of small businesses and affects quite a number of people. One has to ask: who is responsible for law making in this country—the elected representatives of this place or the bureaucrats? While I appreciate that the bureaucrats make a powerful and very important contribution to the work of this House, ultimately we are the people's representatives and we are out there understanding day to day the difficulties that people confront as they go about their business.

The flow-on effect of these tests will be to increase the complexity of the law for this group of people; to increase the amount of paperwork and financial reporting required, which no-one is going to be interested in; and to increase the cost to small businesses involved through the cost of unnecessary audit requirements. As I said, it could cost anything from $10,000 to $30,000. This will have the potential to needlessly increase small business costs by millions of dollars. That is not the aim of the corporate law simplification project.

I have had a letter this morning from one of the accounting bodies making the comment that the adverse implications that would flow from the implementation of the size test are that some small companies will escape their reporting obligations; some large companies will be required to needlessly prepare accounts; additional costs will be needed to identify business size; the overturning of the accounting standard for the reporting entity that was developed by the Australian Accounting Standards Board over a period of five years through a rigorous process more complex than the simplification process; it conflicts with the Corporations Law; and simplification simply has not been achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just pick up where I left off. I should have perhaps asked for the matters to be considered separately and then I would not have been interrupted in quite this way. If I can conclude the comments I was making on particularly the debenture matter, we are of the view that, the government having accepted that the ASC should be able to provide restrictions on access to venture registers and an amendment having been moved, it was worthy of support and it will have our support, as I indicated earlier.

PARA.TAB: One of the other matters that I wanted to advert to briefly, which was picked up by the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), was that of the single member companies as proposed under the bill. It would eliminate the silent director who is often the spouse and is often jointly responsible for company failure, even though they may not have been fully involved. That title `sexually transmitted debt' was something that we had noted as well.

In relation to auditors of proprietary companies, while less stringent requirement for appointment of auditors was of concern to the accounting bodies consulted, the committee accepted that that did not require amendment to the bill; rather, that the problem would be addressed by the accounting working party set up under the simplification process. As the government has given a guarantee that the working party will give full consideration to that issue, we welcome that undertaking. I understand that the government has accepted the recommendation from the committee that the inclusion of a small business guide should be reviewed by the Attorney-General after it has been in operation for a reasonable time.

In relation to preparation of final financial reports and the recommendation that the ASC should prepare quarterly reports to the Attorney-General stating its reason for requiring small proprietary companies to prepare accounts, the government has indicated it will raise that matter with the chairman. That is a response that we have noted as well. There were other minor amendments, as outlined by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), and they do not present any difficult to us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all members for their contribution. I think the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill and what it attempts to do is pretty strongly supported by both sides of the parliament.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan) is a fairly harsh taskmaster when it comes to her particular criticisms.Obviously, when we move from a system which is in place to a new system of distinguishing between large and small companies and the sorts of requirements we put on both, some companies which are now enjoying the status of being an exempt proprietary company will be picked up and deemed to be large. But the test does very much target companies in terms of their economic significance. If a company has two of the three requirements—50 employees, an annual turnover of $10 million, and assets of $5 million—it is a relatively large and important commercial concern. I do not know whether it is unreasonable for the community to expect a somewhat more stringent level of disclosure in terms of the financial position and activities of those companies than for the vast majority which will get very great benefit out of this bill.

The figures have been put at 98 per cent to two per cent, so it is the vast majority who are getting a much greater benefit. That is why the bill has been very warmly received by the small business community, at least as far as the views that have been expressed to me are concerned. There will be a small number affected. I do not know whether it is the 15,000 figure. That would be 15,000 companies which probably have more than 50 employees, but they would have to have 50 employees plus meet one of the other two tests as well. So I think it would actually be a figure somewhat less than that.

The other matter which the honourable member for Pearce raised was the reporting entity concept which the accounting bodies are very attached to and have been for some years and which they promote very strongly. In fairness, one has to say that the vast balance of views of people in this area—particularly the lawyers, in terms of the Law Council of Australia, and other advisers concerned with how these things can be made to work in a practical sense—is that the reporting entity concept is not a practical one to put into operation. If we are not now talking about a program, like it or not, the three criteria are at least fairly straightforward and simple and companies will know whether they fall within it or not. The reporting entity concept is a far vaguer concept and, though it has some attractions, in my view and, indeed, in the view of the committee, the proposed tests are the way to go.

These are new changes. It is a new area of law and we are trying some innovative things. As I have indicated, the government will review these changes very closely. We want to try to benefit, and get cost reductions for, business. We want innovative reforms that actually work. Therefore, we will watch this legislation very closely. If it is not working, if there are problems, if the thresholds are impacting on much larger numbers of companies in an adverse way, or if it is not in the public interest for the information to come out, we will change it. We are really trying to do a positive thing here.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many years has it taken to get this bill up?

—Two years, I suppose, since I have been Attorney-General. This was one of my major projects in terms of the simplification of the Corporations Law and it is relatively well advanced. The second stage will come out in a second bill in July. It will mean that, within probably another 18 months or so, the core provisions of the entire Corporations Law would have been rewritten. Quite honestly, I do not know if that is a bad achievement, given the complexity of what we were starting with. I thank members for their contributions and support. This is a good bill, and I commend the amendments to the House.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill (on motion by Mr Lavarch)—by leave—read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSMITTER LICENCE TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1994Cognate bills:RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (RECEIVER LICENCE TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1994RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS TAXES COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 8 March, on motion by Mr Elliott:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to support the amendments that are before the House and I commend the government for them. I must say at the outset that I was surprised at the rather mean spirited remarks of the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), when he was responding on behalf of the opposition to the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott). The member for Goldstein seemed to think that there was something terrible in the fact that the government and the SMA had reconsidered the licensing fee that they were going to charge amateur radio operators. I will come back to that later in my contribution, but it is worth while putting on the record that the remarks were mean spirited. As members of parliament, rather than attacking the government for responding to people who make representations, we should be commending the government and the government agency, instead of telling them that we are starting to keep a closer eye on them for doing this.

PARA.TAB: These amendments will make it easier for apparatus licensees to pay their licence fees. They will now be able to make those payments annually for an apparatus licence, in instalments if they wish, and licences can be issued for a period of up to five years. That puts a little bit more certainty into these things for the licensees. Licensees will be able to have the choice of paying the total fee for the full period or paying by annual instalments.

Formerly, a default in the payment of a licence fee—which was usually an up-front fee—would have resulted in the suspension or cancellation of a licence. There was no scope to allow a licensee a period of grace in the payment of the fees. Often, people who needed these licences as an integral and ongoing part of their business could have been deprived of them through falling on hard times and suffering cash flow problems. These amendments make it a lot easier for business.

There are amendments which will introduce a system whereby people who default on an annual instalment will only lose their licences as a last resort. Licensees will now be able to pay by instalment, paying interest on the late payment of fees and, if still in default, pay the balance of the licence fee for the entire period. As I said, the licence would only be suspended or cancelled as a last resort.

Those amendments to the bills are the result of a long and detailed public inquiry by the Spectrum Management Agency. In 1993, in response to a report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, chaired by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), the government directed the Spectrum Management Agency to inquire into the restructuring of licence fees for cost recovery. The Spectrum Management Agency released a public discussion paper, held extensive public seminars and consulted with the Wireless Institute of Australia and the Radiocommunications Consultative Council. Over 4,000 submissions were received, and the amendments before us today are among the many key recommendations to emerge from that inquiry.

The SMA plans to begin issuing five-year licences from April this year in line with the commencement of the radcom licensing computer system. It should be emphasised that these bills are intended to give apparatus licensees a choice, and give them flexibility in the way that they obtain their licences. They do not relate at all to the restructuring of the apparatus licence regime fee structure which has caused some concern amongst sections of the community.

As the chairman of the caucus committee on transport and communications I have received representations expressing concern about some aspects of the SMA's draft proposal for the change to the fee structure. With a number of other government members—and also, I understand, some members of the opposition—I have made approaches to the government to have the proposed fee schedule re-examined. Rather than the mean spirited way in which the member for Goldstein addressed this, I would like to commend the Spectrum Management Agency and the parliamentary secretary, because I am pleased to see that the SMA has further considered the level of fees to be applied to amateurs in the light of the public benefit that amateurs provide to the community.

A lower overall fee is now proposed by the SMA in view of the training and the experience in communications technology that amateurs provide to young people, and the role that amateurs provide in maintaining communication links in times of emergency. The SMA has quite rightly decided to reduce the tax component of the licence fee to the minimum level. This will reduce the fee from the proposed $71 to $51 per annum. The fee would be applied to all amateur licences. While $51 represents a small increase on fees paid for many years by amateurs, the new fee is based on the administration and maintenance services provided to this group by the SMA and includes the cost of issuing the licences, managing interference to their services, issuing and registering call signs, accrediting examinations, and representing amateurs' interests in the international negotiations that the government carries on from time to time. It also represents a reduction of $20 from the draft fee which was proposed prior to the most recent round of consultations.

While there are social benefits of amateur radio, the fee set at $51 represents more than fair value for their access to and ongoing use of large amounts of radio frequency spectrum. The important thing is that this reduction in the fee has not been shifted onto others, because the change in the level of amateur fees will not be offset by an increase in the fees paid by other radiocommunications licensees.

I think the parliamentary secretary and the SMA should be commended for taking into account the work that amateurs do, both in times of national emergencies and in providing a very useful network that the community as a whole can take advantage of. People might recall that, during the bushfires in Sydney last year, people in the amateur radio area were involved in helping the State Emergency Service people. I think it was proper and reasonable for the government to take cognisance of the representations that were made, and it was proper and reasonable for the SMA to reflect that element in the fees that it charged.

The changes to the fees for amateur radio operators are part of the broader change to apparatus licences. The fee structure proposal is just one of the results of the inquiry that the SMA conducted for all users of the radio frequency spectrum, not just amateur radio users. The government's objective is to establish an efficient and equitable means of managing this vital national resource. It is a resource that all Australians ought to share in, through the licensing of the spectrum. The changes to apparatus licences are designed to reduce the number of categories of licences, and to provide for a more equitable distribution of the charges that are already made for the use of the spectrum.

The proposals put forward by the Spectrum Management Agency suggest fees based on a combination of the costs of administration and the value of the part of the spectrum being used. This method of charging is in line with the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, in which both the government and the opposition participated.

Up until now, as honourable members would know, fees and categories of licensed radiocommunication equipment have developed in an ad hoc fashion, over time, with little relationship between the fees charged for the spectrum used and the value of that spectrum. The cost to the Commonwealth of the administration and use of the public resource of the radio frequency spectrum should be reflected clearly in the pricing structure. That was one of the key findings of the public inquiry.

Using this method, fees for some categories may rise, while some fees will fall. However, it should be stressed that no overall variation in revenue is being proposed. Fee concessions will be available to non-profit voluntary apparatus licensees who are primarily providing safety or human life services, such as rural firefighting and sea rescue. In broad terms, local governments and state governments could expect to benefit from the restructuring of the fees. Small businesses, such as taxi services and paging services, are also likely to see fee reductions.
