Given that the ABC was the only one of the three licensees that received a licence without paying any funds to the taxpayer, and without having to go through an option process, I thought that the least we could do was impose certain minimum standards of Australian content on the two ABC channels.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister. What are the implications for Australian families of the excellent employment growth reflected in today's statistics?

—The question goes to the links between employment and Australian families. It is a very important question because, as was pointed out by the Treasurer and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, alongside this incredible achievement of 560,000 jobs in two years we have an historically high level of participation rate. That historically high level of participation rate underlines the fact that during the 1980s and into the 1990s we saw quite fundamental social changes occurring in Australia; changes that will have quite profound effects on Australian families.

PARA.TAB: It is very important in the context of this parliament because one of the things that divides us from those on the other side of the House is that members of the opposition tend to be more socially conservative. It is such social conservatism that often means that, in terms of debate about policy, those opposite are not able to grasp the meaning of statistics. What these figures actually mean is that levels of participation, as we suggested, if applied in 1983-84—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are right, Brian. The meaning does allude everybody.

PARA.TAB: Nr SPEAKER—Order! Those on my left. The member for Mayo!

TALK.START.PARA: —Eric understand all of that!

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker—The Leader of the Opposition is not assisting.

TALK.START.PARA: —At that time we were talking about unemployment of around 3.8 per cent if we had today's levels of participation. In terms of the implications for the way that the social security system is structured, that meant that the social security system had to, in a sense, be turned outward towards the labour market. Many of the reforms that were carried out in the late 1980s in terms of the so-called active society model have now been proven, in this period of strong recovery, to be quite fundamental in assisting particularly women back into the work force.

PARA.TAB: The reforms represented by the white paper together with a more incentive based social security system have meant that there were much stronger resources for people to enable them to get the training and the skill enhancement necessary. Again we have seen a quite marked impact, which again explains the rather faster achievement in employment growth than, for example, was achieved coming out of the 1983 recession.

In the numbers today, we see evidence of a dramatic decrease in the number of married couple families who had an unemployed member. I point to one statistic that illustrates the success of a combination of policy. We have seen over the same 12-month period the number of sole parent families, arguably the group most disadvantaged, with employed members increase by 180,000. That is quite a massive improvement and that is what comes from the emphasis this government has placed on child care—253,000 places—and on programs like JET where 46,000 jobs for sole parents were created as a result of that program alone.

I emphasise these points because, fundamentally, they are the difference between a government that has policy integrity and looks at the interrelationship between different elements of policy and an opposition that is increasingly negative, increasingly cynical, fundamentally opportunistic and could never achieve reforms of the dimension that this government has achieved. That is why—let me go to the OECD, and I have been and chaired conferences in the OECD—Australia, comparatively speaking, does better in these areas than any other country in the OECD.

We do well because there is integrity in terms of our policy, because there are links across different elements of policy and because, fundamentally, the government recognises that the issue of employment—the Leader of the Opposition speaks about it almost casually, with no substance, and says it is important—is important. The government has demonstrated in the 560,000 jobs it has created in two years—this is more than rhetoric; this is substance—that these are outcomes that illustrate how effectively we have worked in this very important area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Do you still maintain that a senior executive of the Packer organisation informed the Prime Minister that Mr Packer and the Leader of the Opposition have a secret deal to change Australia's media ownership laws? Do you still maintain this or do you not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lee The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday I said that I was aware of information which I believe links the Leader of the Opposition to the allegations which the Prime Minister has put forward. That information came from the Packer camp and I was told by them that the Liberal Party had indicated to them that they would—
—By whom?

—Let me repeat: that information came from the Packer camp and I was told by them that the Liberal Party had indicated to them that they would relax the cross-media ownership rules. In the last week the Leader of the Opposition and Senator Alston have both declined to deny that. If you read very carefully the statements which have been made by Mr Packer, Mr Barron and Mr Richardson, you will see none of them has denied it. That is why those of us on this side of the House have called on the Leader of the Opposition and Senator Alston to tell us what they have said to Mr Packer and his executives in private, and that is why we are suspicious when on 13 occasions the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition—
—Look at this report.
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition knows better.

—We have every right to ask these questions when the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition on 13 occasions this week have declined to indicate whether they think it is undesirable for Mr Packer to own Fairfax and Channel 9. You can tell us right now: are you opposed to Mr Packer owning Channel 9 and Fairfax? Yes or no.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Silence. That is no surprise. When asked whether they are in favour of Mr Packer owning Fairfax and Channel 9, the answer is silence. That is no wonder. On A Current Affair last night Mr Ray Martin, a good interviewer, asked John Howard:

ANSWER.PARA: Let's forget personalities. Should any man or woman own a television network in Australia and also the major publishing group?
Mr Howard: Well, it depends entirely on what other players in all of the media markets are. It depends on a whole range of factors.
Here is the best line of all:
I'm not going to say yes or no to that question.

`Why should I,' said the Leader of the Opposition. Why should the Leader of the Opposition feel under any pressure at all to tell us whether Australia's richest man, the man who controls the most popular television network, should also own the most influential newspapers? Apparently this is an issue which is of no importance whatsoever to the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it is.

—It is your credibility that is on the line because you will not tell us what you have said to Mr Packer, and Senator Alston will not tell us what he said to the executives at PBL in his many and numerous conversations with the people at Park Street. That is what is exposing you.

PARA.TAB: For those reasons, we have demonstrated that this government stands by the cross-media ownership laws. We think the cross-media ownership laws promote diversity of ownership and plurality of opinion. The question for you is: why is your opinion today different from what it was in 1991?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. In the hope the minister might have some evidence, I invite him to table those notes from which he was quoting.
—I think it is more in hope. Was the minister quoting from private documents?
—Personal documents, Mr Speaker.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the minister aware of alternative options for regulating industrial relations? Can the minister advise the House whether the government has embraced any of those options? What are the government's intentions with regard to regulating industrial relations in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker—
—That's easy. You hand it over to the union movement. Pull a bag over your head.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor!

—I thank the honourable member for his question and indicate to him and the House that I am aware of reports of approaches to industrial relations that involve the stripping away of the award safety net or, alternatively, allowing for conditions to be negotiated away. Under the government's Industrial Relations Reform Act, workers are guaranteed a comprehensive safety net, regardless of whether they are in existing employment or commencing a new job.

PARA.TAB: In contrast, under the opposition's Jobsback, we see guarantees only of four miserly conditions: annual leave, four weeks; two weeks non-cumulative sick leave; a minimum hourly rate of pay, not a weekly rate or an annual rate; and unpaid maternity leave. No-one is going to be fooled by that approach and the opposition's attempts to hide the consequences of its Jobsback policy. Opting out offers new employees only those same four miserly conditions, those same four miserable provisions.

Jobsback does not so much as say what the minimum hourly rate will actually be. All the member for Flinders keeps saying is, `That's a matter of detail. We'll get to it one day.' We are asking: just when are we going to see that detail? When are we going to have revealed to the people of Australia what that minimum rate will be?

If we look to the New Zealand system, which is a system the member for Flinders has waxed lyrical about and is on the public record and the record of this House on many occasions as praising, we see well illustrated the consequences of going down the Jobsback path. We now have on the public record the analysis of Professor Harbridge of New Zealand's Victoria University, who has published an analysis of his country's Employment Contracts Act—that is, the Employment Contracts Act for which you have been full of praise.

That analysis shows that, under that system, women in New Zealand have fared far worse than men. Women have been the principal losers. They get lower wage increases; they have suffered even bigger reductions in overtime rates and in penalty rates than have men in comparable jobs in New Zealand. Members of the House will be interested to know that Professor Harbridge found that new workers in New Zealand are now being offered lower pay and conditions than existing employees. What that means is that in New Zealand you have a system of industrial apartheid.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are following New Zealand now, are we?
—You have a division.
—Oh, I see.

—You have women on the one hand being exploited under the Employment Contracts Act and you have workers working alongside each other doing an exact equivalent job and performing the same duties getting different rates of pay. That is exactly what jobsback promises Australian workers. Back in 1992 the member for Flinders stood in this House and said:

ANSWER.PARA: For all the Government's silly scare campaigns, the truth is that in New Zealand people are actually better off.

That is what he asserted here, and that is what he genuinely believes. He has never stepped away from that. He has always believed it. He believes it today. In spite of all the facts on New Zealand, he believes that people will be better off under that system. We know for a fact that they are not better off, and we know for a fact that Australian workers will not have a bar of this system.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, on Monday you said that there was firm evidence of a secret deal between Mr Packer and me and that `it was dead right that the Prime Minister had received this secret evidence from inside the Packer camp.' I emphasise the word `evidence'. On Tuesday you categorically refused to detail either the alleged secret evidence or your supposed sources from inside the Packer camp. Yesterday you spinelessly refused to appear here to back up your baseless allegations, and your hapless Leader of the House had to shut down debate to protect you from being brought in here to apologise for your false, unfounded and totally cowardly claims. Today is your last opportunity this week to emerge with any credibility at all. Today is your last opportunity to apologise. Today is your last opportunity to admit that you were dead wrong. Will you now admit that you were dead wrong and that you made a baseless, unsubstantiated allegation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lee The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This case is like a steam train: it has built up its momentum. They have programmed him with the questions and he cannot stop. He has to read them out as he goes through.
—Answer the question!
—Where is your evidence?
—Order! The minister has the call.
—On Monday you put out a press release saying that your position on cross-media ownership had not changed since 1987. Do you remember that?
—You are telling lies. You are.
—This is the man who goes by the title of honest John; the man whose credibility is of such importance to him; the man who misled people at his press release on Monday.
—You are lying. You are lying.
—You told a lie on Monday in your press release.

—Order! The minister will resume his seat. I again say to members on both sides of this place that there is unparliamentary language which is not permitted. Do not put me in a position to have to adjudicate on that yet again. The minister will withdraw what he said. I appeal to members on my left to be careful in what they are saying.
—Mr Speaker, I withdraw the word `lie' and insert the word `untruth' as long as—and I appeal to you, Mr Speaker—
—Withdraw unequivocally.
—I withdraw unequivocally. The Leader of the Opposition distributed an untruth in his press release when he claimed that his position had not changed since 1987.
—Where is your evidence?
—Where is my evidence? You put out a statement saying that your view had not changed since 1987. As Ray Martin pointed out last night in his interview on A Current Affair—
—He is the witness now, is he?

—We are going to make a lot of use of Ray Martin because it was one of the worst performances that you have given for years. Ray Martin reminded all of the viewers out there of the petition which the Leader of the Opposition signed to the Prime Minister. The petition stated:

ANSWER.PARA: We respectfully ask you to oppose the sale of the Fairfax Group to any individual or consortium that would result in a greater concentration of media ownership.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is your evidence?
—The Leader of the Opposition is not helping.

—That was drafted by the honourable member for Bradfield with a bit of help from the honourable member for Canberra. It was signed by the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and half the people sitting on that side of the chamber. All of those people believe that Mr Packer should not be allowed to buy Fairfax. When it was put to the Leader of the Opposition by Ray Martin on A Current Affair last night, how did the Leader of the Opposition equate his claim that his position has never changed with the fact that he signed the petition?
—You dishonest man.
—Where is your evidence?
—Order! Those on my left!
—This is what happened. Ray Martin said to John Howard:

ANSWER.PARA: Well, I wasn't the Leader of the Opposition then.
But wait, there is more. He went on to say:
I wasn't the spokesman on communications. I went along as a team player. I went along with the opposition's situation.

PARA.TAB: Government members—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right!

—So, apparently, in the world of the Leader of the Opposition, it does not matter what you say about cross-media ownership. It does not matter if you tell Mr Packer to abolish the cross-media ownership rules. It does not matter what you say about cross-media ownership as long as you are not the Leader of the Opposition or the spokesman on communications. You were exposed last night and you know it.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, and refers to the handling of secret Aboriginal documents.
—You should learn from your mistakes, John.
—Order! Your colleague is trying to be heard.
—I ask the minister: what has been the reaction of Aboriginal women to the mishandling of secret documents regarding the Hindmarsh Island bridge proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Oxley for his question. He has a very deep personal commitment to the rights of Aboriginal people and Aboriginal women in particular. The actions of the member for Barker, supported very actively by the member for Hindmarsh, have caused great disquiet, hurt and sadness to Aboriginal people in South Australia, particularly Aboriginal women. The hurt suffered by those women is being felt in Aboriginal communities around the length and breadth of this country. Such is the seriousness of the action of the member for Barker, supported by the member for Hindmarsh.

PARA.TAB: In response to the honourable member's question, yesterday I sought to make it very clear what the role of the member for Hindmarsh was in these very serious matters, and how her own conduct as the shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs had contributed to that suffering of Aboriginal women. I made it clear how she had worked in a tag team, in collaboration with the member for Barker, and how they had both known when the matters were raised in the parliament that the documents to be tabled here were going to cause such suffering to Aboriginal women.

When I made those concerns public yesterday, I was supported by Aboriginal women who have been deeply involved in this current issue. The Aboriginal Legal Rights Movement in South Australia put out a media release, which stated:

ANSWER.PARA: If . . . shadow minister . . . genuinely concerned about Aboriginal people . . . particularly Aboriginal women—why didn't she demand that Mr McLachlan . . . return the box and the envelope and make an immediate public apology for the unlawful copying?

What we then saw from the member for Hindmarsh was not some attempt to try to set the record straight, but an admission that she was in complicity with the member for Barker; that she knew, when she came into this chamber and embarked upon that tag team series of questions to me, what the member for Barker had, and she ought to have known if she had any sensitivity of the great hurt that that was to cause to Aboriginal women. What she has done as the shadow minister is not utter one word of criticism—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is next?
—I will come to you in a moment. What the member for Hindmarsh has done is not utter one word of criticism of the member for Barker—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left might not encourage the minister.

—But as the shadow minister, the person charged on the opposition side of this House for defending Aboriginal rights and speaking up for Aboriginal people, instead, she has supported the member for Barker in every public statement that she has made. She voted to support his conduct on the floor of this House—
—Of course she would.
—Her position is, as I made clear, absolutely untenable.
—Where do you sit with Graeme Campbell?
—It is no wonder that pressure is building and will continue to build—
—The member for O'Connor.
—either for her resignation or for the Leader of the Opposition to remove her from her position.
—Go on; what a rabbit you are.

—This matter went further because yesterday the member for Hindmarsh, in her defence—the only defence that she put forward—instead of doing what I have suggested would be the honourable thing—put out a media release headed—can you believe this—
—What about Graeme Campbell?
—Come on, Wilson. You are not going to put up with this, are you?
—It is a good question.
—Well, go on with it.
—I will. Give me a—
—Order! The member for Burke and the member for O'Connor have both been called to order this afternoon. I now formally warn both of you.

—Yesterday, instead of doing the honourable thing, the right thing and the noble thing, she put out a media release—can you believe this—headed `Serious questions about Tickner's behaviour'. That is the defence for the member for Hindmarsh.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —What she said compounded the hurt to Aboriginal women that the member for Oxley has raised in his question. She said of me that the minister must answer the following questions: firstly, why were the documents in the possession of white, non-Aboriginal males? I am happy to answer the question. Because the member for Barker put them in those hands.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—The second question of this epic defence: why did the minister not keep the documents safe? Answer: because the member for Barker took them and copied them. This is an issue that will not go away. This affair puts the jobs of these two shadow ministers irrevocably on the line. The Leader of the Opposition has only one role to play in this matter. Yesterday, despite the censure motion—
—Ha, ha. You weren't even here yesterday.

—Despite the censure motion, in the debate on the land fund bill the member for Barker said in the Hansard at page 1799, that this box of materials, before it went to his office for copying—this is what he said:

ANSWER.PARA: speaking of me. He went on to say that it went to the minister's office—speaking of me—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order of relevance. The minister knows, as you know, Mr Speaker, that this matter is still being looked at and already the minister has made some errors. I ask you to get him to desist in going on with this stuff that he knows is subject to evaluation.
—Order! There is no point of order, but the minister might draw his answer to a close. I think he has been given some discretion in this matter.
—I will conclude, referring back to the great hurt that was caused to Aboriginal women.
—Come on; sit down.
—Order! The minister is drawing his answer to a close.
—What the member for Barker has said in relation to this matter is:

ANSWER.PARA: received and photocopied a box of documents which also included the contents of secret letters containing women's business.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is bringing it to a close, is he?
—I am. He said this yesterday in a media release. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: The secret letters arrived in an unsealed envelope without any markings on the outside.
I pose this question, and this is what Aboriginal women—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on. Wind up.
—The minister will wind up.
—Wind him up.
—He is.
—I pose the question: if the letters—
—Come on; sit him down.
—He has indicated he is winding up; and he is.

—If I can be allowed to be heard: I pose two simple questions. One is that if the letters were in an unmarked and unsealed envelope and were not read, how were they identified? I am holding the original envelope.
—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. Question time is for the opposition to ask questions of the government; not the other way around. Could you please sit this person down immediately?
—I have already ruled on that. The member for Warringah will resume his seat. The minister has, I think—
—I have one more sentence. I finish on this one note—
—Oh, Mr Speaker!
—No, no, he is finishing.

—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker, under whatever standing order relates to your authority as the Presiding Officer of this parliament. On what basis do you expect your authority to be maintained when on three occasions you ask the minister to come to a conclusion and on all of those occasions he completely ignores you?
—He has finished his answer; but I do so on the basis that, if the minister had been allowed to speak without interruption, he would have concluded a lot earlier.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that the envelope the minister was flashing around be tabled.
—Come on; table it.
—The minister is tabling the document.
—Table it!
—Order! I think the minister is trying to say he is going to table it.
—I am quite happy to table it but I ask the opposition leader when he learnt of the member for Barker's conduct. It is a simple question.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR COMMUNICATIONS AND THE ARTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Costello) proposed:

That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Deputy Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith that this House censures the Minister for Communications and the Arts for:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1) making unfounded and false allegations that the Leader of the Opposition entered into a secret deal with Mr Kerry Packer to change Australia's media ownership laws;

(2) wilfully and falsely asserting that a senior executive of Mr Packer's had told the Prime Minister of the supposed deal asserting he knew the identity of that person and the substance of his claims;
(3) attempting to aid and abet the deceit of the Prime Minister on the subject by repeating baseless claims of the Prime Minister which he knew to be false;
(4) failing to detail any evidence in support of the alleged conspiracy to this House and attempting to mislead it into believing the falsehood;
(5) refusing to apologise to the Leader of the Opposition and the House for his smears and misconduct;
(6) failing to competently discharge his duties as a Minister of the Crown and a Member of this House.

PARA.TAB: Mr Beazley—We accept the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

PARA.TAB: Mr Reith—I second the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative, with an absolute majority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House censures the Minister for Communications and the Arts for:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) making unfounded and false allegations that the Leader of the Opposition entered into a secret deal with Mr Kerry Packer to change Australia's media ownership laws;

(2) wilfully and falsely asserting that a senior executive of Mr Packer's had told the Prime Minister of the supposed deal asserting he knew the identity of that person and the substance of his claims;
(3) attempting to aid and abet the deceit of the Prime Minister on the subject by repeating baseless claims of the Prime Minister which he knew to be false;
(4) failing to detail any evidence in support of the alleged conspiracy to this House and attempting to mislead it into believing the falsehood;
(5) refusing to apologise to the Leader of the Opposition and the House for his smears and misconduct;
(6) failing to competently discharge his duties as a Minister of the Crown and a Member of this House.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has never been the same since Mr Kerry Packer went on television and made certain statements. Mr Packer was asked about the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), and he said:
He's been around for a long time. I think he's a decent man. I think he's an honest man and I think he's a man who has seen the mistakes made and I don't think he will make them again.

That was an objective statement of an observer of Australian politics. All Mr Packer said in that statement was what the rest of Australia already knew; that the Leader of the Opposition is a decent man and that the Leader of the Opposition is an honest man. But that statement of what the whole of Australia knew drew the Prime Minister into a fury. The Prime Minister came back and made a statement that no-one else in Australia knew. He made an allegation that he knew something the rest of Australia did not.

PARA.TAB: He alleged, in a calculated, specific, dishonest and deceitful allegation, that this statement was made because a secret deal existed between the Leader of the Opposition and Mr Packer. It was a calculated, specific, dishonest and deceitful allegation. The Prime Minister, after failing to detail his allegations to this House, after having the opportunity to come into this House and submit himself to questioning, hopped on a jet and hotfooted it over to Singapore. It was no accident that in Singapore he returned to the theme. As Laurie Oakes reports in this week's Bulletin, there he was, down the back of the plane, trying to incite the journalists to write this up. There he was, down the back of the plane, engaging in smear, innuendo, falsehood and lies. He knew that it was false. He knew that he could not substantiate it. He had, cowardly, not come into this House and made the allegations; he went down the back of the plane and tried to seed them in the journalists' minds. Mr Keating claimed to those journalists, as reported by Laurie Oakes in the Bulletin:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . he's told the Packer camp and the Packer camp have told me.

That was the allegation. He was not trying to base it, as the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) now is, on statements that were in the public domain. It was not enough for Mr Keating to say that the Leader of the Opposition had a genuine view about cross-media ownership. It was not enough to debate the merits, as you are now trying to do, little Sir Echo; be careful. He had to allege a conspiracy and he had to allege a first-hand witness to that conspiracy.

PARA.TAB: Little Sir Echo did not take long to take up the chant: `War is peace; black is white; the Prime Minister is always right.' But the trouble was that the Prime Minister was in a different time zone. So as the chant came from the Prime Minister and was echoed back in Australia, it became increasingly out of date. I wonder how he felt, after he said that, yes, there was a senior executive in the Packer camp who had given this information to the Prime Minister, when he woke up on Wednesday, 8 March, 1995 and read the headline on the front page of the Australian: `Richardson denies Packer, Howard deal'. I wonder how he felt when the godfather of his own faction, former senator Graham Richardson, walked away from him? I wonder how he felt when Peter Barron, the great strategist of the Labor Party, walked away from him? I wonder how he felt when the senior executives denied the substance of this claim? I wonder how he felt when Mr Packer denied the substance of the claim? I know how he felt when the Leader of the Opposition denied the substance of the claim: he felt caught, and he was.

To believe this minister, Mr Packer is a liar, the Leader of the Opposition is a liar, Mr Barron is a liar, former senator Graham Richardson is a liar, and the only person who tells the truth is Paul Keating. That is the substance of his position: Mr Packer is a liar; the Leader of the Opposition is a liar; Mr Barron is a liar; former senator Graham Richardson is a liar; and the only person who tells the truth is the Prime Minister. Well, who would want to be in a situation like that? And he knows it is false. He knows this was a smear which he himself walked into. If I were the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), I would be briefing him overtime right now. Send him back; make sure that you give him all the lines. People sometimes have to realise in life that they are not up to it, and this minister is one such person. It should be remembered that before he was appointed to the position of minister for communications he had that moment of self-realisation. He said, `I don't know that I'm up to it.' He said, `I don't know that I'm up to making tough decisions.' He said, `I'm not sure I have demonstrated yet that I'm good enough to be a minister handling difficult issues.' Let me tell you, old son: we're sure. We're absolutely sure that you have not demonstrated that you are a minister that can handle difficult issues.

I made some inquiries of the Labor Party. I asked: `How is it that this minister became the minister for communications? How did he get the appointment?' Do you know what I was told? I was told that, if it had not been him, the minister for communications would have been David Beddall.
Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —It's true! His great qualification for office is that he is not David Beddall. Let us not overlook this qualification. This is a significant qualification, but not a sufficient one.

PARA.TAB: However, the frightening thing is that here is somebody who it was assumed would always be under adult supervision in that post—adult supervision from the Prime Minister himself. But, when the merchant of venom, the Prime Minister, took off on that flight to Singapore, to Bonn and to Hanover—to make his smears in Singapore, his abuse in Bonn and his claims in Hanover—it really reminded me of the movie Home Alone. He left the minister for communications home alone, without adult supervision.

We know that this minister has a great interest in the Australian film industry. In fact, from listening to him, one would think he just about directed, wrote and starred in the movie Priscilla. Actually, there is another movie coming up which has been made by Film Australia, in which they will offer him the star title role, to be called `Whoops, Mum, I shot my baby-sitter'. Here we have the minister for communications sitting in Australia, without adult supervision, trying to deal with these sorts of allegations and the best that he can do is echo—little Sir Echo—the allegations of the Prime Minister.

Before I move off his second role as minister for the arts, I just want to draw the attention of the House to the report of the Australian Children's Television Foundation for 1993-94. On the front cover is a group of children. One of them is wearing a fireman's hat. The one that is wearing the fireman's hat in fact is fireman Lee. It looks very much like the minister. Do you know what I think? I think that the other children are saying to him, `What do you want to be when you grow up?'

TALK.START.PARA: —A liar!
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will withdraw that comment. I have already made a comment today about unparliamentary language.
—I withdraw.

—The tragic thing is that the only thing he wanted to be when he grew up was a fireman, but Paul Keating made him minister for communications. That is the tragic thing. After all of the damage that you have done and all of the damage that you have attempted to do to the Leader of the Opposition, there is an opportunity for you to show your mettle. There is an opportunity for you to come in here and prove that you are up to ministerial office. There is an opportunity for you to show that you can be a minister. Sure, you may never be more than a mediocre, middle-of-the-road minister, but you could get there if you admitted the truth. All you have to say is, `There was no deal.' Each one of your statements has made it clear that you have no evidence. All you have to do is say, `I did not have the evidence.' All you have to do is say, `I have no information.' All you have to do is say, `I dug myself in because I was trying to defend the Prime Minister in relation to an unfounded allegation, and I apologise.' All you have to do is say, `I will from now on make my own judgments, be my own minister, be my own man and deal with policy.' But, if you fail to do that, if even at this late hour you cannot do that, then the facts are clear: you cannot be trusted with a sensitive portfolio. You cannot be trusted to deal with the precise evidence that is required in that position. You cannot be trusted to deal with the nuances, fineness and technicalities of that portfolio and you are not up to the job of minister for communications. That is the tragedy for Australia. In the interview on PM you had the opportunity to make that clear. You were asked about these allegations of the Prime Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: LYNDALL CURTIS: Mr Lee, are you aware of the evidence Paul Keating says he has that a deal has been done?
MICHAEL LEE: I along with a number of other people are certainly aware of information which we believe links Mr Howard to the allegations which the Prime Minister has put forward.
LYNDALL CURTIS: Is this information that has come from the Packer camp?
MICHAEL LEE: And that's dead right.
And further down he says:
. . . If the person who passed on the information to the Prime Minister was in a position to know, then I think it's pretty firm evidence.
LYNDALL CURTIS: And you believe they were in a position to know?
MICHAEL LEE: Absolutely.

Do not stand up here and say `A petition was signed in 1991' or `Something was said in the paper last week' or `Ray Martin said on A Current Affair last night'—you made a highly specific allegation. Your allegation was not that the Leader of the Opposition did not believe in the current state of media ownership laws. Your allegation was not that the Leader of the Opposition was considering his position on cross-media ownership laws.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is what the Leader of the Opposition said on A Current Affair. It is what he said.

—Your allegation was that there was a deal, because it was not enough for you and it was not enough for the Prime Minister to actually debate this issue on its merits. I will tell you why: it would not have explained the Packer statement.

PARA.TAB: The Packer statement was what started the whole thing. The Prime Minister had to have, for his own conscience, some explanation as to how an independent businessman in this country would come to the conclusion that the Leader of the Opposition was honest—a conclusion that most of Australia has come to. It was not enough to talk about the need to change cross-media ownership rules. You made a specific allegation. It is an allegation that you are now walking away from.

The fact is that we know it is false and you know it is false. That is why you will not repeat it. How many times have we asked you to get up here and repeat it? You will have 20 minutes shortly. All I want to hear from you is this: the Prime Minister was told by a senior executive who holds the position of? His name is? On such and such a date he told the Prime Minister that the deal was? That media ownership laws would be changed in return for? That is all you have to say. If you fail to do that, you are effectively walking away from yourself. That is the reality.

Why do we believe this is important? I will tell you why we believe this is important. We are sick of a Prime Minister who engages in smear and lie. We are sick of a Prime Minister who comes up with outrageous allegations, puts them out into the public domain, lets the smear stick, and before he can ever be harnessed with the truth moves on to the next one. It is the age old trick. You cannot catch up with the last smear because he is already on to the next one, and by the time you try to nail that one he has gone on to the one after that.

Do you remember the performance that started all of this off on the Channel 9 program? I can remember it very well. I was mowing my lawn one Saturday afternoon when my wife said, `Mr Laurie Oakes is on the phone.' I got on the phone and Mr Oakes said, `I have just had a request from the Prime Minister who wants to knock you off the Sunday program tomorrow because he has got something big to announce.' The Prime Minister went on the Sunday program. Do you know what he announced? He made an announcement not in relation to the Leader of the Opposition, the state of the economy, the current account deficit, rising interest rates, the plight of home buyers or the gap between the rich and the poor. None of those things were on his mind. The only thing that was on his mind was this intense hatred that he has when people disagree with him.

But it is more than that. This is not just about Kerry Packer; this is a determined effort by the Prime Minister to send a message to the businesses of Australia that anybody who dares to criticise him can expect government retribution. That is the bottom line of this campaign. If you are a big businessman like Kerry Packer you might be able to look after yourself, but if you are not, if you dare to stand up, if you dare to make some honest comments, if you dare to say `The emperor has no clothes', he says, `I will turn the full forces of my lie machine back on to you.' That is the bottom line of this campaign. That is the campaign of the merchant of venom who, for 12 years, has been practising smear, innuendo and lie. This has been the successive campaign over years.

On that program, he made one of the most unbelievable allegations you have ever heard in your life: Mr Kerry Packer was engaged in a scam in which Murray Farquhar attempted to take gold bars from the Philippines national bank. He is comparing Mr Packer to Murray Farquhar. It was not even the worst scam of Murray Farquhar. That might have been a bad scam of Murray Farquhar, but he was involved in one which was much worse. You know what it was too. Murray Farquhar's greatest scam was not trying to take gold bars out of the Philippines; Murray Farquhar's greatest scam was in August 1975 discharging one Laurie Brereton on bribery and conspiracy charges. That was his greatest scam. I can imagine Laurie Brereton when he came up over bribery charges on the Botany council and they said to him, `Murray's got the case. Wasn't that a lucky deal?' Murray Farquhar got the case, and that was the outcome in 1975.

But what did that have to do with media ownership laws? You tell me. What was the substance of that allegation? It came back, as you knew it would, to this persistent campaign. We are seeing it in relation to Mr Packer. We saw it in relation to Du Pont when it was reported on the front page of the Australian Financial Review. We have seen it from other employer groups. We saw it in relation to the HIA. We saw it in relation to the ACCI. This is a concerted campaign to blacken the name of anybody who dares stand up to the Prime Minister and his pretensions.The tragedy for you is that you have been caught up in the wake of this, little Sir Echo. The tragedy for you is that you have become part of this web of deceit. The tragedy for you is that, without adult supervision, you have been pulled in.

As I said in the House the other day, why is it that the Prime Minister always accuses others of conspiring against him? Why is it that there is always a deal going on? I will tell you why: because this Prime Minister always accuses others of the standard of behaviour that he has himself. He could not conceive of the possibility that anybody could ever say a nice thing about a politician without having some quid pro quo. Why is that? Because nobody could say anything nice about the Prime Minister without some kind of quid pro quo.

If we are talking about cross-media laws, you might actually deal with the allegations that are made in the Shawcross book. It was the Prime Minister who made the cross-media laws. It was the Prime Minister who just happened to deliver laws that created the same situation as Alan Ramsey reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 8 March 1995. Alan Ramsey states:

And nobody was more single-minded in never offending either media baron than was the Honourable Member for Blaxland. Keating would often boast in private it was he who "made Kerry his first billion" by his architecture of Labor's cross-media rules in the mid-1980s . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Now we find that these cross-media rules are somehow designed to make sure that you do not get too much wealth or power or money. The fact was that they were orchestrated for the reverse. The fact was that the Prime Minister was the architect. The fact is that the Prime Minister made unfounded allegations. The fact is that you were caught up in them. The fact is that you are part of them. The fact is that you ought to be censured by this House for your disgraceful smear and unfounded allegations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee The Hon M.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LEE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts and Minister for Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) does not take this opportunity to speak in this debate. Have you noticed the Leader of the Opposition has squibbed the debate? He is not prepared to come forward to speak because he was exposed today at question time. I move:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "this House censures the Leader of the Opposition for his reversal of his media policy against media concentration and his refusal to state his policy towards the current threats to the cross-media ownership rules. The House further notes that the Opposition confusion on this matter comes against a background of the Government's success in achieving record job growth and the Opposition Leader's own dereliction in dealing with front bench colleagues who steal documents related to court cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I invite you to address the content of that amendment and the fact that, firstly, it deals with two subjects and, secondly, the last part of the amendment, as read to the House by the minister, reflected on the member for Barker in a way which, if he wishes to proceed down that path, he ought do by separate substantive motion. As such, I believe the amendment should be ruled out of order.

—Whilst the deputy leader was speaking in this debate this afternoon, I took the opportunity to refer to House of Representatives Practice. I draw the attention of the Leader of the National Party to page 363. Reading that, I think that the proposal as put forward by the minister is in order; but I will be listening closely to the comments, particularly in relation to that last part of the motion.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the standing orders provide that amendments are only dealt with by the House when they are admissible. They have to deal with the subject matter, and in this case you have a very serious motion against the Minister for Communications and the Arts. You have a direct opposite now: you have an attempt by the government to move a censure motion against the Leader of the Opposition. Sir, the standing orders are quite clear that that sort of amendment is not admissible under standing orders. I ask you, Sir, to reflect on your ruling.

—There is no point of order. I have ruled on that but I would also say to the honourable member for Indi, because I think he is genuinely concerned about this, that there are precedents for this. There was one, I think, in September last year when the same particular motion was then introduced, and there are other precedents. On that basis, I am allowing it.

—Mr Speaker, the opposition's motion was moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), the man who was hoist on his own petard on Tuesday when he went on the ABC. The honourable member for Higgins went on the program AM and, when he was asked whether he would allow Mr Packer to own both Fairfax and Channel 9, he made the following comment:

SPEECH.PARA: Look, what we've always said is that we want strong anti-monopolistic laws run by the Trade Practices Commission. And we're opposed to market monopolisation always, always.

The problem for the member for Higgins is that was a deliberate misleading of all of the people who were listening to AM that morning because the honourable member for Higgins, as the shadow attorney-general in 1992, led the opposition campaign to stop Michael Duffy, the then Attorney-General, from tightening the merger provision.

PARA.TAB: You were the person who was running around arguing that the Business Council was opposed to the tougher merger test. You were the person who was running around saying that the MTIA and other big business organisations were opposed to a tougher merger test in the Trade Practices Act. You were the person who was leading the opposition's case in opposing a tightening of the merger—

TALK.START.PARA: —The mergers provision!
—The mergers provision section—that's the one.
—Not the monopolies provision—section 46!
—Let me quote from the speech you made. Let me make it clearer from the speech you made in the Trade Practices Legislation (Amendment) Bill in 1992. This is what you said:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal which is put by this Government in this Bill is a bad proposal. It is opposed by the Business Council, the Chamber of Commerce, the MTIA . . .
You finish by saying:
It is, of course, opposed by the Coalition.

Yet he goes on the AM program on Tuesday saying, `We've always said that we want strong anti-monopolistic laws always, always, always'. He is the man who was trying to ensure that the Trade Practices Commission would have no role whatsoever in mergers and takeovers such as this.

PARA.TAB: He is not alone in that because when the current Leader of the Opposition was Malcolm Fraser's Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, he was the person responsible for watering down the Trade Practices Act. He was the person responsible for lowering the test from a substantial lessening of competition to dominance. And this is the pair, the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who did all they could to make sure that we had weak anti-monopolistic laws for the Trade Practices Commission. Yet he had the hide to go on the AM program and claim that this was the feather that he would use to protect himself and other Australians from Mr Packer's attempts to purchase the Fairfax newspapers.

But what did Professor Allan Fels, the Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission, have to say about the opposition's claims that we could rely on the Trade Practices Act to stop Mr Packer buying Fairfax? This is an AAP release which came from the Trade Practices Commission yesterday. It is under the heading, `TPC could not stop Packer on Fairfax', and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: A spokesman for the Trade Practices Commission said today that if the cross-media laws were removed, trade practices rules would not prevent Mr Packer owning a major newspaper and television interests in the same city.

So the proposal which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the Opposition are putting forward—that we can repeal the cross-media ownership laws and rely only on the Trade Practices Act, is a signal to Mr Packer, saying that the opposition believes that Mr Packer can own Channel 9 and the Fairfax newspapers as well.

PARA.TAB: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition claims that there were very highly specific allegations made by me. I would like to remind the House of what I actually said on Monday. I said that I was aware of information that I believed linked the Leader of the Opposition to the allegations which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has put forward. At question time I said that that information came from the Packer camp and that I was told by them—that is, the Packer camp—that the Liberal Party had indicated that it would be prepared to support them and, if elected to government, would remove the cross-media ownership laws.

That is why the government has been asking the Leader of the Opposition and Senator Alston to tell us what they have been saying to Mr Packer and his executives down there at Park Street. The golden rule in politics is: there is no such thing as a secret. If the Leader of the Opposition and Senator Alston are ringing Mr Packer's executives and telling them they would be prepared to support a relaxation of the rules, we think the public of Australia have a right to know that.

Is it any wonder we get suspicious when on eight occasions the Leader of the Opposition has been asked to tell us whether he will rule out allowing Mr Packer to purchase Fairfax because he now owns the Nine Network? On all of those occasions the Leader of the Opposition has refused to tell us whether he thinks it is undesirable.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, on five occasions yesterday, also declined to say whether he thought it was undesirable for that to take place. So it is very clear that all the signals are there that the Leader of the Opposition and Senator Alston have told Mr Packer that they think it is okay for him to own Channel 9 and the Fairfax newspapers.

We on this side of the House think that is not a good thing. We think that cross-media ownership rules are there to promote diversity of ownership. We are not alone in thinking that. On Monday someone who was either impersonating the Leader of the Opposition or who looked a lot like him said, `I am strongly in favour of diversity'. That is what he said in his doorstop on Monday. Yet on 13 occasions the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition have refused to tell us whether they think it is undesirable for Mr Packer to own Channel 9 and the Fairfax papers.

We now come to looking at whether the Leader of the Opposition's claims have been consistent. In his contribution here today, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition claimed that the views of the Leader of the Opposition have been genuinely held. They were genuinely held in 1987 when he told us that he thought the rules were unworkable; they were genuinely held when he said today that he thinks the cross-media ownership rules should be abolished. But we do not understand the doughnut in the middle—the petition he signed in 1991, where he said he was in favour of restricting Mr Packer from buying Fairfax. That is the thing we find difficult to understand.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he was not responsible then.

—As the Treasurer reminds me, his excuse is that he was not then the Leader of the Opposition or the spokesman on communications, as if that in some way absolves someone from having to justify the inconsistency of their opinions. This is a man who goes around the country as honest John, who never deliberately misleads people. Yet on Monday he put out a press release that deliberately tried to mislead everyone concerned into thinking that his view had not changed since 1987.

PARA.TAB: I think we should all concentrate on what the Leader of the Opposition said on A Current Affair last night. He was asked on three occasions whether he would rule out supporting Mr Packer purchasing the Fairfax newspapers. The Sydney Morning Herald reported that appearance this morning under the heading `Cross-media rules: Howard may let Packer have it all'. Our view is that Mr Howard has told Mr Packer, `Cross-media rules: Howard will let Packer have it all.' That is our view. It can be ruled out simply by the Leader of the Opposition and Senator Alston telling us what they have said to Mr Packer and his executives.

Why will you not tell us whether or not you have given Mr Packer and his executives any reason to think that an incoming Howard government would in some way water down the cross-media ownership rules? Ray Martin questioned Mr Howard and asked him, `Should any man or woman own a television network in Australia and also the main publishing group?' That was a fair enough question from Ray Martin. Mr Howard answered, `Well, it depends on what the other players in all of the media markets are. It depends on a whole range of factors'. Here is the killer: `I am not going to say yes or no to that question. Why should I?'

TALK.START.PARA: —Honest John!

—That is honest John, as the honourable member for Parramatta said. Mr Howard said, `I am not going to answer that question. Why should I?' That is a question that goes to the integrity of media coverage in Australia; a question that goes to whether or not the richest man in Australia—the man who owns the National Nine network, the most popular network—should also own one of the most influential newspapers in the country.

PARA.TAB: On this side of the House we make it clear that we think the cross-media ownership rules carry out a very essential role in broadcasting policy. Given Senator Alston's stream of consciousness, it is not hard to find one or two press releases and comments from him saying that he supports a tightening of the rules, abolishing the rules, and a review of the rules. In fact, Senator Alston has put out so many press releases and given so many interviews on this issue that it is not hard to find him supporting every possible position that has been advocated. For that reason we think that the opposition has a few questions to answer.

The Leader of the Opposition has come into the House. I draw his attention to the comment he made on A Current Affair last night. It looks as if the Leader of the Opposition is going to enter this debate. I welcome that, because it might give him a chance to answer a few questions. He might be able to tell us what he has in fact said to Mr Packer. The Leader of the Opposition might be able to tell us what Senator Alston has said to Mr Packer and his executives. Have Mr Howard and Senator Alston given the Packer camp any reason to think that a Howard government would support a relaxation of the cross-media ownership rules? That is the question the Leader of the Opposition has to answer when he gets up to respond. That is what he can tell us.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition tries to tell us that in some way the government's response is some vendetta against Mr Packer because he went on A Current Affair. I will tell him what started this whole fracas. It started in November when this side of the House stood up to Mr Packer and his partners against the opposition proposal. This side of the House said to Mr Packer, `The Labor Party, the party that has introduced competition in aviation and telecommunications, will not introduce new monopoly rights in cable'. That is a principle and a consistent position which the Labor Party has advocated. More competition is good for our economy.
Who is the only figure in public life in Australia who supported Mr Packer's demands for monopoly rights in cable? Answer—

TALK.START.PARA: —Alston!

—Senator Richard Alston, as the honourable member for Werriwa said. Senator Richard Alston is the man who said, `Well, franchises have worked well in America and Britain and I think Australia should give greater consideration to them'. That is the date from which this blue started. The Leader of the Opposition can certainly make it clear today. He can clear up the whole matter by telling us what he has said to Mr Packer in those telephone conversations and what Senator Alston has said in his conversations with the executives of Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd. Has Mr Howard or Senator Alston given Mr Packer and the Packer executives any reason to think that a Howard-led coalition government would support a weakening of the cross-media ownership rules?

PARA.TAB: Why have you refused on eight occasions to tell us whether you would oppose Mr Packer purchasing the Fairfax newspapers? They are the questions for you to answer. It is time you gave us some answers.

TALK.START.PARA: —If before today I had entertained any doubt at all that I am really getting under the skin of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and that I am really getting under the skin of all those failures who sit on the government front bench, it has been confirmed today by the very interesting and salient fact that twice in the space of a week the government has been so worried about me that it has taken the unprecedented step of moving a censure motion. If you think that that is an intimidating, clever, sophisticated parliamentary tactic, can I tell you that I wear it like a badge of honour.

PARA.TAB: I look forward to the day when you move a censure motion against me every day that this parliament sits because that will remind me and it will remind the mainstream of the Australian community that the person you—and that man you serve like an acolyte, the Prime Minister—are really concerned about in Australian politicians is me. Long may you go on doing that, because I have got some news for you and all your mates on the front bench: I am going to bug you on the political stage of Australia until you are driven from office at the next election for the miserable failures you are.

Do you think that in some way I am really sort of overwhelmed or intimidated by this little tawdry performance? You are the person who for three days this week did not have the guts to come into this parliament and defend yourself against attack. But, with the first attack that you made on me, I had the guts to get up and defend myself. But not you, you little Sir Echo; you hide behind the factional skirts of your patron, the Prime Minister.

Can I just remind you that this debate is about one very simple thing; it is about the integrity of the Prime Minister of Australia. He put his integrity on the line. He asked the Australian people to believe him and to disbelieve me. He lied to the Australian people—I repeat that he lied to the Australian people—as he has done on so many occasions, about—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker.
—Sit down, you mug.

PARA.TAB: Mr Beazley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly.
—Order! I might just again caution both sides about parliamentary language. I invite the Leader of the Opposition—

PARA.TAB: Mr Tuckey interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, not even in censure motions.

—If the Leader of the House thinks those sorts of bellicose interjections are going to put anybody off their game on this side of the House, he is completely mistaken. This debate is about one very simple thing—that is, whether the government can substantiate the false, lying claim that I made a secret deal with Mr Kerry Packer. It is about nothing else. It is not a question of whether the government's media policy is good or our media policy is bad or ought to be changed. It has absolutely nothing at all to do with that.

PARA.TAB: This started by the Prime Minister lying through his teeth by saying that I had made a secret deal with Mr Packer. He was asked to provide evidence. Evidence is, as you know, material which supports the allegation. The allegation was that I had made a secret deal. Yet, for all the words that have been uttered, for all the huffing and puffing that has occurred today, you have produced not one skerrick of evidence. Michael, you know deep down in your heart that you have been caught out on this. You have been serving the Prime Minister. You have been slavishly backing up the Prime Minister like the faithful little boy Sir Echo you really are to the Prime Minister. You know deep down that you have not made one skerrick of a case against me.

You can talk about media policy and you can, as you inevitably will, use your weight of numbers to pass this motion today. The more you do that, the more you will underline your sensitivity towards me—and the more I welcome it. I hope you pass a censure motion on me every day. The more censure motions you pass, the more I recognise the political threat that I pose to your leader.

I keep picking up the paper of a morning and seeing stories written out of Singapore and Germany saying, `Really it's a long-term strategy.' It is so clever. You start off by making a false allegation, you go quiet for a week, then you go overseas and you revive the allegation. You hijack a press conference with the Prime Minister of Singapore, insulting one of our Asian neighbours by doing so, then you go off to Germany and say, `This is terrible. This should be talked about back in Australia.' What is the explanation for this? You go down to the back of the plane and say, `Really it is a long-term strategy to ensnare Howard.'

It is so subtle, it is so sophisticated. But instead of it ensnaring Howard, it has ensnared Lee, because was he was not told that the script had changed. It is so secret, sophisticated and convoluted that the only people who really understand it are the Prime Minister and his minders who put it together.

It passes strange that we in this House should have lectures about media policy from people who speak on behalf of the Prime Minister. If media policy in Australia is an unmitigated mess in 1995, it is the fault of one person more than anybody else: the Prime Minister of Australia. The Prime Minister of Australia is the proud author of the policy known as `You have to be either queen of the screen or prince of print'. The real code language is not that you have to be one thing or the other but that when the policy was devised it was devised with one sole objective in mind: to undermine, even destroy, the old Fairfax media empire and the Herald and Weekly Times empire.

No person bears a greater responsibility for the high level of foreign ownership of the Australian media, and any existing levels of concentration of Australian media, than Paul Keating. Paul Keating has done more to hand the media of this country over to foreigners and has done more to concentrate media ownership than any politician left standing in Australia. The last person who ought to have the nerve to raise media policy in this parliament is somebody who seeks to speak on behalf of the Prime Minister of Australia. It was the Prime Minister of Australia who told the former editorial manager, Max Suich, of the Fairfax media empire in the late 1980s how much he hated the Fairfax newspapers and how much he was bent on destroying them.

We all remember that very accurate report of a cabinet meeting in the mid-1980s when the then Prime Minister of Australia, Bob Hawke, supported by the now Prime Minister, Paul Keating, was trying to get the media laws of this country changed. Nobody could quite understand what their end game was because there seemed to be no rhyme or reason or logic in what they were trying to do. In the middle of it, with that great capacity for spotting humbug and isolating what somebody was up to, John Button said, `Hey, Bob, will you tell us which of your media mates you are trying to help so we'll know what you want us to do?' That was very well documented.

The only two people on the government side who emerged with any merit or credit from that were John Button and the soon to be retiring member for Holt, Michael Duffy. At least they showed a little bit of intestinal fortitude, integrity and honesty. Both of them were appalled at the tawdry actions of your former Prime Minister and your current Prime Minister—the man you desire to serve on all occasions.
Mr Elliott interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Mr Speaker, I do not need any protection from that little boy. They were the two men who were the architects of the high level of foreign ownership of the Australian media. Those opposite can interject all they like. They can belly-ache as much as they like. I will be very interested if the member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) is given free reign to take part in this debate. Watch him go. Got him in one. There sits another honest Labor man.
—He knows what happened.

—He knows what happened and he knows what a shambles the present media policy of this country is. He knows what a disgrace it is for the current Prime Minister of Australia to talk about integrity and consistency when it comes to media policy. The only thing that is at issue in this debate, and the only person who is on trial in this debate, is the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee).

PARA.TAB: The simple question I ask again, as people all around Australia have been asking over the last week: where is your evidence to support the allegations? To use that great Australian expression, why don't you put up or shut up? You have been invited time and time again to put up or shut up but you have not had the intestinal fortitude, the guts or the plain Australian courage to actually backup your claim.

The reason you have not done that, the reason you have conjured up this alternative censure motion and paid me the compliment that it represents, the reason you are feigning this infected indignation about alternative policies is that you do not have any evidence to back your claim. You have been blown out of the water. One thing surprised me about the Prime Minister; that is, I never thought he would blink. When it actually came to making an allegation, I never thought he would walk away from it. I was really amazed to get a long distance blink from the Prime Minister. I do not think I could bear a short distance blink from the Prime Minister, but I got a long distance blink when he was in Hanover.
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right!

—I knew I got the long distance blink when I heard the Prime Minister say to the media in Hanover, `I think we should start talking about the republic.' This is the man who can talk to President Suharto about the republic. He can talk to the press of Japan about the republic. He can talk to the Prime Minister of Britain about the republic. He can talk to the President of the United States about the republic. The only people he cannot talk to about the republic are the people of Australia. He does not want the Australian people to be taken into his confidence.

PARA.TAB: One of my colleagues said to me the other day, `It is a 1995 version of the cultural cringe.' Australians years ago used to seek the artistic endorsement of foreigners. Then they sought the professional endorsement of foreigners. Then they sought the business endorsement of foreigners. I thought we had put all of that behind us. I thought we had reached a stage in Australia's history where we could proudly—
Government members—You haven't.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is seeking the endorsement of foreigners in the media debate? You are. You are the people who produced the high level of foreign ownership. I thought we had put all of that cultural cringe behind us. I thought we were a nation that could proudly make decisions about the things that affected the future of this country unhindered by the sanction or unconcerned by the opprobrium of foreigners. However, I find that, when it comes to the constitutional future of this country, the Prime Minister of Australia seeks not the approval of the Australian people; he craves the blessing of foreign leaders. I find that demeaning in every extreme. I find it a 1995 version of the great Australian cultural cringe.

PARA.TAB: Through all of this, the government has failed to substantiate the allegation of the week. It has failed to support the lie of the week—which will now be the lie of the year—by the Prime Minister of Australia that I entered into a secret deal with Mr Kerry Packer. The Prime Minister made that allegation. He had no evidence to support it. He has been demonstrated to be wrong. His integrity has been destroyed, as has that of the minister for communications. The very fact that this censure motion has been moved against me today, which pleases me no end, is the final proof of the ignominious failure of this deceitful, lying smear tactic of the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the Leader of the House, I think the right honourable member for New England wants to raise an issue with me in reference to the motion.

—Mr Speaker, this motion has only just been circulated to members. In examining it and in relating it to standing orders 75 to 78, I suggest that the words concluding the motion are totally against our standing orders. I recommend to you that the words `who steal documents related to court documents' be deleted.

—I have been looking at the motion since I have had it, and I have to say that the question before the House is essentially in relation to media policy. The question of integrity certainly was raised by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. I would be much happier if those last few words were deleted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly. I will be happy to do it. The amendment now reads:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be deleted and the following words be inserted: "This House censures the Leader of the Opposition for his reversal of his media policy against media concentration and its refusal to state its policy towards the current threats to the cross-media ownership rules.
