SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) rorts the issue in any way, and that gives me the opportunity to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Before the Leader of the House commences, should he not indicate to you which of the words have been struck out and where the amendment will end?
—The amendment will now end at `the colleagues' and the other words will come out.
—It will actually end at `job growth'. I am delighted because the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition actually provide—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The amendment has been circulated but the original motion has not. I ask that the original motion be circulated as well.
—That will be done.

—I am glad the Leader of the Opposition spoke in this debate because he originally decided that he would not do so. After actually hearing his contribution, you can understand why he arrived at that earlier conclusion. He subsequently decided to come in here and participate in the debate. Fortunately, in his remarks—because he referred to an earlier censure motion this week—he provides us with the opportunity to make reference to that debate as well. It is no longer necessary for us to put that in our proposition.

PARA.TAB: The first thing to note about the contribution of the Leader of the Opposition is that he is not being censured for the second time this week. He referred to the motion of censure at the beginning of the week, but that was not moved upon the Leader of the Opposition. It shows you how much attention he pays in this place. The motion of censure was moved on the honourable member for Barker.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that your killer point?
—No, there are many more points. Do not worry about that. Off you go. Take off. Run off. The point that—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left! The Leader of the House might resume his seat for a moment.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the fact that, throughout the speech of the Leader of the Opposition and again throughout the speech of this minister, the honourable members for Dunkley, Werriwa, Parramatta and Lilley have continually interjected while not being in their places. I think you should remind them of the standing orders.

—I remind all members of them, but I also remind those of my left that it is not in order to stand at the dispatch box or wherever else and interject while the minister has the call. I call the minister.

—When the Leader of the Opposition spoke in this debate, he discussed cross-media ownership rules, foreign ownership rules and media policy generally. Throughout his speech, he failed to refer to not only current opposition policies but past opposition policies. After hearing the Leader of the Opposition debate the issues that surrounded the decisions last decade—changes to the ownership rules to separate ownership of the electronic media from ownership of the print media—a reasonable person would think that his remarks indicate that the opposition stood in diametrical opposition to us on those particular propositions.

PARA.TAB: They supported us. They supported us on changes we put in place at the time. They merely said that they had some vague concerns about them, but their concerns did not go to the opportunity to establish a network in television—which was the basic element of the electronic media one, apart from the cross-media ownership rules at the time. They did not oppose that proposition. In so far as they had any difficulties with it at all, they had difficulties with whether or not you could move from owning one or two stations in major metropolitan centres around the country to owning any number of them. Then they had doubts as to whether you ought to be excluded from the print media in those centres at the same time. That was the area of their doubt.

So, if you listened to the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition, you would think that he stood here as a devotee of diversity. You would think that the government had somehow failed in its task to ensure diversity, and that that was the reason the government—among others—should be censured for its longstanding media policies in this area. That happens not to be true. The only thing consistent about the Leader of the Opposition when it comes to these matters is his vagueness. He has been vague when he was taken to task by the press on what his policies now happen to be. He was vague then. The media release he re-released earlier this week is such a typical opposition presentation on media policy that it is worth recounting. The style of presentation has not changed over the years. The basic thrust is, `For God's sake, do not force us to commit ourselves in any detailed fashion on anything related to media policy. Please let us stand around the place, shouting out that the government's policy is a mess but, for God's sake, do not tie us down.' The Leader of the Opposition said:

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition sees merit in the Government's proposal to removing the existing two-station rule.
At this stage, we are disposed to support the Government's proposal and that any television network should have the right to reach 75 per cent of the viewing audience.

However we should be looking carefully at the report of the Senate Select Committee, established at the initiative of the Opposition, as we are particularly keen to ensure that the introduction of the 75 per cent rule does not unfairly disadvantage regional television stations.

The Opposition also believes that as part and parcel of the removal of the two-station rule and the introduction of the 75 per cent principle there should be a removal of the existing barriers to entry into both television and radio.
This is those opposite supporting the ability to set up a television network in this country. But where did they have a problem with it? They came to a problem on this point:
On the question of cross-media ownership we are not convinced that the prohibitions proposed by the Government are either necessary or can be justified.

So the official position of the opposition was at that stage: you could have a network and you could own newspapers in all the areas where you had that network. He hates a reference to history when it is a reference to history that deals with himself. He loves a reference to history when he thinks it makes a point about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). That is the first point that you would make about the Leader of the Opposition. Then he said:
The Government's policies encourage foreign ownership.

There is an interesting fact in the 1991 document—which I will get to a bit later—about a petition he signed adopting a policy that he said he had never espoused. That petition, even though it was a matter of debate at the time, contains no reference to foreign ownership.

PARA.TAB: There is a specific reason why it contains no mention of foreign ownership. That was that whilst there was a substantial amount of bipartisan unity, I have to say, having been on the receiving end of a lobbying about it as a minister in the portfolio at the time, on defending the cross-media ownership rules that they previously opposed, there was no bipartisanship on the subject of foreign ownership.

Why was there no bipartisanship on the subject of foreign ownership? For this reason: the government was supportive of putting limitations on it; the opposition was not. Whatever level of foreign ownership has been achieved, and whether or not you regard that level of foreign ownership as suitable or as contrary to the national interest, if the opposition had had policy control at that point in time, it would have been greater.

This is the style of argument of the person who wants to be regarded as a man of great integrity in this place, the Leader of the Opposition. You make an accusation about the government, you attack it from both the left and the right and you hope to God nobody reviews your history. If he does review your history, you get up around the gallery and inform them of what it is that you think that they are up to, trying to obfuscate the defence of themselves or whatever by the propositions they put. He is being very free in this debate and out in the public forum with his accusations of lying. He has, nevertheless, produced a statement at the beginning of this week which was an out and out lie. That was actually picked up, funnily enough—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. You, Mr Speaker, have previously ruled in this area where the accusation of lie and lying has been made. I submit to you on balance that this one falls on the other side of the ledger and should be dealt with accordingly.

—Order! I also said during the debate today that I would hope that both sides in this debate would reflect upon what is unparliamentary language. But I do recall on a number of occasions the Leader of the Opposition using that terminology in the way which it has been used.

—I will not use it again, Mr Speaker, which was not a requirement placed upon the Leader of the Opposition. I just use it that once and now illustrate the point further. It was a very interesting interview the other night on Ray Martin's show. In the same way as he should not have entered this debate, he ought not to have gone on Ray Martin's show last night, because Ray Martin, who is a good interviewer, had the integrity to go through with him his 1991 position as opposed to his 1987 position, which was about as vague as you could have put it but did actually emerge at the end of the day as being one of opposition to cross-media ownership rules. So we will give him what he said back in 1987, even though by very tortuous logic he finally arrived at opposition to the ownership rules. Nevertheless, in 1991 he was absolutely clear cut. The transcript states:

SPEECH.PARA: Martin: Now what about the suggestion today in Parliament by Kim Beazley that you've flip-flopped. That in fact you were a party to a petition in 1991 that called for tougher rules?
Howard: Well, that was the Opposition's policy at that particular time—
even though he had said privately and publicly that he had been devoted to a looser cross-media ownership rule—
Martin: But you signed that petition?
Howard: Well, I wasn't the Leader of the Opposition then, and I wasn't the spokesman on communications and I went along as a team player, I went along with the Opposition's situation.

It is all right to sling around accusations about the Prime Minister, that he is a man without integrity and tells lies. But we now know the criteria by which John Howard is prepared to mislead the public as to his point of view. He will be prepared to mislead the public as to his point of view when he is not the spokesman on communications; when he is not the Leader of the Opposition; when he is a team player; and when he goes along with the opposition situation. We now know the price tag that is placed by the Leader of the Opposition on his personal integrity as far as that is concerned. I would say it is a pretty diverse caveat on the requirement for him to tell the truth.

PARA.TAB: One thing that is consistent about the opposition position is the slipping and the sliding. There has been a slipping and a sliding on this. The Leader of the Opposition says, `Oh, no, I do not have any particular deal in this situation. I go along and have a couple of chats. In the course of those couple of chats I reveal that I have informed Mr Packer that my position privately and publicly is that which it was back in 1987.' Smarm, smarm. He says, `It is no problem as far as I am concerned. I don't agree with the prince of print and the queen of screen and all the rest of it. I never have, except when he bid last time as part of the Tourang consortium in 1991 for Fairfax. Then I was opposed to it. So I do have something to explain. I just want to give you my assurance, Sir, that that little dereliction on my part was due to the fact that I wasn't Leader of the Opposition at the time; I was not the spokesman on communications. I went along as a team player. I went along with the opposition's situation. So please ignore that, Sir, and remember that back in 1987 I would have given you the lot. But please don't support me. Please don't get out there on your channels and say anything nice about me. No, please don't do that; just be absolutely clear that I have crawfished away from that terrible position that I took on the Tourang bid. I beg your forgiveness. We don't have any conspiracy going, do we? There is no special pleading here.'

What a gutless, snivelling, crawling performance that is. Then he has a little difficulty because somebody wants to ask him to sharpen up in his policy area and to say something a bit straightforward about all this. So he is finally brought down. When asked, `Tell us what you would do. You sort of said you were with him back in 1987,' he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am very strongly in favour of diversity and it's worth saying that the man who's done more to concentrate foreign ownership and single proprietor ownership, of the Australian media is Paul Keating.
Another question:
But do you think it is undesirable?
Mr Howard replied:

I think it's undesirable to have too heavier concentration in anything, whether it's newspapers, television or the lot, but I don't think it's desirable to personalise it, I think you have to have rules and principles. He was then asked:
But do you think there should be a rule, do you agree that there should be some sort of rule to avoid the ownership of a major newspaper in a city and one of the major television networks?
He replied:

I think there should be a rule to prevent too much concentration of ownership and the question of whether you best do it by a specific rule or whether you do it in some other way was the essence of what I said back in 1987.
Absolute bulldust! He was asked:
But what I'm trying to get at, is—
to which Mr Howard said:
I know what you're trying to get at, and I've given you my answer.
He was asked:
. . . undesirable circumstance?
The answer was:
I think it is desirable to have as much diversity as possible.
In answer to another question, he stated:
Well it would depend on the size of the market and how you define the market.

Well, fair dinkum: you are a very lucky man. The press has let you lot off the hook on this one during this week. When it comes to a particular policy debate, you have been jumping up and down on both sides of this issue, desperately trying to arrive at a conclusion, but with one underlying theme: `We shall bow at the altar of whoever it is who might provide us with a useful level of political support. If those folk are around, we will apologise for past attitudes that we have taken on this matter which may have had cause to give grievous offence. And if those past attitudes are pointed out to us in a way that makes us look like we are a pack of liars, without integrity, as we slither into our hollows on this one, we will explain it by the fact that we had no official responsibilities at the time and we were just going along with the mob.'The Leader of the Opposition, at the end of the day, never learns. He has spent a lifetime going along with the mob and he does not deserve the attention of this parliament on this matter. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) has developed a well known routine in his presentation, it was one of the most pathetic presentations I have heard from him for a long time, because the challenge for him was a very simple challenge, and that was to produce some evidence to back up the claim.

PARA.TAB: He started by making a point about how many times they had censured the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), which was pathetic in itself. That was his opening point. He then got the amendment wrong and had to change tack on that. He then ran out of time. He filled his 15 minutes with nothing but bluster. It really demonstrates the case which is the censure motion against the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee).

I say to the Minister for Communications and the Arts: if we look at his ashen faced complexion, you know, and we know that you know, there was no deal. The minister and I were sworn in together in this place in early 1985. I have been watching him for some time. I suppose it is fair to say that his rise in the Labor Party has been largely uninterrupted. The Labor Party has been in office and he has been able to ride in on the coat-tails of others to assume now the high office of minister for communications.

In the last 10 years I think there are a couple of lessons that he ought to have learnt about politics. The first thing is that a lot of people think that politics is a game. It is true that politics has many of the characteristics of a game. It has the rough and tumble of a game. It has the theatre of a game. From time to time you have the professional free kick taken by one side, whilst breaking the rules, to still give their side a benefit. That is accepted when you are playing a game.

But the fact is that this is not a game. Yes, it has the characteristics of a game but politics is no game. I think that when we look into your face, minister, you realise that simple fact. When you set out deliberately, maliciously and without justification to smear, when you set out to conspire with others—and, in particular, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—to attack the reputation of another and impugn the integrity of a member of this House, doing so in a baseless and malicious way, you damage your own reputation. The Leader of the Opposition is not damaged by this; you are the one who is damaged by this. Sure, you are going to use your numbers and knock off our censure motion. You will put through your silly amendment. But the reality is, minister, that this damage is damage that you will incur.

I understand why. You owe your place in political life to the Prime Minister. He is your promoter. Just as he knelt at the knee of Jack Lang and learned the tricks of the trade of the New South Wales Right, you sit on the knee of the Prime Minister and learn the lessons of politics from him. As you consider your political career, you think that you owe him; but I would say to you, minister—and this is the second lesson for you—that you are a young bloke compared with the Prime Minister. In fact, the Prime Minister has been here a long time. I do not think he will be here that much longer. You are 37 years old, you are a very young fellow—in fact, you are very young by your actions as well.

The reality is that your reputation will ultimately be built not on the fact that you have been able to hang onto the skirts of the Prime Minister but on the basis of your actions in this place. You might think that your reputation is one that is built only on what your colleagues think of you, but you are wrong. Ultimately, if you are going to have a reputation in this place, it will be a reputation that rests on the opinions of everybody in this House—even people on our side of this House. We will not forget this malicious, nasty, little smear campaign that you have been running and, ultimately, your reputation will be based on what sort of person you are.

I heard the Prime Minister say the other day—and it is a classic Keating quote—`If I were Howard, I'd have had a plan that would drive me mad.' The way the Prime Minister is going on, we do not need a plan because he is pretty mad already—absolutely mad. He will not be here much longer, minister. So you will have to stand on your own two feet and build your own reputation.

You work on the basis of the philosophy you have learnt from the New South Wales Right, which is: say anything and do anything. It is a sort of `whatever it takes' philosophy. The reality is that, if you do not do the right thing—if you do not stand up today as you have been provided the opportunity to do—and admit the error of your ways, then this reputation about you will stick.

I suppose that, in your imagination, you may think that you are the next Paul Keating, and Richo told you that you had those prospects. But I have got news for you. You are not the next Paul Keating, mate; you are the next Ros Kelly, the whiteboard lady. They say you are the rising star. The last rising star that we had around this place was the member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths). What we found out about the member for Maribyrnong was that he could not even run a sandwich shop. That is your destiny, if this is the standard which you are going to set. I just say, by way of an aside, that we have not seen the Codd report on the member for Maribyrnong. It is about time it was produced.

Before I set out the case against you, which is an open and shut case if ever I saw one, let me just deal very briefly—it will not take long to deal with because not much was said by you people—with the basis of your response. Your response simply is one based on an argument about coalition policy. You build your case, not on secret deals, but on all our public statements. It is bizarre in that you guys start with a proposition that there is a secret deal but, when we put the heat on you for the evidence, your evidence consists of the public comments of the Leader of the Opposition. I will come back to the comments you made on Monday night in a minute.

It was interesting to hear that your defence today was based on the Leader of the Opposition's remarks last night on television. Perhaps it is a good try on your part, but the reality is that the charge against you is that you set out maliciously to smear the Leader of the Opposition. That is the charge you have got to answer, and you have dismally failed to do so.

If it were simply a matter of a disagreement about coalition policy, then I would remind you that, on that basis, we would be mounting a similar argument against Mr Keating. Mr Keating himself has said that really he questions the ongoing relevance of the cross-media ownership because of the way in which technology is changing. I reckon that allegation would have a hell of a lot more credit if it came from us. Do you know why? Because if anybody has ever done deals in this country, it is you blokes, not us. It is amazing. You go all the way back to 1987 and get stuck into John Howard, but the fact is that, if you go back to what John Howard said in 1987 on the public record, Kerry Packer was backing you guys, not us—and said so publicly.

We come to this with clean hands. This whole thing started off with one simple statement—with Kerry Packer expressing the views that most Australians have—that is, that John Howard is a pretty decent, honest bloke and he is not a bad alternative Prime Minister. Sure, in your eyes this is a political crime of absolutely huge dimensions. The thought that this is an idea that is going to sweep the country absolutely sends shivers up your spine.

TALK.START.PARA: —It drives them mad.

—It does. It drives them mad. It drives them troppo, as Senator Alston said. But that is the reality of it, and that is where this whole thing started. Let me just go to what you said so we can come to the charge that we have against you. What you said on Monday night, Minister, was a pretty clear statement. This is what you said:

SPEECH.PARA: I along with a number of other people are certainly aware of information which we believe links Mr Howard to the allegations which the Prime Minister has put forward.
You furthermore said:

Ah, well, I think that the claim that the evidence is only circumstantial is based on a claimed knowledge as to who might have passed on the information to the Prime Minister. If the person who passed on the information to the Prime Minister was in a position to know, then I think it's pretty firm evidence.
Then Lyndall Curtis asked:
And you believe they were in a position to know?
Your answer:
Absolutely.

That is a pretty clear statement. That is a very clear statement that you had evidence as to whom, as to when and as to the detail. The reality is that you have not. The whole week, Minister, we have provided you with opportunities. We have asked you the what of this allegation; we have asked you the when of this allegation; and we have asked you the who of this allegation—who was it that provided the information? At every opportunity, you have walked away from the question. You did not even have the guts to front up to question time yesterday. You were up there watching Sesame Street and having afternoon tea. We had a division after question time and, lo and behold, here you were. You have failed to respond to this charge on every occasion it has been brought up.

PARA.TAB: Let us put the whole thing in context. What do we have here? We have nothing other than a political campaign on your part. Minister, you have been brought up in a school of politics which thinks it is smart to run a smear campaign. You think that this is the way in which good public policy is conducted. The reality is that it ain't. It is a serious allegation. You work on the basis that mud sticks. Well, this is mud that ain't going to stick, Minister. This is a campaign we intend to and do repel.

You, of course, act in conjunction with the Prime Minister, and he is a master of the smear campaign. You think that you can profit by it, but if you look at it you will see that what we have is a situation where the Prime Minister attempts to hold on to his office by the use of a smear campaign. In doing so, he demeans the office of Prime Minister. It is no wonder that there is a cynicism about Australian politics that has developed in the last 10 years when people like you and the Prime Minister act in the way you do—in a malevolent way.

Minister, you have two simple choices. Your first choice is to substantiate your claim. We have given you repeated opportunities to do so. Instead, you and Mr Keating have repeated the claim. Your second choice is to salvage some credibility for what you have had to say. That would be to stand here and to admit that you have no evidence and to apologise, not only to the Leader of the Opposition but to the House generally, for the fact that you have waged a campaign for a week now on baseless, unsubstantiated allegations. Minister, I say to you that a glimpse of decency, a whiff of honesty, might give you that chance to salvage. I do not expect you to do so.

The reality is that you deserve to be censured. Why do you deserve to be censured? You deserve to be censured because you lied. It is as simple as that. You have lied to this House, and you have lied to the Australian people. I think you also deserve to be censured because you have slavishly repeated the lies of others, and you have done so knowingly. There has never been any doubt in your mind, has there, Minister? Let us face it. There has never been any doubt in your mind whatsoever that this whole thing was a malicious smear campaign.

Lastly, Minister, you deserve censure not just for the fact that you lied, not just for the fact that you slavishly repeated the Prime Minister's lies but for your political incompetence in putting your own reputation in the hands of somebody like Keating. That is what you have done: you have put your own reputation in the hands of someone like Keating. And, I tell you, he won't be grateful, Minister.

The fact is, he is off on one of his European jaunts. He is off there in Berlin about to enjoy the sights. I think as we rise and go home to our electorates, it is 11 a.m. and an early start for the Prime Minister, who will be off doing the sights of Berlin with the Mayor of Berlin, offering and pressing home his own ideas for improvements to the Berlin streetscape. That is a pretty busy day for him because then after that he will have 4 1/2 hours of rest in which to prepare himself for the gruelling main event of the day, dinner at the Schloss Charlottenberg hosted by the same unfortunate mayor who can look forward to his lecturing on Berlin streetscapes during the day.

Whilst he is doing that, Minister, you will be reading the comment pieces that state that basically, you are a liar; you do not tell the truth; you are just a little Sir Echo in a malicious, grubby campaign to impugn the reputation of someone who has worked hard and, with justification, has a good reputation in this place. You deserve censure. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —There was one simple way for the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) to resolve this matter. He had 20 minutes to do it. PARA.TAB: If we did not need his silence today then we certainly got it last night on A Current Affair, Kerry's program on Kerry's station. MARTIN: Well, let's shoot straight.—

PARA.TAB: All the Leader of the Opposition had to do today was to come into this House and say, `We've all had allegations made against us before. I deny it. It's not true.' TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. It goes to the relevance of this debate. An allegation has just been made about a deal. The member for Perth has another 10 minutes in which to identify the people with whom the deal was done or he insults them as well.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The member for O'Connor was cautioned earlier today.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said at the outset: in any event, the case was proved conclusively yesterday and today by the Minister for Communications and the Arts and by the Leader of the House. And it was proved by the words of the Leader of the Opposition on the Ray Martin show last night.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Tuckey interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for O'Connor!

PARA.TAB: I was also intrigued that at a time when the honourable member for Bennelong was making his silent and secret push to again become Leader of the Opposition there was an article in the Weekend Australian of 12-13 November under the heading `New push for Howard falls short of a second coming'. TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on this report, Report on the management and treatment of breast cancer, my first purpose is to offer my congratulations for this report to the community affairs subcommittee chaired by the member for Brand (Ms Fatin). It is important to point out that she and her four colleagues on the subcommittee received 192 submissions, which indicates the level of interest in this issue around Australia. They held 12 days of public hearings. I took some time to attend one of those and certainly found it quite fascinating and, of course, of extreme importance.

PARA.TAB: This inquiry follows a report tabled in August of last year on home and community care. In both cases, we found that the Australian community, both professionally and at a personal level, is very willing and very eager to respond to parliamentarians and the parliament when they are given the chance to. The high level of interest and open-mindedness that we find in these inquiries is most welcome. What also comes through is that as a country we have a very high level of skill. When we do something well, we do it very, very well, and we certainly rank amongst world leaders. But what seems to occur in breast cancer treatment, as in many other issues, is that we do not do it the same all over. Whilst we may do it well in one part of the country, we appear not to have learnt how to spread that best practice, that skill, across the whole country.

As a nation Australia has long understood the tyranny of distance and the inequalities caused by our geographic dispersion, so I suppose many of us had thought that with modern communication technology and all those things we would have shrunk those differences and lessened them. What this inquiry shows is that women throughout Australia do get varying levels of treatment and service depending on where they live. That is a matter that I am sure is of concern to the parliament and to all of us. Yet at the same time the people offering the advice, and certainly the professionals, going on the evidence of the medical professions and the various individuals that took part, made very clear their willingness to actually participate in improving the system.

I noted also some comments from the staff from the office of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), expressing some concern about the report. I think it is often wise for people to take time to read these reports and look at them closely and thoughtfully rather than succumb to the pressure of the media to respond at the moment they are released. We know what happens. The report comes out and the media scan it, look for a few controversial words here and there, and instantly look for a response. Most of us who have been around a while tend to recognise that that is the worst time to respond, and I have no doubt that when the minister and her department look at this report closely they will come back with very positive responses to it, because I think it certainly is a very worthwhile report.

I said my purpose this morning was to place on record the appreciation of both myself and the rest of the committee for the work of the member for Brand and her colleagues who carried out this inquiry, and for the report they have presented. I also want to point out that the committee has actually re-established the subcommittee that conducted the inquiry, so they will in fact continue some of their work. From our point of view, to produce the report is extremely important but it is not the end of the process, and we want to develop methods and ideas and ways in which the report itself becomes an active vehicle for testing ideas and getting people to look further.

Of course, the government is required to respond to the report in the three-month period. Between now and then, it is expected that the subcommittee will continue to be active and will consult with the community and the professions. In that process, the subcommittee will try to ensure that the report is seen as an active, vibrant document and not something that has been tabled and then pigeonholed.

That particular role has been one that we have been testing and trying to develop. In the area of social policy, as I said, the reporting process is only one stage. I offer my personal congratulations on behalf of the committee to the honourable member for Brand, to the subcommittee and to the staff who helped, particularly Julie from the department, who assisted in the drafting. I support the motion that the Main Committee take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan Mrs J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was around this time last year—in fact it was one year ago yesterday—that the then Leader of the Opposition, Dr John Hewson, launched the Beat breast cancer: lobby for life kit. This was funded by the Hancock Family Breast Cancer Foundation in Perth. The kit was widely supported by many thousands of people throughout Australia, men and women. It is interesting to note that, despite the fact that 99 per cent of patients suffering from breast cancer are women, this issue, Australia wide, has certainly had the support of men and women. No doubt that is because not only are the patients traumatised but their entire families are often also traumatised by this disease.

PARA.TAB: The initiative that John Hewson launched last year resulted in almost 100,000 signatures from people all over this country to endeavour to increase funding for breast cancer research. The petition deplored the fact that six Australian women per day die from breast cancer and noted that the possibility of contracting breast cancer is as high as one chance in 12 for Australian women.

The petition also recognised the fact that breast cancer has the potential to affect every Australian family. It noted and recognised that there were inadequate research funds available to help combat breast cancer and the petitioners asked that the government increase funding and, in addition to that, consider further initiatives to encourage private donations.

At that particular time, Dr Hewson wrote a letter to include in the kit. Many thousands of the kits were circulated around the country. I do not wish to read the whole of Dr Hewson's letter, but I would like to read the final paragraph. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Collectively, the men and women of Australia have a powerful voice. I believe it should be heard. The facts about breast cancer in this country are a national disgrace and it is up to all of us as Australians to act. In this, the International Year of the Family, we have an opportunity to demonstrate our commitment to families. What could be more important for a family than to insist on Government action to support the health and well-being of Australian people.

The hard cold facts about breast cancer have been well highlighted in this report, and I would like to recap on some of those points. Breast cancer is the most common cause of death from cancer in women. Forty per cent of women who get breast cancer die from the disease. There is no known cause of breast cancer. There has been a rising incidence of breast cancer and it is now the most common cause of death for Australian women aged 25 to 44.

PARA.TAB: Breast cancer affects one in 12 Australian women. Over 6,000 women per year are diagnosed with breast cancer in Australia. That means that one woman dies every four hours in this country, and six women die every day. About 2,500 women die from breast cancer each year. On present trends, over the next 10 years another 30,000 Australian women will die of breast cancer. There is quite an extensive list of facts which, when one starts to delve into them, are quite alarming. The alarming point is that very little was being done to address this issue and to make funding available for research, diagnosis, treatment and after care treatment.

The fact that nearly 100,000 Australians signed a petition which was presented to the Australian parliament and that the government did act was a victory for democracy. It goes to show that, when ordinary Australians become involved in the processes of this place, we can actually move mountains and get places. I see that as a great victory for democracy in this country: the power of the people.
After that petition was presented to the parliament, a number of things happened. The government announced in the women's budget statement for 1994-95 the following measures:

SPEECH.PARA: From 1994-95, the screening program will form the basis of a new comprehensive national Breast Cancer Program. It is important to widen our focus and to address the treatment issues that are one of the most pressing concerns of women with breast cancer. It is also important to keep up Australia's research effort on this disease. The new Breast Cancer Program will therefore have two new elements.

.A National Breast Cancer Centre which will be set up under the auspices of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). It will analyse Australian and overseas research, seek medical consensus on the best treatment practices, provide accessible information on treatment and other issues to doctors and patients, and assist development of support services. The Centre will also be a clear, single information point for doctors, women and the broader public, about all aspects of breast cancer.

After that petition was presented, the government set aside, as per the 1994-95 budget, a total of $16.4 million for the centre and its associated activities over a four-year period, so that meant $2.5 million for this particular budget. In addition, the government announced a measure to set up a breast cancer foundation, with this comment:

.A Breast Cancer Foundation will be set up to raise funds, particularly from the private sector, to support basic and applied breast cancer research, particularly research relating to practical treatment and information for women. The Commonwealth will provide $3m over three years to establish the Foundation, and in the next three years, will also match up to $1m a year in private donations.

I certainly applaud the small progress that has been made in terms of the funding, but I have to say that I was very disappointed that the government saw fit to spend $3 million setting up a new foundation when, in this country, we already have several credible foundations. I would have thought that the $3 million might have gone a long way towards helping to fund many of the initiatives that have been recommended in this report. I am deeply disappointed about that.

PARA.TAB: I know that there are several institutions—including, as I said before, the Hancock Family Breast Cancer Foundation, in my state—whose charter is to raise public funds to help to research and to improve the treatment and ongoing care of breast cancer patients. We have a number of foundations already, so why would we allocate $3 million to setting up a new foundation and all the costs associated with the administration of that? I fail to understand the logic in that.

I congratulate the member for Brand (Ms Fatin) on her dedication—she has done an incredible amount of work—and my colleague the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), who has also put in an immense effort in this matter. The member for Brand, along with others, moved this agenda forward in November 1993. That was when the then minister for health, Senator Richardson, decided that this inquiry ought to take place, following on the heels of a Senate inquiry which had begun to look at the screening process. This inquiry went well beyond that reference and looked at the broader aspects.

This report on the management and treatment of breast cancer is quite comprehensive. I congratulate all the members of the committee and the secretariat for the tremendous work they have done. One can only hope that this important document does not become a relic on library shelves and that those who have been so committed to getting the report up would now have the same commitment to seeing some or all of its recommendations adopted. Importantly, a clear focus on the issue has been maintained. I agree with my colleague the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) that reports such as this need to be considered in detail, particularly with regard to where the priorities lie.

I was particularly heartened to read the recommendations in relation to people in rural and remote areas of Australia. Those patients live well beyond the treatment centres of urban Australia and have difficulties not only in having to face a terrible and devastating disease but also because of isolation, remoteness and accessing ongoing treatment and primary treatment.
I refer to the summary of the report because some good points were made. In the preliminary observations section of the report it says:

SPEECH.PARA: A considerable volume of evidence has been gathered by the Committee which shows that women who have not had access to specialist, multidisciplinary care have been disadvantaged in terms of receiving "best practice" management and treatment for breast cancer. Those at greatest disadvantage in accessing such multidisciplinary care are some women from rural and remote areas, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women, and women from non-English speaking backgrounds.
I am particularly pleased to see that this has been a focus.

PARA.TAB: I also read with interest the submission by the daughter of a woman living in remote and rural Australia. That submission highlighted not only the problem for the patients but also the grave difficulties for families trying to offer support services. So there is little doubt that women from rural and remote areas face additional trauma because of the difficulty of accessing primary and ongoing treatment and counselling. The submission from Danielle Kelly highlighted the difficulties in giving families of cancer patients in rural and remote areas the support that they need. I hope also that the recommendations to broaden and standardise the travel assistance schemes and the provision of child care will be amongst some of the urgent matters to be addressed in this bill, given the special difficulties of women in rural and remote communities.

The other matter which I hope the committee will get behind and push with a very great degree of urgency is the matter of mammary prosthesis. It is nothing short of scandalous that women in Australia cannot obtain a rebate from Medicare for mammary prosthesis, and I note that the committee has put a degree of urgency on that.

There are many issues raised in this report which have great weight and which deserve considerable attention. As I said, I would like to congratulate all of those who have been involved in this report on the management and treatment of breast cancer, and I look forward to seeing some positive action to forward some of these recommendations and to get legislation in place to make sure that some of the anomalies currently in the system are addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mrs Silvia

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very proud to stand here as a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs and support the motion that the House take note of its Report on the management and treatment of breast cancer. I also take this opportunity to thank my colleagues on the committee and on the subcommittee that dealt with this subject for allowing me to be part of the investigation, because it was an area that I was particularly interested in when I came into this House. In fact, in October 1993, I made a speech in the House following a comment from the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans), who, incidentally, ended up on this particular committee and took an interest in it. He had made the comment, in October 1993, that it was nothing short of irresponsible that, in his words, mammography was `demeaning and painful' for the woman who was being tested.

PARA.TAB: In our mammography units, the technical competence and expertise of those involved is incredibly high. It is an expertise that has been built up from worldwide experience. Standing here approximately three weeks after having my last mammography test, I would like to suggest that it is far better that women experience a small amount of discomfort under this quality procedure than that they live with the thought—as many women in Australia do—that they may have breast cancer and are too frightened to do anything about it. I am quite happy to experience that small amount of discomfort if only to have that moment of receiving a letter, as I did last Friday, which says that it is all clear. It is by no means demeaning to me as a woman or, I am sure, to any other woman. Peace of mind is far more important.

I note that I made that speech on 21 October 1993 and, as we have heard already, my colleague beside me here, the honourable member for Brand, pushed this issue to the forefront in November 1993. Often these things happen because of the dedication of those who are interested. All the members of the committee were extremely interested in this subject and that is why we members—from both sides of this House—dedicated so much time to pursuing this issue.

The report is very detailed and I would like to talk about four areas that, to my mind, are of specific interest. One of the recommendations in the report is about the need for education in three areas: education for undergraduates, for postgraduates, and for those in general practice. Throughout our deliberations, we saw the possibility that, in those areas, there was not quite enough education. In the undergraduate area, the committee recommended that medical schools examine their curricula, as a matter of urgency, with a view to initiating courses which will enable their undergraduates to access information about diagnosis, management and treatment of cancer, with particular reference to breast cancer. Attention must be given to educating undergraduates, especially about the emotional and psychosocial context within which patients must deal with their malignant diseases.

As well as my personal experience of twice in my life having undergone a mammography and the three-week waiting period, I have now had the experience of listening to women throughout Australia who have had breast cancer. I know what they have to deal with, in their minds, on this subject. There is very much a need for the practitioners who are dealing with the women of Australia to understand our feelings when we are faced with the possibilities of breast cancer. And that comes right down to our general practitioners.

I approached a general practitioner back in 1991 or 1992 on this subject because I was concerned. The male practitioner said, `Look, don't worry about it, I am sure there's nothing wrong.' That was not what I expected from a GP. I expected a little more understanding. Six or seven weeks ago I approached my general practitioner—I now have a woman—on a similar issue, and she said, `Let's have a look at the mammogram and see if there's a problem,' and she talked me through it.

When I made my appointment to have my mammogram it was an interesting experience. I would like to relate it to the women of Australia. Last October I made a speech in which I mentioned that a unit had opened in Launceston in the previous July. I had not been there until a few weeks ago. If all the units around Australia are similar to the one in Launceston, the women of Australia should not fear having a mammogram. It was the most genteel atmosphere for that type of service that I have ever experienced in my life—a life that has been reasonably lengthy compared with others in this place.

Women of Australia should not be afeard. Often women of Australia are afeard of the next area I would like to speak about, that is, information—or, I suggest, lack of information. Recommendation No. 29 says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that women be provided by practitioners with written information about breast cancer to which they and their families can refer repeatedly. The information should be written to meet the differing needs of individuals by encompassing approaches which range from the purely supportive to the medically sophisticated.
The women of Australia are diverse. One extra area we need to tag onto is how we get information to women from non-English speaking backgrounds.

PARA.TAB: There is a broad range of areas where we need to get information to Australian women. The member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan) mentioned the dissemination of information to rural women. We discovered that the rural women are disenfranchised in some areas and are not gaining a lot of knowledge in this area.

We must provide information to the women of Australia. That came out time and time again throughout our deliberations. Women of Australia want the information to be in a written form so that it can be read by women or, in the case of non-English speaking women, by members of their family or friends. They need the information at their fingertips so that it can be disseminated to them at a suitable time. Often information is given at the time of diagnosis. That is the time when women can become spaced out, and may I suggest that men in similar circumstances might too.

When faced with a crisis or a trauma in life, people do not take in necessary information in a concise form. One may only get bits and pieces of it. We must be looking towards providing information that can be kept within reach of family members, as well as the person receiving the diagnosis, so that they can read it at their convenience and when their minds come to terms with the issue they are facing.

Also, when disseminating information we must disseminate it prior to diagnosis. When I walked in the door of the breast cancer mammography screening unit in Launceston I was met by a very friendly receptionist who asked me to complete a form and read a piece of information. That information detailed, in a very gentle form, what I was going to undergo. Had I been going for my first mammography, that would have been terrific. I already knew what I was going for. In this instance I was having it in one of our units, as opposed to having it in a normal X-ray unit where I had been before. The women there had been specifically and specially trained to disseminate this information to other women. It was done in such a way that, in the half hour or so I spent there, I did not feel demeaned or afraid.

As I left the unit I was given more information, telling me what would happen within the next week or so when I would get my letter back from the department in Hobart. I did receive that letter, which gave me more information. That is the sort of thing that has to continue, not just at that screening level but at the next level, when a woman is diagnosed. I am fortunate. One in 10 to one in 16 women in Australia are not so fortunate. So we must continue this gentle—may I stress `gentle'—but informative flow of information to the women of Australia in this regard.

Women misunderstand what being diagnosed with breast cancer can mean, so information is going to alleviate many concerns and then to inform on what is going to happen in the future. I come out of the education field. I cannot stress enough that that is definitely the way to go.

After further deliberations by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), as the honourable member for Pearce said, we now have a national breast cancer centre. I am particularly pleased that not only is the national breast cancer centre going to look at research in that area and to look at support, but it is also going to be looking at the dissemination of information. That is extremely important.

The other area is funding. Certainly these things do mean a lot of funding. I was a little bit disappointed by the previous speaker's slightly negative notions on this, but may I say that we have started. The women of Australia, with support from our male colleagues, have begun the process. At least we are not where we were 10 years ago, when nothing was happening, basically. So the process has begun and it can accumulate from here. While there are committed women and men—and I do add `men' here—not only will this continue to be highlighted in our country but the report from this committee will never become covered with dust and dirt on some shelf. There are too many dedicated people in this.

I thank the honourable member for Brand (Ms Fatin) and the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), along with others on that committee. We will not let the report gather dust. There are many extremely important recommendations in it that we will follow up. I say that with absolute conviction because I know the dedication of the people I have spent the last 18-odd months with.

Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for the opportunity afforded by this parliament to be on this committee and to work with my colleagues. I thank the parliament also for its dedication in looking at this. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had the opportunity to speak briefly on this report, on the management and treatment of breast cancer, when it was tabled in the House on Monday this week. I would like to reiterate my appreciation of the work done by members of the subcommittee of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs and also for the support given by and the work of the committee staff. I commend the chair, the honourable member for Brand (Ms Fatin), for the role she has taken. I really should say that the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Quick) was no token male. Despite the fact that when this committee was being made up we thought we should have a male, he did not behave as a token male. I feel that he, like other members of the committee, has found it a most valuable experience.

PARA.TAB: There was a bipartisan approach taken, as has occurred in other inquiries. There was certainly a degree of commitment and we worked well together. That is the way that something as important as breast cancer should be dealt with. I found myself in the unusual position of being the only opposition member on this inquiry, but I was determined that the inquiry and the report would be wide ranging and have some real impact.

There are some other acknowledgments which are due. My colleague the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) moved a private member's motion in the House of Representatives in 1993. That motion was related to increased funding for breast cancer research and I was asked to second it. I thought I already knew something about breast cancer but, when I undertook my research for the motion, my education in this area really began.

When I was seeking this information, I contacted Professor Grantley Gill, whom I knew at that time only by reputation. I also spoke with Dr Jill Robinson, because we worked in the same building, although for two separate organisations. Jill works for the South Australian Breast X-Ray Service. She put me in contact with Dr Wayne Tilley, a medical researcher at Flinders Medical Centre. I found myself with excellent material to work with and I was inspired by the commitment that these people displayed to their work. Jill Robinson and Grantley Gill were later to give evidence to the inquiry.

It was also in this material that was provided to me that I found the quote from Professor John Forbes as to how women could find out more about servicing their car than they could about the optimal treatment for breast cancer. I must confess that I got a scolding from an older and more conservative surgeon in Adelaide for having used that quote. Knowing what we know now, I am glad I used that quote. It is now history that John Forbes also gave evidence to the inquiry.

It is appropriate for me to acknowledge the commitment and interest that John Hewson showed in highlighting the need for further research into breast cancer. I am sure he will be interested in this report, and I will make sure he receives one. It was when I first visited Flinders Medical Centre with John and his wife Carolyn that I first met Dr Stephen Birrell, who was also later to give evidence to the inquiry. When I found some technical difficulty, or found that a woman was ringing me to find out about her breast cancer and I needed expert advice, he was always at the end of the phone. I am grateful for that. On the same occasion I also met Wayne Tilley and that provided me with the opportunity to put a face to the telephone voice.

I wish to record my special thanks to all those people who put in submissions and who found the time to give evidence. As I mentioned on Monday, it was a privilege to take part in the inquiry. I also acknowledge the time that Dr Cherrell Hirst, who is the Medical Director of the Wesley Breast Clinic in Brisbane, made available to me when I visited her clinic.

I detected an early reluctance on the part of members of the medical profession to take part in another inquiry, as the Senate had conducted its own inquiry into the early detection of breast cancer, and here was another lot of politicians wanting more of their time. That attitude changed very quickly and an excellent dialogue existed between the committee members and the profession. It was wonderful to hear from the women. I am sure it took some courage for them to come forward. There was an often expressed view that they did it in the hope that they would be able to help other women.

Before I became a member of parliament, I worked in a large organisation where there were over 500 staff. More than a hundred of them reported directly to me and the majority were women. This provided me with the experience of living the statistics. The statistically predicted number developed breast cancer, including those well below the target age group. I saw what it did to them and how it affected their families.

On Monday I touched on the need for information to be distributed to the community and also to the profession. I note that Anthony Green, when he was giving evidence to the committee, said that there was a definite lack of education, not only for the public but amongst doctors and some surgeons, as to the current state-of-the-art knowledge of breast cancer and the options for treatment. On Monday I also mentioned in the House the emphasis that was given in the inquiry to the need for further research to be done.

On that occasion we also spoke about the degree of cooperation. It is important to acknowledge that there is a movement forward. Changes are taking place. Even as the committee was receiving evidence, there was an endeavour on the part of some members of the profession who are leaders in their field to educate their colleagues. The report from the breast cancer consensus conference was tabled for our information by Professor Alan Coates. I reread that report last night, having not looked at it for some time, and I was interested to see documented there some of the things that we have been highlighting in our speeches and that we found during the inquiry.

It is important to note that these people are acknowledging the things that are important to improve the outcomes for women. In this report it says that one in 25 of all women will die of breast cancer and that one in 13 will have it by the time they are 74. There is evidence that the incidence of breast cancer is on the increase. That makes allowances for the fact that there is an ageing population and that the screening programs have led to earlier detection. Thus, breast cancer is being recorded statistically to a greater degree, although perhaps previously, before those cancers were detected, those women were recorded as dying for other reasons. There is evidence that breast cancer is on the increase, so I would like to think that the inquiry will be beneficial in some way.

For those members of the profession who do not think it is appropriate for members of parliament to be attempting to lead them in a particular direction, if they read the consensus report and absorb that they would be going some way to educating themselves. I do admit though, as experts in the field have acknowledged, that it is very difficult to keep up with all the reading. We all know that but I hope the inquiry report may have developed that further.

In the report, a lot of emphasis is given to the emotional impact that breast cancer has on women. I was pleased that a page and a half of this brief report from the consensus conference was also devoted to that. We have made strong recommendations about counselling in our report. I hasten to add that that is not just to benefit patients, although that is important. Counselling would also benefit those who are caring for them. In our report we quoted Mr Tony Green, Secretary of the Divisional Group of Rural Surgery, Royal Australasian College of Surgeons. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure, in truth, that I could cope with seeing more than the number I see now—emotionally and in terms of time.

I work mostly 12 hours a day, and some of the more difficult time consuming stuff is spending hours with my breast cancer ladies—firstly, in the decision making process and, secondly, in the support and care straight after the surgery when more questions arise. Then they perhaps go for radiation oncology, and then they are back again with questions they did not ask . . .
People caring for women with breast cancer also have to contend with such things.

PARA.TAB: It has been pointed out to me that in a report in one of the papers in the last couple of days it was said that our emphasis on the multidisciplinary teams could be construed as setting up power bases. During the inquiry, concern was expressed that centres of excellence should not just be in capital cities and not go out to the country. As members of the committee would know, and as those who read the report will find out, that was not our recommendation at all. The multidisciplinary approach is what is required. There is no need for members of that team to be physically under the same roof. In fact, interesting networks throughout the country and in rural Australia have already been established. We had evidence to that effect. I recommend that as a very flexible way to go.

I have been asked many times in the last couple of days about what will happen to the report. As a member of a committee that worked in an apolitical way, it is disappointing to read reports that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) has scorned the report. I have also read reports that representatives of the minister's office have said that the last budget fixed the deficiencies raised in the report.

The Advertiser claims that a spokesperson for the minister said that some of the report's claims were misleading and that the government stood by its record. This spokesperson says that our committee failed to take into account `new incentives to tackle the disease such as the breast cancer centre and additional research funding'. What a pity the minister is to play politics over such an important issue and what an insult to the members of the committee who have devoted so much time and commitment to this inquiry. Why not read the report and even study the evidence before making a knee-jerk reaction based on political expediency rather than fact?

During the inquiry we heard evidence that Australia had received funding for breast cancer research due to our Third World status—given that the internationally accepted minimum in medical research is two per cent of health expenditure and Australian investment is 1.4 per cent. The minister should have been aware of criticisms made during the inquiry about a national breast cancer centre because I questioned her about it in the House on 6 June 1994. Given the political nature of her immediate response to the report, I shall quote it again for the record. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. Is she aware that there has been significant criticism of the proposed $16.4 million national breast cancer centre announced in the budget? Will the minister admit that all she is doing is setting up a clearing house for research? Will she do as Professor John Forbes suggested when he gave evidence to the public inquiry into the management and treatment of breast cancer: either await the findings of that committee or, at the very least, change the terms of reference so that research becomes a function of the centre?

The often reported claim that the budget allocated additional funds for medical research does not stand up to scrutiny. To prove my point, a report to the Australian Medical Association, produced by Access Economics, states:

Therefore the effective change in spending on health and medical research in the four years is a reduction of almost $50 million per annum. On the face of it, the government does not presently have a strong commitment to health and medical research.

I hope that the government will belatedly give this report serious consideration. I also hope that the report will be widely discussed by the medical profession. Equally importantly, I hope it will promote community education and the production of accurate information for women to have about breast cancer.

PARA.TAB: The media has an important part to play in community education. I hope it can resist the temptation to sensationalise. In this area, I wish to congratulate the local paper at Dubbo. In the days following the committee's visit there—Professor Alan Coates tabled the report from the consensus conference at that meeting—the local paper published a lot of factual and helpful information which could only have benefited the women in that area. I again commend the report to the parliament and hope that it receives adequate attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Deahm Ms M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be able to speak to this report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs, having been a member of the subcommittee which put it together. Those who have read the report will note that the dedication is to the women of Australia and it is to the women of Australia that I would like to dedicate my speech this morning. The other speakers, both in the House and here, have spoken about the substance of the report, the methods of treatment and the management, so I will focus my brief remarks on some of the women that we came into contact with during the inquiry and also the women of my electorate.

PARA.TAB: As a woman—and I think I can probably speak for the other women on the subcommittee—I found it was a very personal experience working on this inquiry. Some of us have had a brush with this disease in one way or another. Some years ago, I had a benign lump removed from my right breast. At the time, the gynaecologist who was treating me did not know whether the lump was cancerous. He thought it was not and, as it turned out, it was not. But, nevertheless, having an operation to remove a lump, about the size of a golf ball, was fairly traumatic and also painful. I felt very much in line with the issue.

During the inquiry I often remarked to some of my colleagues, as we were listening to the most intimate of evidence, that I found my hand reaching towards my chest to see that everything was all right. It is something that I think only a woman could understand; it was a very moving experience. Of course, listening to that sort of medical evidence, apart from wanting to clutch my breast to see that it was okay, I was wondering: who is right? We heard such a variety of evidence. We heard from a doctor who thought that every case of breast cancer ought to result in a mastectomy and we heard from others who thought that other kinds of treatment were appropriate. I felt a mounting degree of confusion which has, to a great extent, been alleviated by the report.

Women talked to us about their dealings with the medical profession in their particular cases. The quote which is at the introduction of chapter 2 is, I think, very apt and I would like to read it. This woman said:

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps at 38 years old I was caught in a system that assumed patients are older and more willing to give in to the medical pressure. . . . Decisions were being made on my behalf and I was expected to agree and not be a problem. This kind of pressure is very difficult to withstand. . . . I don't think women are considered as equals in the decision making process. I don't know how this attitude can be turned around but I certainly felt I was treated like a child who should leave everything to the grownups.

That is a quote dealing with breast cancer, but it is a quote that could apply to a lot of women in dealing with the medical profession, particularly older women. I think that younger women are a bit more wise now. They see themselves as equals with the doctors and do not treat them like gods. But it reminded me of my sister's story about her mother-in-law who, while tending an ailing and ageing spouse, used to sit indoors all day if the doctor said, `I might pop in tomorrow.'

PARA.TAB: That sort of attitude has gone through the profession, particularly when dealing with such an intimate part of a woman. I guess that, because of their reproductive capacity, women do get prodded and `mauled' a lot more perhaps than men do, so we are very sensitive to that. Most gynaecologists until fairly recently were men. I had a theory once that a lot of men went into gynaecology because they hated women. Certainly some that I had dealings with were that way, but I am glad to say that I found that some are excellent and very compassionate. But that can be a real problem.

Female conditioning is part of that in saying that the doctor knows best, we must do as we are told. We had quite a number of instances of medical insensitivity to women. One woman—the members of the committee will recognise her—gave some very strong evidence. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: I had a young doctor resident there . . . I was talking to him just casually one day . . . and I said something about the future. He said to me, `Oh, if I were in your situation, I wouldn't plan the future.' And I said, `Oh! What do you reckon?'. He said, `You might live two months' and he sat back.
. . . Then he looked at me and said, `Of course, you might live 20 years, but neither one of them is really very likely. But do not plan your future too far ahead, will you?'

This is a woman who had a very responsible position in the community. She lives a fair way from a major city. When she discovered that she had breast cancer, the specialist who gave her the news said something like, `Well, you've got breast cancer. Do you have private insurance?' When she said no, he held the door open and said, `I don't treat public patients.' The honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) has talked about the need for sensitivity, the need for counselling and the psychological effects. I must say that I felt, `My God, how would I feel if something like that happened?' Any woman hearing that would be absolutely devastated.

PARA.TAB: This same woman had to travel a long way to a major city for chemotherapy, thought she had finished the course, came back and was told that, no, she had only had half of it. When she refused to go back because her arms were black and blue from all the treatment, the doctor called her husband in and talked only to her husband. He said, `If she doesn't continue with this treatment, it's down to you, it's your fault'. As she said, they did not speak for several weeks before she resumed some treatment. In the end she gave up and said, `Well, if I'm going to die, I'm going to die.' She is still a very prominent person in her community and surviving.

But the kind of women that we spoke to would fall into two categories—obviously, younger women and older women. In relation to the older women I found that, certainly in the inquiry but also in my electorate, I had a lot of women come to see me after I had made it known that I was on this committee. Also one of my local doctors arranged for a whole morning in his surgery when he brought in, one after another, women with breast cancer that he had treated. The stories of the older women were very tragic because most of them were, by that time, at a stage where the cancer had spread to other parts of the body—it is particularly tragic once it is in the bones. They were undergoing at that stage, I guess, palliative treatment and pain control.

One woman gave me a little notebook that she kept. She had entered every contact, every experience and every treatment in it. It went back over some years. I felt very emotional about seeing that—the record of her life and her treatment. Her husband was beside her and very supportive. She talked positively about what was happening next. I thought she was going to die, and probably quite soon. But she stoically went on.

We also met some of the women in Dubbo whom the member for Adelaide referred to, particularly women on farms, who were, in many cases, running the farms themselves. They had to go to the city for treatment—for surgery and for radiotherapy or chemotherapy—yet they were still there, running their farms and saying, `I am not going to let this thing get me down.' I think that was very important.

The younger women, as shown by the quote I just gave, are a little bit more uppity and want better treatment. One woman in my electorate told me of her experience. She was in her early 30s and had just entered into a new relationship when it was discovered that she had breast cancer. Her GP referred her to the local surgeon—a very good surgeon—and he said, `Fine. We will have to take the breast off.' She actually worked at the hospital, although not in a medical situation, and she knew her way around enough to know that she should get a second opinion. So she went to one of the well-known doctors that we took evidence from at Westmead Hospital. He examined her and said, `No. There is no need to remove your breast. You can have a lumpectomy and have conservative treatment after that.' To his credit, the surgeon who first gave an opinion carried out that operation. He was not too stuck in his ways; he simply was not one of those specialised people. A lot has been said by other speakers about the need in this area for specialists who really know the disease intimately.

The other problem of my constituents and a lot of the people we heard from was the problem of having to travel for treatment. Those honourable members who know my electorate will know that it is a couple of hours drive from Sydney and there are some very isolated places in it. Women have to travel long distances to have chemotherapy and to have radiotherapy. I am glad to say that, after a lot of lobbying, the present government—I hope it is not just because it has an election coming up in a couple of weeks—has now announced that it will open an oncology outreach clinic at the Blue Mountains hospital in Katoomba, so women can have their chemotherapy there. There is an outreach radiotherapy clinic planned for the Nepean Hospital at Penrith, so those women in my electorate will not have to travel quite as far.
We heard also about the psychosocial needs involved. Another interesting quote from someone who gave us evidence was:

SPEECH.PARA: Recent evidence . . . suggests that women who were involved in their treatment decision and where medically possible, offered some choice tended to be better psychologically adjusted at a three year follow-up. It did not matter which surgery type they had chosen.

That goes back to what I started with—the treatment of the attitude of doctors towards women. Women who have doctors who sit down and explain to them what is happening, give them some choices and explain what the alternatives are—as we have seen from that quote and all the other evidence we took—are much better adjusted to their situation, as are their families.

PARA.TAB: Of course, this disease, as we have said, has sexual connotations and female image connotations. One of the things that I certainly would fear would be its effect on how I looked and so on. Somebody quoted a person from a support group who was sitting by the bed of a recovering patient and said, `Your husband will still love you.' I think the member for Adelaide loves that quote. I think that is at the heart of a lot of those situations. I have heard men talking about this disease on the radio, saying, `All I wanted was my wife to be well.' But I am sure there are men who feel that their wives are no longer complete.

I have some wonderful older women in my electorate who make jokes about their prostheses: `Oh God, I have lost some weight and now the other one is too big!'. One was talking about doing the garden and leaning over and having her prosthesis slip out. I think this is where support groups are very important. They mean that the women can get together and talk about those things with like-minded people, and share a joke like that, as well as expressing how they feel about themselves and about the disease.

I congratulate the government on the setting up of the breast cancer centre. It was being set up during the inquiry so we did not have a chance to see what it was going to do. I think it will do an excellent job collating research, developing best practice systems and providing information.

SPEECH.PARA: As other speakers have said, information is extremely important. Women have often had to find information for themselves because it has not been provided.
