PARA.TAB: I would also like to comment on the remarks by the member for Adelaide about the newspaper reports of the reaction of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) to the report. In fact, the minister did not say those things. The comments were made by someone on her staff and, I understand, were misquoted. The minister is very supportive of what we have done and I am sure she will give the report her full attention when she responds to it.

Finally, I would like to thank my colleagues, particularly the member for Brand (Ms Fatin), who did an excellent job chairing the subcommittee, and the members of the secretariat, who did a brilliant job in pulling it all together and looking after us as we travelled around the country talking to so many people. It is a job well done and I look forward to seeing some very positive results from it. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the discussion today because breast cancer is of special interest to me. I would like to start with a quote from the Hancock Family Breast Cancer Foundation:

SPEECH.PARA: Breast cancer, more than any other disease, strikes at the very fabric of the individual . . . the woman's sexuality, motherhood and self-image, and affects the whole dynamics of her family. Like other malignancies, it robs the community and the work force of valuable members . . .
I note that the report being presented today is dedicated to the women of Australia. That is a very good idea because it is a particularly significant report.

PARA.TAB: I pass my own personal congratulations on to the member for Brand (Ms Fatin) for her initiative and leadership of the subcommittee. I also acknowledge the member for Macquarie (Ms Deahm), the member for Bass (Mrs Silvia Smith), the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) and the member for Franklin (Mr Quick). Although the member for Franklin, as the member for Adelaide said, might have seemed a token male, I am sure we will hear that was not the case when we hear him speaking in a moment. I am sure his compassion will be evident through the report and also in his own speech.

I have read the report. I believe it is a substantial report and a landmark report as well. It is significant because there has not been a lot of information about breast cancer in the past. We are beginning to recognise that breast cancer kills six Australian women per day. The mortality rate of 40 per cent has not changed that much over the last 50 years and it is an important issue. I acknowledge my colleagues from Western Australia now sitting in the gallery.

It was on International Women's Day last year that the lobby for life campaign commenced. Some time last year we presented petitions from over 100,000 petitioners to parliament. Those petitions, according the Notice Paper, are still arriving in parliament, so it is an issue that is of importance within the Australian community.

As I said, the report is a landmark report because it covers a number of issues, in particular, improving knowledge at medical schools and helping doctors to become more aware of the issue by updating their skills. It also recommends some best practice treatments being distributed, and I am sure that the cancer centre that we have spoken about so often will be developing those things.

I want to raise two points. The first concerns information. This point has been discussed with me by a colleague in Western Australia. This particular woman has had a mastectomy. She told me that at the time she was told she had breast cancer no information was given to her. As the member for Bass quite rightly said before, when told of tragic news it is hard to take in information immediately. There was no information given to her so that she could go back to her family and discuss the issue. I would like to read recommendation 29 on information. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee recommends that women be provided by practitioners with written information about breast cancer to which they and their families can refer repeatedly.
I think the emphasis is on `repeatedly' because it is a process and the information needs to be looked at repeatedly. The recommendation goes on:

The information should be written to meet the differing needs of individuals by encompassing approaches which range from the purely supportive to the medically sophisticated. Information should be presented in a manner which will not make assumptions about which level of information the recipient will require.

That is a very significant recommendation and one that all the people involved professionally—whether they are practitioners or are involved through government—should look at and address immediately. It is a very important area and I would like to do justice to the woman who came to me and asked me to try to get this information in, as well as congratulating the committee for recognising its importance and putting it in the report.

PARA.TAB: The other area of importance for me in discussing this whole issue is increasing funding. I know that the government is increasing funding in research and I compliment it on that. But I do not believe it is enough; I do not believe it is anywhere near enough. I get criticised repeatedly by the member for Macquarie (Ms Deahm) for a statement when I spoke about AIDS. I was not commenting on AIDS, but on the parity between diseases. I said that the funding disparity between research on breast cancer and other diseases was alarming, and that that was not a criticism of other funding projects but an urgent call for parity. That is what I am calling for, and in every discussion and speech I have made on breast cancer, I have asked for an increase in funding and research, because it is a serious issue that the community does not necessarily pay enough attention to.

Finally, I would like to say that the report is great. It should not be put on the bookshelves of history and be forgotten under cobwebs. I am sure that members of the committee, because of their compassion about the subject, will ensure that it gets the recognition it deserves. I can assure the committee, and also my colleagues on the subcommittee, that I, too, will not let the issue rest. It is one that I have taken on board as an issue for me to continually work with whilst I am in parliament. I give that assurance to my colleagues and fellow committee members, and I again congratulate the committee and its chair for their great work.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—I inform the Main Committee that we have present in the gallery this morning members of the Select Committee on Procedure of the Legislative Assembly of Western Australia. On behalf of the Committee, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quick Mr H.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like other members of the Committee, welcome the opportunity to speak on the Report on the management and treatment of breast cancer. It is interesting to note the widespread coverage in the media on the release of the report. One hopes that the principal players in this area—the women, the medical professionals, the support personnel, and state and federal governments—will have a very long and thorough look at our report, and that they will not only look at the committee's recommendations but read fully the whole report, not just once but several times.

PARA.TAB: I would like to concentrate on three areas in the report: data collection, research and counselling. As a lay person who sought to gain a real understanding of all aspects of the management and treatment of breast cancer, one would assume that the normal starting point would be reading all the available material associated with the topic. I must admit that I could not match the member for Brand (Ms Fatin) in her enthusiasm, but I did try to gain some understanding. I found that the medical side of this equation was readily available, but the real missing link was the paucity of regional, state and national data which would enable anyone, let alone a beginner, to try to comprehend a comparison of treatments and outcomes. In this day and age, with the emphasis on technology and the information age, there is no reason why data cannot be collected, collated and exchanged in any part of this country.

One wonders at the wisdom residing in the decision makers and administrators both in the hospitals and the state and Commonwealth health departments who have not yet come to realise that, without a properly resourced national data collection system which can access and compare state and territory information, enabling the comparison of treatments and outcomes in the management and treatment of breast cancer in women throughout Australia, these women are getting a second-class deal.

The committee was told on several occasions that the hospital registrars, the bean counters, saw the staff involved in this valuable aspect of the medical process as the first in line of dispensable people when cutbacks occurred in hospitals. As a former resident, I was pleased to note that South Australia was to the forefront in establishing a prototype hospital base register system. It is interesting to note the comments made by Professor Alan Langlands in this regard:

SPEECH.PARA: It is essential that long term funding is provided to make available outcome data on diagnostic and treatment strategies. To do so, cancer registries based on the individual hospitals and health areas must be funded and developed as a matter of priority. This requires financial support for Area, State and National co-ordination. Additional funding is also required to ensure that Hospitals have access to the appropriate biostatistical advice and computing facilities adequately supported.
Professor Martin commented:

Cancer registries properly maintained can exert a beneficial influence on medical staff concerned with patient care in hospital. Its maintenance can lead to a modification of treatment regimes, better record keeping and provide up to date results for study by hospital staff. Unless this is done one finds the staff, even medical staff, have a total ignorance of what is being accomplished within their own hospital. I have absolutely no doubt that if earmarked funding was provided for public hospital breast cancer registers, preferably using an agreed history, examination and treatment proforma, that advances in the treatment of these patients would become available more rapidly, particularly if the hospitals were able to pool their data.

I now move to the contentious issue of research. Research into breast cancer is currently pursued in two major forms: research at the cellular level, particularly molecular biology; and clinical trials where differing types of treatment are tested. In this regard it is interesting to note the comments made to the committee by Dr Stephen Birrell from the Flinders Medical Centre on the overall lack of financial support for medical research:
Unless you know the data, you cannot offer solutions; you cannot offer patients choice.

This is the second time that I have been involved in a House committee report on health issues. In the other case I was also amazed at the lack of coordination in the health system in this country. I guess, as a beginner, that this is a result of having vested control in the states and then expecting the federal government to fill in the pieces or pick up the tab when the system fails or when there is a need to have a national approach to a particular health issue. Another complicating issue is the size of and power exerted by the very large hospitals in the capital cities. Quite often their priorities are not those of the governments and by their ingenuity they have managed to find funding sources outside the system.

PARA.TAB: It does appal me as an Australian to realise that Australia has achieved recognition as a Third World country when it comes to the amount of money allocated to medical research. What annoys me even more is that there does not appear to be any concerted, systematic and rational approach to the whole issue by all the sectors involved. I think it is time to stop the point scoring and address the issues immediately. We must work to stop the whole issue of health funding, and health research funding in particular, being addressed on an ad hoc basis.

I now move to the issue of counselling, an area that I am very interested in. Most people when faced with a visit to the doctor have a genuine feeling of inadequacy. When a woman is being treated for breast cancer there is a real and continuing need for her to be able to communicate freely and frequently with those treating her.

Evidence provided to the committee as it journeyed throughout Australia showed us in graphic terms that we have serious deficiencies in this area. The blame cannot and should not be shafted home to any one group. To show both sides of this problem, I would like to read two quotes. The first is from Ms Pat Coonan from the Cancer Support Group of Victoria. She states:

SPEECH.PARA: Many breast cancer patients complain to us about the cold and clinical way their medical practitioner or specialist informs them of a cancer diagnosis. There often appears to be little account taken of how the diagnosis affects the patient emotionally or how the prospect of surgery may damage the patient's relationship with her partner if she has one. Sometimes marriages break down after breast surgery. Many medical practitioners do not refer their patients to organisations such as ours for support.

On the other side of the spectrum, Mr Anthony Green, a member of the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons, made a statement, and this has already been referred to by another honourable member today. He stated:

I am not sure, in truth, that I could cope with seeing more than the number I see now—emotionally and in terms of time . . . I work mostly 12 hours a day, and some of the more difficult time consuming stuff is spending hours with my breast cancer ladies—firstly, in the decision making process and, secondly, in the support and care straight after surgery when more questions arise. Then they perhaps go for radiation oncology, and then they are back again with questions they did not ask.

It is disappointing and very unfortunate for the women in Australia, and their families, that the need for the integrated participation of the specially trained nurse or some other professionally trained counsellor in the management and treatment of breast cancer has not received the recognition and support it deserves.

PARA.TAB: There is a world class model operating in the United Kingdom and its value is slowly being recognised here in Australia. Professor Grantley Gill of the Royal Adelaide Hospital gave evidence to the committee. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I think one of the things we could do, and which we are going to do at the Royal Adelaide Hospital because we got funding for it, is something which I saw working very well last year when I visited a few breast units in the United Kingdom. Over there all the breast units have one or more breast care nurses who have psychological training as well as working with the clinic.

. . . I think you need backup from the time the patient is seen by a doctor in a clinic, for however many appointments there are, to when they come into the hospital. That is where these breast care nurse-counsellors provide that backup, often with an outreach situation; they meet the patient in the clinic; they become involved with the family; and they monitor any problems or changes in decision . . .

As other speakers have mentioned, there are many other issues tied up in this wonderful report and they are just as frustrating to address. There are many wonderful examples of best practice cancer management and treatment throughout Australia. The women of Australia deserve the very best irrespective of where they live.

PARA.TAB: I trust that all those involved in the management and treatment of breast cancer take note of our recommendations and I look forward to the government's considered response to this report. Once again, I thank all my fellow honourable members of the committee for their sterling work in this report under the able `chairability' of the honourable member for Brand and her wonderful guiding hand throughout. I sincerely thank people for the opportunity to serve on the committee. I commend the report to the Main Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs report on the management and treatment of breast cancer is the second major report on breast cancer produced by the current parliament. The first, which dealt with breast cancer screening and the treatment in Australia, was conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs last year and was responded to by the government in December. While there is some amount of overlap between the two reports, they provide an overview of breast cancer and raise many important questions about the way we are dealing with the disease, from screening right through to education and research. Today I wish to touch on some of these issues, particularly as they relate to women in my regionally based electorate of Hinkler. Breast cancer is the most common cause of cancer in women. However, it is really a disease that ultimately touches every person, male or female, and every dimension of the family; and even the extended family is affected. The statistics are even more frightening, with breast cancer affecting one in 12 Australian women. Over 6,000 women a year are diagnosed with breast cancer in Australia. About 2,500 women per year, or seven per day, die of the disease in Australia. On present trends—and this is a frightening statistic—over the next 10 years, if current patterns were to stay in place, 30,000 women would die of breast cancer.

PARA.TAB: With the growing focus and awareness of breast cancer since the last election, these two parliamentary inquiries are both timely and very valuable, as they have generated a lot of interest, information and community discussion. What I have found most pleasing in these two reports is the recognition, at last, of the disadvantage and sacrifice faced by women living in rural and regional areas such as my own, based on the provincial cities of Bundaberg and Gladstone.

The 1991 census figures showed that 47 per cent of women aged 35 years and over reside in non-capital city areas. I suspect the figure is even higher in Queensland. There is clearly a huge responsibility for government and the medical fraternity to address the need of these women living outside the capital cities, particularly as breast cancer is a disease that affects older women. Yet, as these two parliamentary reports testify, this has been the area where the infrastructure and support for screening, treatment and management of breast cancer have been abysmally lacking.

There is no clearer evidence of this than in my own electorate of Hinkler, yet fortunately I can report that in relation to public screening facilities the situation is at least on the improve. Women over 40 years of age and living in Bundaberg, in the Wide Bay-Burnett subregion, generally have not found it easy to take advantage of the Commonwealth's much publicised national program for early detection of breast cancer.

These at risk women have to travel up to 300 kilometres or more in one direction or other to access free public screening, either to Nambour on the Sunshine Coast or to Rockhampton in Central Queensland. For many of these women it is a one- or two-day trip that is difficult to afford in time and money, as many of them have the responsibilities of children and/or workplace activities. Too often, women have to put off getting a screening mammogram because of the inconvenience and the cost. Thankfully, from time to time, various community organisations have organised the so-called `boob buses', a term I do not use in any disparaging way. They are a measure of the substandard service that has to be offered to women, notwithstanding the fact that the people who organise those services do a marvellous job.

Following the government's further five-year commitment to the national screening program as contained in last year's budget, Wide Bay-Burnett women will at last be able to have access to a free screening centre closer to home. Last July, after several years of waiting and lengthy community consultation, a new three-pronged public screening service was announced for the southern part of my region. This will include a fixed screening and assessment unit based in Bundaberg, a satellite service based in Hervey Bay, and a relocatable unit to travel to the more remote hospitals within the region.

The new $800,000 screening and assessment unit in Bundaberg is due for completion in the middle of this year and will include a medical director, Dr Therese Ryan—who has already been appointed—a radiographer and nursing and administrative staff. The unit will also have access to other specialist staff, both public and private, including pathologists and radiologists. It will provide a caring and multidisciplinary approach, as discussed by my colleague the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), in terms of breast cancer screening in the Wide Bay area.

There has been some debate in the Bundaberg community that the new public facility will simply duplicate the service that is already provided by the private sector. This is a fact that comes out in one of the recommendations of the Senate committee's report, recommendation 16, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Program avoid any duplication in the provision of screening services, but that it utilise both the private and public sectors in the provision of screening services subject to all the services meeting the guidelines for accreditation established by the National Program.

Some duplication will occur in Bundaberg, but that will only be to a certain extent. Wide Bay and Burnett women can currently get a screening mammogram from a private clinic; however, it is not free. Only diagnostic mammograms attract the Medicare rebate, and that is only if there are actual symptoms of breast cancer or if there is a history of disease in the family. One civic-minded local clinic has been charging patients the Medicare rebate level of 85 per cent of the scheduled fee so, in that instance, there has been no additional cost. However, the fees have to be paid up front.

PARA.TAB: Further, the new Bundaberg public clinic will provide a complete, specialist and unique information centre for breast cancer screening. Where private operators have won the day and have provided the free public screening program, such as in Cairns in Far North Queensland, the private operator has set up a specialist facility like the public facility planned for Bundaberg. I am certainly a firm believer in making greater use of the private sector, and I expect there will be some significant contribution from the private sector in the provision of the national screening program in the Wide Bay and Burnett area. Firstly, it is likely that the Bundaberg core centre will use privately based radiologists to read film; and, secondly, the satellite service at Hervey Bay, while not yet finalised, could possibly be contracted out to a private operator.

That aside, given the long wait that the Wide Bay and Burnett women have had, and still have, for such a free screening service, I have publicly supported the interim measure of the government paying a fee or a rebate to private clinics that perform screening mammograms for eligible women in the age group at risk, or for those who require diagnostic help. Given the sheer number of women to be screened in the Wide Bay and Burnett area, making use of private facilities in the interim would seem a commonsense approach.

Moving then to the northern part of my electorate, which is in Central Queensland, women from Gladstone, Mackay and Longreach, and from the central west in general, have had to travel to Rockhampton to take advantage of a free public screening program. A number of community organisations and individuals have assisted some of these women in overcoming the disadvantage of distance, in recent years.

In Gladstone, I would particularly like to commend the efforts of the former President of the Port Curtis Lioness Club, Maria van Gorkom, who, after her mother's brush with breast cancer, made a personal commitment to try to assist as many local women as possible to access the Rockhampton screening service. Over the last two years, she has organised some twenty-eight 18-seater buses to transport local women to Rockhampton. In total, she and the Port Curtis Lioness Club have transported over 400 Gladstone women to Rockhampton. This is truly a remarkable achievement, and I understand that the Lioness Club buses are still operating under the new president, Shirley Lee.

Still, for many of these women, and other women in centres such as Biloela and elsewhere in the northern part of my electorate, it takes at least a whole day—if not two days—to obtain a free mammogram in Rockhampton. For women of Longreach and the central west—part of the electorates of my colleagues the members for Kennedy (Mr Katter), Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) and Capricornia (Ms Henzell)—the time taken is more like three days: a day to drive in; a day for the screening; and a day to get home. Again, many women have been unable to afford this sort of time and cost, and have put their own health at risk for the sake of the family business.

Thankfully, this situation is about to change, with the commissioning of a new mobile breast screening van to be ready in mid-April. This van, complete with two roving radiographers, should be ready to handle about 40 women a day. It will enable women who had previously been unable to readily access Rockhampton to have access to a regular public screening service: something that their city sisters have enjoyed for some time. The vehicle will be a valuable educational tool as well, disseminating breast cancer information to many parts of the Central Queensland area.

I, like many women and families of Central Queensland, am eagerly awaiting the mobile service's first scheduled visits. Although the mobile unit in Central Queensland is eagerly awaited, I believe the service could be further enhanced within my electorate with the provision of a satellite service in Gladstone, perhaps not unlike the one I mentioned earlier in respect of Hervey Bay. Whilst I recognise that there is not the same specialist fraternity available in Gladstone as there is in Rockhampton and Bundaberg—and my colleague also mentioned the necessity of that networking arrangement—I believe that it is important that Gladstone be recognised in women's health matters as a growing community with diverse medical needs. It is a rapidly expanding industrial city and it needs this kind of service in order to be ahead of the pace, rather than behind it.

Further, whilst I in no way depreciate the quality of a mobile unit or the necessity for it, I intend to lobby for a permanent free-standing satellite unit to be established at the Gladstone Base Hospital. This would facilitate access to women from Gladstone City, Boyne Island, Tannum Sands and Calliope, as well as the rural people from Agnes Water, Miriam Vale and the Boyne Valley.

A Gladstone satellite screening service could mirror what is being done in Hervey Bay. Films would have to be read and data based in Rockhampton, but I believe that would be a better system than periodic van visits, particularly in the light of the demand already demonstrated in Gladstone, with over 500 women having travelled to Rockhampton on organised buses in the last two years. Such an extension of the Central Queensland service fits in neatly with what both parliamentary committees have recommended in terms of access for women.

Whilst my electorate and much of Central Queensland still awaits the public screening service, the broader issues of management and treatment for those women in rural and remote areas who are diagnosed with breast cancer need to be addressed. Again, both the committees recognised this in their reports, in particular, recommendation 31 of the report of the House of Representatives committee.

During the Brisbane hearings of this committee I, like many other people, was horrified to hear a prominent Brisbane breast cancer surgeon say that some women living on drought affected properties had sacrificed themselves for their families, by choosing a quick mastectomy instead of six weeks radiation therapy in Brisbane. It is horrific that women should have to sacrifice their health because of the drought—the quick mastectomy and then on with the work. It shows the spirit of those women, but it is a dreadful price to pay. Another prominent Brisbane breast surgeon said in evidence:

SPEECH.PARA: The problem [of isolation from facilities] must be attended to urgently. The lack of radiation treatment centres outside major cities was a serious concern . . . and giving women travel assistance and accommodation is not a suitable response in the 1990s.
Such radiation treatment centres cost millions of dollars. In Queensland the only centres are in Brisbane and Townsville.

If governments cannot provide additional treatment services, they have a responsibility to provide adequate travel assistance to patients seeking treatment in other centres, whether it be for surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, or some other forms of treatment.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, there should be provision in such travel assistance for an escort, especially for patients receiving treatment for the first time. Psychological support is important for the sake of the patient herself and for a positive outcome. Cancer support workers in my region tell me that the travel assistance issue is amongst the biggest concerns of cancer patients and, as the House of Representatives committee has suggested in its report, it is an issue that needs urgent attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dodd Mr P.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Brand (Ms Fatin) and the members of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs for an excellent report. I will follow the previous speaker in confining my comments to the provision of these services to rural and remote regions. I draw the attention of the Main Committee to that section of the report dealing with rural and remote patients. Forty-seven per cent of women aged 35 years and over reside in non-capital city areas, and that proportion is larger in Queensland. The report states the obvious: most of these women are disadvantaged in their access to breast cancer multidisciplinary teams and allied treatments. The report goes on to discuss lower referral rates and looks at the reasons why this occurs.

PARA.TAB: The first reason, and I think it is probably the main reason, is the current lack of mammography screening programs in country areas, which has led to most lesions presenting at the palpable stage with a consequent need for more radical surgery to be undertaken. That is the real problem that we have to address in rural and remote areas. It is obvious that the second and third are also difficulties. They are in relation to assessing radiotherapy facilities and the practices of some country based surgeons being a problem. But it is true, as the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) said, that we have got a lot to do to provide these services to all women in Australia, wherever they reside.

I must say that in my electorate it is very welcome that there is a breast screening unit now at Calvary Hospital in Cairns, which is accessible to women in Cairns. But I also represent the remote areas of the Torres Strait and Cape York Peninsula, and that does provide real technical difficulties in relation to providing mammography screening programs. I have been dealing with this as long as I have been the member for Leichhardt. The difficulty is that we have not got the technology right to get the screening to remote areas. The main problem is the roads: the roads are just too rough to get the screening units out there. It is very sensitive equipment which cannot be shipped around the country without damage, which would therefore damage its effectiveness, so it is a real problem. That is something that we have to address in terms of research and development. We need to provide some sort of scheme to do that.

It has been suggested that one way of getting these units in is by barge, and I think Queensland Health is looking at that at the moment. That is particularly relevant at this time of year, the wet season, when that is sometimes the only way you can get into remote communities. Communities in my electorate like Weipa, Kowanyama, Aurukun and Lockhart River are accessible by barge, and that may be one way of getting the equipment in. It has been suggested on some occasions that there is also a problem with the reliability of electricity supplies for these units, so that may be another problem, but I have been assured by the FNQEB that in Far North Queensland that is not a problem. Nevertheless, we have got this problem about the roads, and that has to be resolved.

Unfortunately, in my electorate there is also a problem in areas that are not so remote. I have had correspondence from the Douglas Shire Health Action Group, and I commend that group for its concern about this issue. I also commend the Queensland government generally for setting up and funding health action groups. I think they play a very good role. They are set up mainly to lobby the state government, but obviously they lobby members of the federal government about health issues in their areas.

The Douglas Shire Health Action Group has a valid complaint that the mobile unit that has been set up in Far North Queensland does not go to Mossman and Port Douglas. For the benefit of people who do not know, I should say that Port Douglas is about an hour's drive from Cairns, and Mossman is a little bit further on. Although it is a windy road, it is not a dirt road. I have got here a letter from the then Queensland Minister for Health, Ken Hayward, explaining simply that the Queensland health department set up a breast screening clinic which operates out of Townsville and functions on a two-year cycle. The letter says:

SPEECH.PARA: I am informed that, at present, the clinic is fully utilised in the northern region and tablelands, the Innisfail area, and the peninsula and Torres Strait regions.

Unfortunately, the clinic does not go to the Douglas Shire area in my electorate. It is a similar problem which the honourable member for Hinkler experiences in his electorate, in that women in Mossman and Port Douglas have to travel to Cairns. We are talking about the more senior members of the community, and there is little or no public transport between Mossman, Port Douglas and Cairns.

PARA.TAB: The health action group has been looking at the situation, and there is a booking at a Cairns unit for women from the Douglas Shire, which will go some way towards solving the problem. Nevertheless, it is a real problem. We have women who, though they do not live in the remote areas of Australia, live in areas which are remote from regional centres, and they cannot access these facilities easily. Because of the very serious nature of breast cancer, we cannot afford to say that it is easy for women to drive for an hour or to stay overnight. Breast cancer is too important an issue to give those sorts of solutions.

I commend the government when I say that we have come a long way. I notice that the honourable member for Hinkler is nodding; this issue is a bipartisan issue. Although we are addressing the problem, nevertheless, we have to do more. The report on the management and treatment of breast cancer in Australia by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs recommends that the Commonwealth government, in conjunction with state and territory governments, standardise and broaden the travel assistance scheme. The report says that, in the event this cannot be achieved, the Commonwealth should assume full responsibility. I commend this recommendation. I know that the report is referring to the treatment of breast cancer, but obviously that point also applies in relation to screening for breast cancer.

I strongly recommend to the government that further resources be provided to carry out research into how we can provide breast screening units in the most remote areas of Australia. The reality is that the service is being denied to the women who live on Cape York Peninsula not because of the lack of resources, but because of the lack of technology. Women from that area have to come to Cairns to have the proper treatment or screening, and that means at least a two-day trip. In the case of breast screening, we have to develop a way to get screening units into remote areas.

The report made reference to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women. The reality is that the women in remote communities, although they may come to Cairns from time to time, generally will not take the initiative to travel to Cairns for breast screening. If women in remote communities are to have access to breast screening, and remembering the level of poverty in those communities, a breast screening unit must be taken to them. If we do not have the technology at present, it is the responsibility of all political parties, at both state and federal level, to ensure that the resources are there so that the service can be provided.

I note that, in its response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs on breast cancer screening and treatment in Australia, the government said that the National Advisory Committee for the Early Detection of Breast Cancer will be asked at its next meeting to consider establishing a subcommittee to look at the issues of implementation of breast screening units in rural and remote areas and to assess and to develop strategies. I am advised that there will be further strategies developed after those deliberations. The government response also states that access by women from rural and remote areas to screening services will be closely monitored by the program. The response says:

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of financial assistance is a state responsibility. It is noted, however, that such assistance needs to be equitably distributed across all needs and all sectors of the population.
I note that the government response to the Senate report on breast screening states:

The National Advisory Committee will be asked at its next meeting to consider establishing a subcommittee to look at implementation issues in rural and remote areas and to assess and develop strategies.
I am advised that that is happening, and that further strategies will be developed after those deliberations. That government response states also:

PARA.TAB: Access by women from rural and remote areas to screening services will be closely monitored by the Program.
The matter of financial assistance is a State responsibility. It is noted, however, that such assistance needs to be equitably distributed across all needs and all sectors of the population.

SPEECH.PARA: That echoes the comment which the honourable member for Hinkler made and I am making, that if we are serious we have got to provide both services for the treatment of breast cancer and services for the screening for breast cancer in rural and remote areas. I certainly commend the committee for its report. I commend all members for their deliberations on this. It is a very serious issue and one which, obviously, women in our constituencies are very concerned about.

PARA.TAB: I pay tribute to the women in the parliament. The women in the parliament, of both sides, have raised this issue and surely we need no other evidence that there should be more women in the parliament. Now that we have got more women in the parliament we are starting to talk about these sorts of issues which affect women. It is a tribute also to this parliament that we are adopting a bipartisan attitude towards the whole issue. I commend the report. I certainly hope that the government implements all the recommendations, especially the recommendations that I have made reference to in my speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I want to make a few remarks without closing the debate on the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the management and treatment of breast cancer in Australia. I will not keep the Committee much longer today—we have been here nearly two hours and I have already made a contribution in the main chamber—but I would like to make a few passing remarks. Like some of my colleagues here today, I want to make a few personal remarks. It is not something I often do in this place but I remember the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), who is here in the Committee, and colleagues of hers when she was in the Senate, once taking up a matter of women's health and discussing—
—Hysterectomy.

—Yes, hysterectomies. I was not actually going to mention that part of the anatomy, but as my colleague has done so I say that. At the time I think people found it rather unusual that it was done, but I think that on occasions it is rather necessary.

PARA.TAB: As we have canvassed the main report pretty broadly today, I will just make a few personal comments. They are not about my personal health, because fortunately I have never had to experience breast cancer. But I suppose because of my age—I am now in my early 50s—I could not have escaped the fact that friends and colleagues of mine at various stages in recent years have had breast cancer. As a consequence of that, their experience touches people around them, as we found during our inquiry. Families and friends are very much involved in the business of breast cancer.

During a visit to the United Kingdom in 1991 I decided to go to Scotland to meet a man, Professor Pat Forrest, whom I had read about in the Australian media. Pat Forrest was an eminent surgeon but is now retired. He was a person given the task of setting up the actual breast screening clinic in Scotland, and subsequently throughout the rest of the UK. I understand that he has a wife who comes from Melbourne and as a consequence he knew quite a bit about Australia. When visiting here he had made some rather critical comment about the management and treatment of women with breast cancer. I was interested in that, because it was not the sort of criticism that one would just look at and say, `Either he does not understand the situation or he is wanting to have a go at somebody.' It was constructive comment.

So I went to talk with him about the treatment of breast cancer because, just before that overseas visit, a friend of mine, who had actually worked on my staff, was diagnosed as having breast cancer. I watched with a great deal of distress her efforts to get treatment and to be managed by the various people in Western Australia who were available to her. I also began then to look at other people who were similarly in what I called a maze of not knowing where to go and how to get appropriate treatment. So I talked to Pat Forrest and he to me.

When I came back to Australia it was a topic that never really left the back of my mind as one that maybe this parliament could get involved in. I was not sure how to begin the process because it is true that we had begun the debate about setting up a national mammography program in about 1988-89 and, after the government decided to introduce the program with the cooperation of the states and territories, that began to take place. Whilst there are certain comments that one can make about that, our inquiry had nothing to do with diagnosis; we were not looking at the diagnosis of breast cancer but rather what happened to a woman once she was diagnosed. When I became a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs it seemed appropriate to set up a subcommittee and look at the management and treatment of breast cancer in this country.

I thank once again the members of that committee for their contribution. I think twice today people have mentioned the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Quick) as our token male but I can assure him that none of us at any stage seriously thought of him as such at all. His contribution was greatly appreciated—and I think he knows that—not only by us but also by the witnesses who came before the inquiry.

I think it was also a very useful thing that the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) and I both have a medical background and that we were able to understand the terminology that we were beginning to read about, delve into and use. I also thank my colleagues the member for Bass (Mrs Silvia Smith) and the member for Macquarie (Ms Deahm) for their contribution and participation in the inquiry. There really was a commitment and a dedication that overtook us because it is very hard not to get pretty passionate about these sort of subjects.

I also wish to comment on the medical profession. At the beginning, for about six months, I read medical journals and other medical information about current practice in terms of treatment and management—when I could get my hands on any such literature—and I became conscious of the fact that the medical profession might look at our inquiry as being inappropriate and that it was important to gain its cooperation. We needed members of the profession to talk to us, to tell us what was optimal care and what was occurring when they were treating women with breast cancer. It was equally important to speak to the women and ask them what was happening to them and to hear their stories.

My colleague from Adelaide has mentioned some members of the profession whom she spoke to at various times to check and confirm things or to further understand certain matters. I think the first such person contacted us, and that was Mr Colin Furnival, an eminent surgeon, who rang the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) and expressed a concern that there had been an inquiry in the Senate that we were duplicating. I reassured him that we were not and that ours was quite different. From that time, he and I were able to talk at any time when there were things to confirm or check. I found him very approachable and I appreciated that very much indeed. He also came before our inquiry. As members of the committee would know, he is the chair of the breast surgery section of the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons in Australia so his appearance before us was very valuable.Three other members of the profession, Professors Allan Langlands, Martin Tattersall and John Forbes, were also very approachable. I was able to speak to them informally and privately at various times to confirm that what we understood was correct or to glean more information about what the profession was able to do in this country.

I finish my remarks by saying that, in fact, in this country, women are able to achieve and find some of the best treatment and management in the world. There is no question of that. But the difficulty is that not enough women are able to access that form of multidisciplinary care. Our report tries to show how that can happen, and we are asking for cooperation not only from the Commonwealth government but also from the state and territory governments—because, of course, it is they who have the delivery responsibilities of health, and governments can do quite a deal towards providing services—and also from the profession itself and the capacity of the profession to actually deliver multidisciplinary care to women with breast cancer.

In a sense, when one reads the report, one will see that most of the recommendations do go to the profession itself. The way in which I have explained that—when I was asked, `How did you conclude what it is that you have recommended? How did you come to those recommendations?'—was to say that we held a mirror up to members of the profession and let them hear what they were saying. We let them talk about the lack of data. When we could not find it, we asked them if it was there and they said no, and they were telling us how they might be able to get it. When we talked about optimal care, they told us how it could be provided.

We talked about access for women in rural and remote Australia—and the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) and the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) have talked about the difficulties that some of their constituents have—and about how we would provide care, treatment and management of those women. When we asked, `Can the care be taken to them, or should they be taken to the treatment and management?' the profession was able to show us how it could be done. When we talked about counselling and the psychosocial problems that women have, the profession was also able to show us how optimal care could be delivered.

I conclude my remarks today by again thanking all those people who were involved in this inquiry: the people who sent in their submissions and who came before us; the profession; all the governments; and the members of the committee. As has already been said today, this committee is going to continue its work, so we look forward to hearing from people who wish to write to us further, and we certainly look forward to speaking with the profession further about how it might be able to implement a number of the recommendations in the report.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Sullivan) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many (a) private homes, (b) schools and colleges, (c) hospitals, (d) health care facilities and (e) child care facilities are estimated to lie within an area adjacent to (i) Tullamarine, (ii) Essendon and (iii) Moorabbin airports that are presently subject to Australian Noise Exposure Index contours of (A) 20 to 25, (B) 25 to 30, (C) 30 to 35 and (D) 35 plus.
(2) What studies has his Department or other agencies such as the Federal Airports Corporation conducted since 1989 into noise levels at each airport referred to in part (1).

TALK.START.PARA: —The amended answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised that noise contours for movements at Melbourne Airport during 1988 (1988 ANEI) identified that:
(a) in the 20-25 zone there were 5,882 dwellings, 11 schools and colleges, no hospitals, 2 health care facilities and 5 child care facilities;
(b) in the 25-30 zone there were 1,775 dwellings, 3 schools and colleges and 3 child care facilities;
(c) in the 30-35 zone there were 21 dwellings; and
(d) in the 35+ zone there was one dwelling.
In respect of Essendon Airport, I am advised that an ANEI based on 1984/85 traffic indicated that at the time 670 dwellings were within the 25+ ANEI zone.
I am advised that information is not available in respect of the number of schools, colleges, hospitals, health care or child care facilities falling within the ANEF zones at Essendon Airport.

At Moorabbin Airport the 1990 ANEI indicated that there were 250 dwellings in the 20-25 ANEI zone and 50 within the 25-30 ANEI zone. Since then traffic levels have declined which would mean that currently there may be fewer dwellings in these zones.

I am advised that no hospitals, schools, health care or child care facilities exist within the ANEF zones, although a secondary college and one hospital lie on the 20 ANEI contour at Moorabbin Airport.

(2) In 1993/94 a noise and flight path monitoring system was installed at Melbourne Airport. This system provides noise level and flight path information relating to aircraft movements at Melbourne and Essendon Airports.
The most recent noise monitoring study for Moorabbin Airport was conducted in 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, upon notice, on 2 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1808 (Hansard, 31 January 1995, page 147), does the Government's refusal to investigate claims concerning the moving of funds from Papua New Guinea before the kina was floated indicate a willingness to ignore how Australian aid to other countries is used.
(2) Does the Government require countries to whom aid is given to account for its use; if not, why not; if so, how is the accountability specified.
(3) Will he provide evidence of how all monetary assistance provided by Australia to Papua New Guinea has been spent; if not, why not.
(4) Will he ensure that all aid given to all countries in future is fully accounted for.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. It simply reflects the fact that, in this situation, and as indicated in my reply to Question 1808 of 5 December 1994, the investigation of such claims or allegations is a matter for the appropriate Papua New Guinea (PNG) authorities. Should those authorities approach the Australian Government, the Government would cooperate with any duly authorised investigation.

(2) Most of Australia's aid is provided in the form of Australian goods and services for specific, rigorously designed projects and programs. In this way, the aid we provide can be managed and monitored from port of dispatch to project site. We aim for stringent accountability in all our arrangements with contractors, consultants, international organisations and other governments. Further, the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB), undertakes its own regular and intensive monitoring and evaluation of aid projects and programs through its network of aid posts in developing countries and Canberra-based personnel. These procedures, combined with effective monitoring and review mechanisms, make it extremely difficult for aid funds to be redirected to alternative uses by recipient countries and ensure that the aid program is well directed.

PNG is the only country to which we provide significant assistance in monetary form as untied budget support. However, both the Australian and PNG Governments have agreed that budget support will be phased out by the end of the decade. It is planned that there will be, commencing in FY 1994/95, a seven year straight line reduction of budget support to zero in FY 2000/01, and a corresponding increase in sector program aid. This will be consistent with the approach we take with other countries receiving Australian aid.

(3) Yes. In FY 1994/5 $213.4 million will be provided in the form of budget support, $77.3 million will be provided in the form of jointly programmed aid and $16 million will be provided in the form of retirement benefits and termination payments to officers of pre Independence administrations.

Budget support payments are paid directly to the PNG Government and are disbursed as part of the annual budget appropriations made by the PNG Parliament. As such, these funds are disbursed through the normal processes of the PNG Government as reflected in the annual national budget.

Program aid is provided to support a wide range of development activities in six priority sectors (infrastructure, health, education, law and order, renewable resources and the private sector). The sector programs include provision of technical assistance, accountable grants for infrastructure, grants to community groups, scholarships, equipment and supplies to support sector programs and projects. Funds disbursed through program activities are expended in line with Commonwealth financial regulations for expenditure of public monies.

As well as the above, minor aid flows to PNG are also provided through a range of other program mechanisms. These include Development Training courses, Regional and Multi Country Programs, Emergency and Humanitarian Relief, support for Non-Government Organisation, Direct Aid Program projects through the Head of Mission Discretionary Aid Fund and Australian Development Cooperation Scholarships. In FY 1993/4 monetary assistance through these channels totalled approximately $22.75 million. As with program aid, accountability for expenditure is in accord with Commonwealth procedures.

I refer Mr Cameron to the AIDAB statistical manual Australian Overseas Development Cooperation 1989/90 to 1993/94: Official Expenditure by country, Region and Sector for detailed descriptions of monetary assistance to PNG over the past five years and to Budget Related Paper No. 2, Australia's Development Cooperation Program 1994-5 for estimates of FY 1994/5 assistance.

(4) As described in the answer provided for question 2, Australia's aid program has effective mechanisms in place to ensure that official development assistance reaches intended recipients, is used efficiently, and is directed at meeting development and humanitarian concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 2 February 1995:

(2) Did the report conclude that, for the average government school recurrent cost to be a materially accurate reflection of the average costs of educating a student in a government school, issues relating to superannuation, inconsistencies between accounting practices, privately raised funds and accrual accounting need to be addressed; if so, does he endorse the conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2) The report reached those conclusions.

As implementation of the recommendations would be dependent on the States and Territories agreeing to change some elements of the National Schools Statistics Collection, I am not in a position to endorse the report's conclusion. The report was provided to the Taskforce on School Statistics of the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs for its consideration. The varying accounting and reporting procedures in the States and Territories mean that implementation of some recommendations, if accepted, may take some years.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 8 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) According to the most recent data, what percentage of persons who participated in the Jobstart program are in unsubsidised employment at the conclusion of their participation in the program.
(2) Does the data referred to in part (1) cover only the three months immediately after the conclusion of the Jobstart subsidies.
(3) What is known about the proportion of Jobstart participants who are in unsubsidised employment more than three months after the termination of subsidies and after payment of any relevant bonus.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The most recent available data are for the 12 months ending December 1994. These data show that some 59% of former Jobstart participants were in unsubsidised employment around 3 months after participation in the program.
(2) Yes.
(3) There is evidence that Jobstart outcomes are, in general, sustained over the longer term.

Information on the longer term outcomes of former participants was gathered between March and September 1992 as part of the evaluation of Jobstart. The evaluation found that around 53% of former participants were in employment 6 to 8 months after termination of subsidy payments. This outcomes level is comparable to the post program monitoring estimate for the year to end March 1992 which indicated that 55% of clients were in employment 3 months after program participation.

Further information on longer term Jobstart outcomes was gathered between August 1994 and January 1995 as part of the development of extended post program monitoring. Estimates based on pilot surveys indicate that longer term outcomes levels are comparable to those at 3 months after program participation. While the data are subject to seasonal influences and require confirmation through further surveys, unsubsidised employment outcomes 6 and 12 months after program participation were found to be around 60%.
Reliable data on unsubsidised employment levels following payment of bonuses to employers will not become available until 1997.
